CHAPTER 1
CODE OF ORDINANCES
1.01 Title                    1.09 City Powers
1.02 Definitions              1.10 Indemnity
1.03 Rules of Construction    1.11 Personal Injuries
1.04 Amendments               1.12 Extension of Authority
1.05 Catchlines and Notes     1.13 Warrants
1.06 Altering Code            1.14 General Standards for Action
1.07 Severability             1.15 Standard Penalty
1.08 Presumption of Liability 1.16 Pending Suits
 
1.01   TITLE.
This code of ordinances shall be known and may be cited as the Code of
Ordinances of the City of LeClaire, Iowa.
1.02   DEFINITIONS.
Where words and phrases used in this Code of Ordinances are defined in the Code
of Iowa, such definitions apply to their use in this Code of Ordinances unless
such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the Council
or repugnant to the context of the provision. Other words and phrases used
herein have the following meanings, unless specifically defined otherwise in
another portion of this Code of Ordinances or unless such construction would be
inconsistent with the manifest intent of the Council or repugnant to the
context of the provision:
1.   “All of the Council” or “of the Council” means all of the seats of the
Council including a vacant seat and a seat where the member is absent, but does
not include a seat where the Council member declines to vote by reason of a
conflict of interest. When a “majority” of the Council are required for
passage, and three Council members are present, then all must vote for the
passage. When four or five are present, then three must vote for passage. When
three-fourths of the Council are required for passage, then four must vote for
passage.
2.   “Alley” means a traffic way, dedicated to public use, which affords only a
secondary means of vehicular access to the back or side of properties otherwise
abutting a street.
3.   “City” means the city of LeClaire, Iowa.
4.   “Clerk” means the city clerk of LeClaire, Iowa.
5.   “Code” or “Code of Ordinances” means the Code of Ordinances of the City,
as amended, including any document or ordinance included by reference therein.
“Code of Ordinances” means the Code of Ordinances of the City.
6.   “Council” means the city council of LeClaire, Iowa.
7.   “County” means Scott County, Iowa.
8.   “IAC” means the Iowa Administrative Code.
9.   “May” confers a power.
10.   “Measure” means an ordinance, amendment, resolution, or motion.
11.   “Month” means a calendar month.
12.   “Must” states a requirement.
13.   “Oath” shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which
by law an affirmation may be substituted for another, and in such cases the
words “affirm” and “affirmed” shall be equivalent to the words “swear” and
“sworn.”
14.   “Occupant” or “tenant,” applied to a building or land, includes any
person who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, whether alone
or with others.
15.   “Ordinances” means the ordinances of the City of LeClaire, Iowa, as
embodied in this Code of Ordinances, ordinances not repealed by the ordinance
adopting this Code of Ordinances, and those enacted hereafter.
16.   “Person” means an individual, firm, partnership, domestic or foreign
corporation, company, association or joint stock association, trust, or other
legal entity, and includes a trustee, receiver, assignee, or similar
representative thereof, but does not include a governmental body.
17.   “Preceding” and “following” mean next before and next after,
respectively.
18.   “Public property” means any and all property owned by the City or held in
the name of the City by any of the departments, commissions, or agencies within
the City government.
19.   “Public way” includes any street, alley, boulevard, parkway, highway,
sidewalk, or other public thoroughfare.
20.   “Repeat offense” means a recurring violation of the same section of the
Code of Ordinances.
21.   “Shall” imposes a duty.
22.   “Sidewalk” means that surfaced portion of the street between the edge of
the traveled way, surfacing, or curb line and the adjacent property line,
intended for the use of pedestrians.
23.   “State” means the State of Iowa.
24.   “Statutes” or “laws” means the latest edition of the Code of Iowa, as
amended.
25.   “Street” means a general term used to describe a public right-of-way
which provides a channel for vehicular and pedestrian movement, and may provide
for vehicular and pedestrian access to properties adjacent to it, and which may
also provide space for the location of utilities (both above and below ground).
26.   “Will” is mandatory.
27.   “Writing” or “Written” may include any mode of representing words or
letters in general use, and include an electronic record as defined in Section
554D.103 of the Code of Iowa.
28.   “Year” means twelve consecutive months.
Words that are not defined in this Code of Ordinances or by the Code of Iowa
have their ordinary meaning unless such construction would be inconsistent with
the manifest intent of the Council, or repugnant to the context of the
provision.
1.03   RULES OF CONSTRUCTION.
In the construction of this Code of Ordinances, the rules of statutory
construction as set forth in Chapter 4 of the Code of Iowa shall be utilized to
ascertain the intent of the Council, with the understanding that the term
“statute” as used therein will be deemed to be synonymous with the term
“ordinance” when applied to this Code of Ordinances.
1.04   AMENDMENTS.
All ordinances that amend, repeal, or in any manner affect this Code of
Ordinances shall include proper reference to chapter, section, subsection, or
paragraph to maintain an orderly codification of ordinances of the City.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 380.2)
1.05   CATCHLINES AND NOTES.
The catchlines of the several sections of this Code of Ordinances, titles,
headings (chapter, section, and subsection), editor’s notes, cross references,
and State law references, unless set out in the body of the section itself,
contained in this Code of Ordinances, do not constitute any part of the law and
are intended merely to indicate, explain, supplement, or clarify the contents
of a section.
1.06   ALTERING CODE.
It is unlawful for any unauthorized person to change or amend, by additions or
deletions, any part or portion of this Code of Ordinances, or to insert or
delete pages, or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with this Code of
Ordinances in any manner that will cause the law of the City to be
misrepresented.
1.07   SEVERABILITY.
If any section, provision, or part of this Code of Ordinances is adjudged
invalid or unconstitutional, such adjudication will not affect the validity of
this Code of Ordinances as a whole or any section, provision, or part thereof
not adjudged invalid or unconstitutional.
1.08   PRESUMPTION OF LIABILITY.
The occupant of any premises, and the owner of unoccupied premises, upon which
a violation of an ordinance is apparent, the owner of any object or material
placed or remaining anywhere in violation of an ordinance, and the occupant and
the owner of any premises served by any excavation, connection, or structure
illegally made or erected shall be deemed prima facie responsible for the
violation so evidenced and subject to the penalty provided therefore, unless
otherwise provided for herein.
1.09   CITY POWERS.
The City may, except as expressly limited by the Iowa Constitution, and if not
inconsistent with the laws of the Iowa General Assembly, exercise any power and
perform any function it deems appropriate to protect and preserve the rights,
privileges, and property of the City and of its residents, and to preserve and
improve the peace, safety, health, welfare, comfort, and convenience of its
residents, and each and every provision of this Code of Ordinances shall be
deemed to be in the exercise of the foregoing powers and the performance of the
foregoing functions.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.1)
1.10   INDEMNITY.
The applicant for any permit or license under this Code of Ordinances, by
making such application, assumes and agrees to pay for any injury to or death
of any person or persons whomsoever, and any loss of or damage to property
whatsoever, including all costs and expenses incident thereto, however arising
from or related to, directly, indirectly, or remotely, the issuance of the
permit or license, or the doing of anything thereunder, or the failure of such
applicant, or the agents, employees, or servants of such applicant, to abide by
or comply with any of the provisions of this Code of Ordinances or the terms
and conditions of such permit or license, and such applicant, by making such
application, forever agrees to indemnify the City and its officers, agents, and
employees, and agrees to save them harmless from any and all claims, demands,
lawsuits, or liability whatsoever for any loss, damage, injury, or death,
including all costs and expenses incident thereto, by reason of the foregoing.
The provisions of this section shall be deemed to be a part of any permit or
license issued under this Code of Ordinances or any other ordinance of the
City, whether expressly recited therein or not.
1.11   PERSONAL INJURIES.
When action is brought against the City for personal injuries alleged to have
been caused by its negligence, the City may notify in writing any person by
whose negligence it claims the injury was caused. The notice shall state the
pendency of the action, the name of the plaintiff, the name and location of the
court where the action is pending, a brief statement of the alleged facts from
which the cause arose, that the City believes that the person notified is
liable to it for any judgment rendered against the City, and asking the person
to appear and defend. A judgment obtained in the suit is conclusive in any
action by the City against any person so notified, as to the existence of the
defect or other cause of the injury or damage, as to the liability of the City
to the plaintiff in the first named action, and as to the amount of the damage
or injury. The City may maintain an action against the person notified to
recover the amount of the judgment together with all the expenses incurred by
the City in the suit.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.14)
1.12   EXTENSION OF AUTHORITY.
Whenever an officer or employee is required or authorized to do an act by a
provision of this Code of Ordinances, the provision shall be construed as
authorizing performance by a regular assistant, subordinate, or a duly
authorized designee of said officer or employee.
1.13   WARRANTS.
If consent to enter upon or inspect any building, structure, or property
pursuant to a municipal ordinance is withheld by any person having the lawful
right to exclude, the City officer or employee having the duty to enter upon or
conduct the inspection may apply to the Iowa District Court in and for the
County, pursuant to Section 808.14 of the Code of Iowa, for an administrative
search warrant. No owner, operator or occupant, or any other person having
charge, care, or control of any dwelling unit, rooming unit, structure,
building, or premises shall fail or neglect, after presentation of a search
warrant, to permit entry therein by the municipal officer or employee.
1.14   GENERAL STANDARDS FOR ACTION.
Whenever this Code of Ordinances grants any discretionary power to the Council
or any commission, board, or officer or employee of the City and does not
specify standards to govern the exercise of the power, the power shall be
exercised in light of the following standard: The discretionary power to grant,
deny, or revoke any matter shall be considered in light of the facts and
circumstances then existing and as may be reasonably foreseeable, and due
consideration shall be given to the impact upon the public health, safety and
welfare, and the decision shall be that of a reasonably prudent person under
similar circumstances in the exercise of the police power.
1.15   STANDARD PENALTY.
Unless another penalty is expressly provided by this Code of Ordinances for
violation of any particular provision, section, or chapter, any person failing
to perform a duty required by this Code of Ordinances or otherwise violating
any provision of this Code of Ordinances or any rule or regulation adopted
herein by reference shall, upon conviction, be subject to a fine of at least
$105.00 but not to exceed $855.00.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.3[2] and 903.1[1a])
1.   Special Standard Civil Penalties for Stormwater and Erosion Control
Violations.
   A.   Any violation arising from noncompliance with any provision contained
within
Chapter 162 of this Code (Stormwater and Erosion Control) shall be subject to a
fine of not less than $500.00 for each offense.
2.   Each day that a violation occurs or is permitted to exist constitutes a
separate offense.
1.16   PENDING SUITS.
No new ordinance shall be construed or held to repeal a former ordinance,
whether such former ordinance is expressly repealed or not, as to any offense
committed against such former ordinance or as to any act done, any penalty,
forfeiture, or punishment so incurred, or any right accrued or claim arising
under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect any such offense
or act so committed or so done, or any penalty, forfeiture, or punishment so
incurred or any right accrued or claim arising before the new ordinance takes
effect, save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform to the
ordinance in force at the time of such proceeding, so far as practicable. If
any penalty, forfeiture, or punishment be mitigated by any provision of a new
ordinance, such provision may be, by the consent of the party affected, applied
to any judgment announced after the new ordinance takes effect. This section
shall extend to all repeals, whether by express words or implication, whether
the repeal is in the ordinance making any new provisions upon the same subject
or in any other ordinance. Nothing contained in this or the preceding sections
shall be construed as abating any action now pending under or by virtue of any
general ordinance of the City herein repealed, or as discontinuing, abating,
modifying, or altering any penalty, any penalty accrued or to accrue, or as
affecting the liability of any person, firm, or corporation, or as waiving any
right of the City under the ordinance or provision thereof in force at the time
of passage of this ordinance.
CHAPTER 2
CHARTER
 
2.01 Title              2.03 Powers and Duties of City Officers
2.02 Form of Government 2.04 Copies on File
 
2.01   TITLE.
This chapter may be cited as the charter of the City of LeClaire, Iowa.
2.02   FORM OF GOVERNMENT.
The form of government of the City is the Mayor-Council form of government.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.4)
2.03   POWERS AND DUTIES OF CITY OFFICERS.
The Council and Mayor and other City officers have such powers and shall
perform such duties as are authorized or required by State law and by the
ordinances, resolutions, rules, and regulations of the City.
2.04   COPIES ON FILE.
The Clerk shall keep an official copy of the charter on file with the official
records of the Clerk and the Secretary of State, and shall keep copies of the
charter available at the Clerk’s office for public inspection.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.1[3])
CHAPTER 3
MUNICIPAL INFRACTIONS
 
3.01 Municipal Infraction    3.05 Alternative Relief
3.02 Environmental Violation 3.06 Criminal Penalties
3.03 Penalties               3.07 Non-Compliance Liens
3.04 Civil Citations
 
3.01   MUNICIPAL INFRACTION.
A violation of this Code of Ordinances or any ordinance or code herein adopted
by reference or the omission or failure to perform any act or duty required by
the same, with the exception of those provisions specifically provided under
State law as a felony, an aggravated misdemeanor, or a serious misdemeanor, or
a simple misdemeanor under Chapters 687 through 747 of the Code of Iowa, is a
municipal infraction punishable by civil penalty as provided herein.† 1
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.22[3])
 
Notes
1 † EDITOR’S NOTE: For criminal penalty for violations of this Code of
  Ordinances, see Section 1.15.
3.02   ENVIRONMENTAL VIOLATION.
A municipal infraction that is a violation of Chapter 455B of the Code of Iowa
or of a standard established by the City in consultation with the Department of
Natural Resources, or both, may be classified as an environmental violation.
However, the provisions of this section shall not be applicable until the City
has offered to participate in informal negotiations regarding the violation or
to the following specific violations:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.22[1])
1.   A violation arising from noncompliance with a pretreatment standard or
requirement referred to in 40 C.F.R. §403.8.
2.   The discharge of airborne residue from grain, created by the handling,
drying, or storing of grain, by a person not engaged in the industrial
production or manufacturing of grain products.
3.   The discharge of airborne residue from grain, created by the handling,
drying, or storing of grain, by a person engaged in such industrial production
or manufacturing if such discharge occurs from September 15 to January 15.
3.03   PENALTIES.
A municipal infraction is punishable by the following civil penalties:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.22[1])
1.   Standard Civil Penalties.
   A.   First offense – not to exceed $750.00.
   B.   Each repeat offense – not to exceed $1,000.00.
Each day that a violation occurs or is permitted to exist constitutes a repeat
offense.
2.   Special Civil Penalties.
   A.   A municipal infraction arising from noncompliance with a pretreatment
standard or requirement, referred to in 40 C.F.R. §403.8, by an industrial user
is punishable by a penalty of not more than $1,000.00 for each day a violation
exists or continues.
   B.   A municipal infraction classified as an environmental violation is
punishable by a penalty of not more than $1,000.00 for each occurrence.
However, an environmental violation is not subject to such penalty if all of
the following conditions are satisfied:
      (1)   The violation results solely from conducting an initial startup,
cleaning, repairing, performing scheduled maintenance, testing, or conducting a
shutdown of either equipment causing the violation or the equipment designed to
reduce or eliminate the violation.
      (2)   The City is notified of the violation within 24 hours from the time
that the violation begins.
      (3)   The violation does not continue in existence for more than eight
hours.
3.04   CIVIL CITATIONS.
Any officer authorized by the City to enforce this Code of Ordinances may issue
a civil citation to a person who commits a municipal infraction. A copy of the
citation may be served by personal service as provided in Rule of Civil
Procedure 1.305, by certified mail addressed to the defendant at defendant’s
last known mailing address, return receipt requested, or by publication in the
manner as provided in Rule of Civil Procedure 1.310 and subject to the
conditions of Rule of Civil Procedure 1.311. A copy of the citation shall be
retained by the issuing officer, and the original citation shall be sent to the
Clerk of the District Court. The citation shall serve as notification that a
civil offense has been committed and shall contain the following information:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.22[4])
1.   The name and address of the defendant.
2.   The name or description of the infraction attested to by the officer
issuing the citation.
3.   The location and time of the infraction.
4.   The amount of civil penalty to be assessed or the alternative relief
sought, or both.
5.   The manner, location, and time in which the penalty may be paid.
6.   The time and place of court appearance.
7.   The penalty for failure to appear in court.
8.   The legal description of the affected real property, if applicable.
If the citation affects real property and charges a violation relating to the
condition of the property, including a building code violation, a local housing
regulation violation, a housing code violation, or a public health or safety
violation, after filing the citation with the Clerk of the District Court, the
City shall also file the citation in the office of the County Treasurer.
3.05   ALTERNATIVE RELIEF.
Seeking a civil penalty as authorized in this chapter does not preclude the
City from seeking alternative relief from the court in the same action. Such
alternative relief may include, but is not limited to, an order for abatement
or injunctive relief.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.22[9])
3.06   CRIMINAL PENALTIES.
This chapter does not preclude a peace officer from issuing a criminal citation
for a violation of this Code of Ordinances or regulation if criminal penalties
are also provided for the violation. Nor does it preclude or limit the
authority of the City to enforce the provisions of this Code of Ordinances by
criminal sanctions or other lawful means.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.22[12])
3.07   NON-COMPLIANCE LIENS.
In lieu of and/or in addition to applying other alternative forms of relief for
violations of this Code of Ordinances, and/or any ordinance or code herein
adopted by reference, the City Administrator is hereby authorized to record
with the Scott County Recorder’s office a “Certificate of Non-Compliance” lien.
Said lien may be recorded after notice has been served on the owner of record
of a property where a violation has occurred or allowed to exist. The notice
shall state the nature of the violation(s), the actions needed to correct the
violation(s), and the timeframe within which the violation(s) must be corrected
prior to the issuance of the lien. The lien shall remain in full force and
affect until such time as the violation(s) is completely corrected and likewise
no building and/or other such City permits or requests for City action(s) or
review involving said property will be considered until such time as the lien
is removed from the property.
CHAPTER 5
OPERATING PROCEDURES
 
5.01 Oaths                 5.07 Conflict of Interest
5.02 Bonds                 5.08 Resignations
5.03 Powers and Duties     5.09 Vacancies
5.04 Books and Records     5.10 Removal of Appointed Officers and Employees
5.05 Transfer to Successor 5.11 Gifts
5.06 Meetings
 
5.01   OATHS.
The oath of office shall be required and administered in accordance with the
following:† 2  
1.   Qualify for Office. Each elected or appointed officer shall qualify for
office by taking the prescribed oath and by giving, when required, a bond. The
oath shall be taken, and bond provided, after such officer is certified as
elected but not later than noon of the first day that is not a Sunday or a
legal holiday in January of the first year of the term for which the officer
was elected.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 63.1)
2.   Prescribed Oath. The prescribed oath is: “I, (name), do solemnly swear
that I will support the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution
of the State of Iowa, and that I will faithfully and impartially, to the best
of my ability, discharge all duties of the office of (name of office) in
LeClaire as now or hereafter required by law.”
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 63.10)
3.   Officers Empowered to Administer Oaths. The following are empowered to
administer oaths and to take affirmations in any matter pertaining to the
business of their respective offices:
   A.   Mayor
   B.   City Clerk
   C.   Members of all boards, commissions, or bodies created by law.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 63A.2)
 
Notes
  † EDITOR’S NOTE: Whenever reference is made in an ordinance to a City officer or
  employee by title only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words
  “of the City of LeClaire” and shall be taken to mean the officer or employee of
  this City having the title mentioned or performing the duties indicated. No
2 provisions of an ordinance designating the duties of any officer or employee shall
  be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine or penalty
  provided in this ordinance for a failure to perform such duty, unless the
  intention of the Council to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or
  employee is specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the duty.
5.02   BONDS.
Surety bonds are provided in accordance with the following:
1.   Bonds Required. Each City officer required by law or Code of Ordinances to
be bonded shall, before entering upon the duties of office, be covered, and
included under the City’s “Blanket Bond,” to be approved and verified by the
City Administrator, conditioned on the faithful performance of such officer’s
duties and the proper handling and accounting for the money and property of the
City in said officer’s charge.
2.   Amounts of Bonds. The Council shall provide a blanket surety bond in the
amount not less than $150,000.00 for all officers or employees that the Council
deems necessary. The City shall pay the premium on all official bonds required.
3.   Bonds Filed. All bonds, after approval and proper record, shall be filed
with the Clerk.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 64.23[6])
4.   Record. The Clerk shall keep a book, to be known as the “Record of
Official Bonds” in which shall be recorded the official bonds of all City
officers, elective or appointive.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 64.24[1a] and [3])
5.03   POWERS AND DUTIES.
Each municipal officer shall exercise the powers and perform the duties
prescribed by law and this Code of Ordinances, or as otherwise directed by the
Council unless contrary to State law or City charter.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13[4])
5.04   BOOKS AND RECORDS.
All books and records required to be kept by law or ordinance shall be open to
examination by the public upon request, unless some other provisions of law
expressly limit such right or require such records to be kept confidential.
Access to public records that are combined with data processing software shall
be in accordance with policies and procedures established by the City.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 22.2 and 22.3A)
5.05   TRANSFER TO SUCCESSOR.
Each officer shall transfer to his or her successor in office all books,
papers, records, documents, and property in the officer’s custody and
appertaining to that office.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13[4])
5.06   MEETINGS.
All meetings of the Council, any board or commission, or any multi-membered
body formally and directly created by any of the foregoing bodies shall be held
in accordance with the following:
1.   Notice of Meetings. Reasonable notice, as defined by State law, of the
time, date, and place of each meeting and its tentative agenda shall be given.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 21.4)
2.   Meetings Open. All meetings shall be held in open session unless closed
sessions are held as expressly permitted by State law.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 21.3)
3.   Minutes. Minutes shall be kept of all meetings showing the date, time and
place, the members present, and the action taken at each meeting. The minutes
shall show the results of each vote taken and information sufficient to
indicate the vote of each member present. The vote of each member present shall
be made public at the open session. The minutes shall be public records open to
public inspection.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 21.3)
4.   Closed Session. A closed session may be held only by affirmative vote of
either two-thirds of the body or all of the members present at the meeting and
in accordance with Chapter 21 of the Code of Iowa.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 21.5)
5.   Cameras and Recorders. The public may use cameras or recording devices at
any open session.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 21.7)
6.   Electronic Meetings. A meeting may be conducted by electronic means only
in circumstances where such a meeting in person is impossible or impractical
and then only in compliance with the provisions of Chapter 21 of the Code of
Iowa.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 21.8)
5.07   CONFLICT OF INTEREST.
Unless otherwise specifically provided for herein, public officials/employees
of the City shall be subject to the conflict of interest provisions as stated
in Sections 362.5 and 362.6 of the Code of Iowa, as amended, and said sections
and provisions, as amended, are hereby adopted by reference.
5.08   RESIGNATIONS.
An elected officer who wishes to resign may do so by submitting a resignation
in writing to the Clerk so that it shall be properly recorded and considered. A
person who resigns from an elective office is not eligible for appointment to
the same office during the time for which the person was elected if, during
that time, the compensation of the office has been increased.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13[9])
5.09   VACANCIES.
A vacancy in an elective City office during a term of office shall be filled in
accordance with Section 372.13[2] of the Code of Iowa.
5.10   REMOVAL OF APPOINTED OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES.
Except as otherwise provided by State or City law, all persons appointed to
City office or employment may be removed by the officer or body making the
appointment, but every such removal shall be by written order. The order shall
give the reasons, be filed in the office of the Clerk, and a copy shall be sent
by certified mail to the person removed, who, upon request filed with the Clerk
within 30 days after the date of mailing the copy, shall be granted a public
hearing before the Council on all issues connected with the removal. The
hearing shall be held within 30 days after the date the request is filed,
unless the person removed requests a later date.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.15)
5.11   GIFTS.
Except as otherwise provided in Chapter 68B of the Code of Iowa, a public
official, public employee or candidate, or that person’s immediate family
member, shall not, directly or indirectly, accept or receive any gift or series
of gifts from a “restricted donor” as defined in Chapter 68B and a restricted
donor shall not, directly or indirectly, individually or jointly with one or
more other restricted donors, offer or make a gift or a series of gifts to a
public official, public employee, or candidate.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 68B.22)
CHAPTER 6
CITY ELECTIONS
 
6.01 Applicable Codes              6.03 Election Precinct Boundaries Designated
6.02 Designated Nomination Methods
 
6.01   APPLICABLE CODES.
The City Council of the City of LeClaire hereby adopts by reference the
applicable State Code sections as they now exist, or are hereafter or herein
amended, as they pertain to the rules and procedures for the nomination,
election, and other related activities involving elected City officials.
6.02   DESIGNATED NOMINATION METHODS.
All candidates for elected municipal offices shall be nominated under the
provisions of Chapter 44 or Chapter 45 of the Code of Iowa, as amended.
6.03   ELECTION PRECINCT BOUNDARIES DESIGNATED.
The election precincts of the City shall be named, bounded, and described as
follows:
1.   Precinct #1 shall be comprised of all of that part of the City lying
within the perimeter described as follows:
Beginning at the intersection of Territorial Road and 23rd Street, thence South
along the centerline of 23rd Street to its intersection with Holland Street;
thence East along the centerline of Holland Street to its intersection with
North 8th Street; thence South along the centerline of North 8th Street to its
intersection with Jones Street; thence West along the centerline of Jones
Street to its intersection with Fourteenth Street; thence South along the
centerline of Fourteenth Street to its intersection with Davenport Street; then
East along the centerline of Davenport Street to its intersection with
Stagecoach Trail; thence South along the centerline of Stagecoach Trail to its
intersection with Eagle Ridge Road; thence Easterly and Southerly along the
centerline of Eagle Ridge Road to its intersection with Canal Shore Drive;
thence West along Canal Shore Drive to its intersection with Interstate 80;
thence South along Interstate 80 until the meander line of the Mississippi
River and the Southerly City corporate limit line; thence continuing Easterly
and then Northerly along said corporate limit line to its intersection with
Territorial Road; thence Westerly along the centerline of Territorial Road to
the point of beginning of the parcel herein described.
1.   Precinct #2 shall be comprised of all of that part of the City lying
within the perimeter described as follows:
Beginning at the intersection of Interstate 80 and the meander line of the
Mississippi River and the Southerly City corporate limit line; thence Westerly
along said corporate limit line to its intersection with 35th Street extended
and the Westerly corporate limit line; thence Northerly along said Westerly
corporate limit line to its intersection with Forest Grove Drive; thence West
along the centerline of Forest Grove Drive to the Westerly corporate limit line
(encompassing the Pebble Creek North and South Additions); thence South, West
and North along said Westerly corporate limit line (encompassing said property)
to its intersection with the Northerly Interstate 80 right-of-way line; thence
East along said right-of-way line to its intersection with 35th Street; thence
North along the centerline of 35th Street to its intersection with Wisconsin
Street; thence West along the centerline of Wisconsin Street to the Westerly
corporate limit line (encompassing the Pleasant Valley Community School
District Junior High School property); thence North, East and South
encompassing said property and back to its intersection with Wisconsin Street;
thence East along the centerline of Wisconsin Street to its intersection with
26th Street; thence North along the centerline of 26th Street to its
intersection with Holland Street; thence East along the centerline of Holland
Street to its intersection with North 8th Street; thence South along the
centerline of North 8th Street to its intersection with Jones Street; thence
West along the centerline of Jones Street to its intersection with Fourteenth
Street; thence South along the centerline of Fourteenth Street to its
intersection with Davenport Street; thence East along the centerline of
Davenport Street to its intersection with Stagecoach Trail; thence South along
the centerline of Stagecoach Trail to its intersection with Eagle Ridge Road;
thence Easterly and southerly along the centerline of Eagle Ridge Road to its
intersection with Canal Shore Drive; thence West along Canal Shore Drive to its
intersection with Interstate 80; thence South along Interstate 80 until the
meander line of the Mississippi River, the Southerly corporate limit line, and
the point of beginning of the parcel herein described.
CHAPTER 7
FISCAL MANAGEMENT AND RELATED PROCEDURES
 
7.01 Purpose                             7.08 Cash Controls
7.02 Council Finance Chairperson         7.09 Financial Reporting and Record
                                         Keeping
7.03 Operating Budget Preparation and    7.10 Property Identification, Control,
Administration                           and Inventory
7.04 Budget Amendments                   7.11 Disposal of City Property
7.05 Capital Improvement Budget          7.12 Competing with Private Enterprise
Preparation and Administration
7.06 Funds, Expenditures, and Purchasing 7.13 Fees Established
Controls
7.07 Bidding, Request for Proposals, and
Purchasing Controls
 
7.01   PURPOSE.
The purpose of this chapter is to establish policies and provide for rules and
regulations governing the management of the financial affairs of the City.
7.02   COUNCIL FINANCE CHAIRPERSON.
One member of the Council shall be appointed by the Mayor as the Council
Finance Chairperson who will be charged with the duties and responsibilities of
overseeing the City’s finances and other related matters, as spelled out
herein, according to the Council’s policies, directives, and goals. The Finance
Chairperson shall provide financial oversight and guidance to City staff to
assist in guidance and implementation of the listed policies and procedures.
The City Administrator is hereby designated as the City’s Chief Financial
Officer and as such shall be directly responsible for the administration of the
provisions of this chapter.
7.03   OPERATING BUDGET PREPARATION AND ADMINISTRATION.
The annual operating budget of the City shall be prepared in accordance with
Code of Iowa Section 384.16, as amended, and the following specific provisions:
1.   Budget Proposal Preparation. The City Administrator shall compile and
prepare the necessary budget detail for review and discussion by the Mayor and
City Council. Said proposed detail shall be submitted to the Mayor and City
Council no later than the last Monday in January of each year.
2.   Budget Requests; Submittal by Department Heads, Boards, Commissions, Etc.
All department heads, boards, commissions, and other various entities or
agencies of the City or groups requesting appropriations from the City must
submit their budget proposals and supporting documentation to the City
Administrator for review and possible inclusion in the City budget proposal on
such forms and at such times as required by the City Administrator.
3.   Official Budget Document. Once the annual budget has been adopted and
approved by the City Council as provided for by law, the City Administrator
shall prepare and submit to the Council, no later than the first Council
meeting in July, the City’s official budget document which shall include any
and all relevant and pertinent budget information which may be used in the
administration and monitoring of the annual budget. Copies of the City’s
official budget document shall be kept on file for public use.
4.   Budget Review and Monitoring. The City Administrator shall review and
monitor the annual budget by whatever means they deems necessary, cause to be
kept whatever reports are necessary or required herein, and initiate and
conduct whatever remedial or corrective actions as may be necessary or required
by law.
7.04   BUDGET AMENDMENTS.
The City’s budget finally adopted for the following fiscal year becomes
effective July 1 and constitutes the City’s appropriation for each program and
purpose specified therein until amended as provided for by Section 384.18 of
the Code of Iowa, as amended. As with the annual budget preparation, the City
Administrator shall prepare, in a timely manner, any and all appropriate,
detailed, supporting documentation necessary for the Council’s evaluation and
review of the budget amendment. Budget re-appropriations of any kind or any
amount (including line-item transfers) will be reviewed and approved by the
Finance Chairperson and adopted by Council as a budget amendment in the
succeeding fiscal year.
7.05   CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT BUDGET PREPARATION AND ADMINISTRATION.
For the purpose and use within the purview of the State’s Local Option Sales
and Services Tax Legislation and pursuant to Resolution #88-128, the term
“Major Capital Improvement” means any singular or multiple-item expenditure or
obligation legally incurred by the City which usually are relatively expensive,
don’t recur on an annual basis, result in some form of a fixed asset, and which
must satisfy at least one or more of the following criteria:† 3
1.   Any such expenditure or obligation having a total value (including all
applicable “soft costs”) of between $5,000.00 and $15,000.00 and having a life
expectancy of at least 10 years from the date of purchase or acceptance of
ownership by the City.
2.   Any such expenditure or obligation having a total value (including all
applicable “soft costs”) of at least $15,000.00 and having a life expectancy of
at least five years from the date of purchase or acceptance of ownership by the
City.
3.   Any such expenditure or obligation having a total value (including all
applicable “soft costs”) of at least $2,500.00 where such expenditure or
obligation is incurred as the “matching portion” to any private, State, or
federal grant.
4.   Any such expenditure or obligation incurred in the abatement of any public
nuisance or in the protection and preservation of the health and welfare of the
citizens of the City.
5.   Any such expenditure or obligation incurred in providing permanent,
public, infrastructure improvements (not including those improvements
undertaken within the municipal utility areas) in the pursuit of community
development or in providing any permanent, public, infrastructure improvements
as economic development enhancements where the improvements are project-
specific and are not related to speculative endeavors.
 
Notes
  † EDITOR’S NOTE: Multiple-item expenditures or obligations may be termed
  “Major Capital Improvements” when the values and functions of the multiple
3 items can be reasonably and justifiably combined together so as to form an
  integral, not regularly recurring, component of a specific project, activity
  or purchase, and when this combined value satisfies at least one or more of
  the above-listed criteria.
7.06   FUNDS, EXPENDITURES, AND PURCHASING CONTROLS.
City funds, expenditures, and purchasing controls shall be administered and
maintained by the City Administrator, City Clerk/Treasurer, and Department
Heads in accordance with the provisions of Section 384, Division II of the Code
of Iowa, as amended, and the following specific provisions:
1.   No expenditure shall be authorized by any City official, officer, or
employee except as is hereinafter provided.
2.   As of July 1, of each year, the City Administrator and Department Heads
may administer and expend their respective budget appropriations as approved by
the Council. Expenditures should be coordinated and timed as to available cash
flow and should conform with the purchasing authority as spelled out herein.
3.   The City Administrator and/or Department Heads may authorize and approve
budgeted expenditures of any kind up to a maximum of $10,000.00 without
additional Council review. Any expenditure over this amount will require
additional, specific, formal review, and reauthorization by the Council. The
Council may, by separate resolution, lower this maximum expenditure threshold
at any time to insure the continued sound financial management of the City as
it deems necessary.
4.   The City Administrator, working with the respective department heads and
supervisors, will have the authority to cause to be made “book transfers”
between line items within a single sub-program. Any such transfers will be
reported to the Council. Any other transfers must be submitted to the Council
for formal consideration.
5.   Any transfers between funds shall be considered by formal resolution only.
6.   The City Administrator is hereby authorized to issue warrants/checks for
immediate payment of amounts due which, if not paid promptly, would result in
loss of discount, penalty for late payment, or additional interest cost. Any
such payment made shall be reported to the Council for review and approval with
and in the same manner as other claims at the next meeting following such
payment. The following specific items are authorized for immediate payment in
addition to those types listed above:
   A.   Payroll and associated taxes.
   B.   Any legally incurred debt, due and owing by the City which has been
previously approved by specific Council action.
   C.   Postage or shipping costs which must be paid immediately.
   D.   Recording feed.
   E.   Any request from the City Administrator which must be expedited for the
good of the City.
   F.   Employee-related reimbursements (medical/dental, safety boots/glasses,
travel expenses, etc.)
   G.   Deposit refunds (rec. cards and utilities).
7.   Authorized Signatories. Two signatures are required on all City checks.
The Mayor, Mayor Pro Tem, City Administrator, and the City Clerk/Treasurer are
hereby designated as the official City signatories, and such are hereby
authorized to sign financial and other legal instruments of the City when so
approved by the Council.
7.07   BIDDING, REQUESTS FOR PROPOSAL, AND PURCHASING CONTROLS.
Bids and requests for proposals will be used as required in Chapter 384,
Division VI, and Section 362.5(4) of the Code of Iowa, as amended.
Additionally, the following requirements will apply as they relate to
requesting bids or requests for proposals:
1.   Any purchase of materials, equipment, supplies, services, etc., where the
estimated cost is expected to exceed $2,500.00 in value, shall be done only
after having received written proposals, or as otherwise approved by the
Council. Proposals shall be taken from at least three qualified, responsible
vendors. If an item is a proprietary product, this provision may be waived.
Every effort shall be made to avoid specifications or requirements that require
proprietary items exclusively. Any purchase over the “threshold” amount listed
herein made under a joint purchase arrangement (i.e. “State Bid”) with another
governmental agency will not be subject to the bidding requirements established
herein. When, by virtue of any requirement of this section, bids must be
obtained, any and all verifying documentation must be maintained for at least
two years. Once a bid is received and accepted for a particular item, unless in
a fluid or highly volatile market, no new bids need be sought for reorders
unless more than one year has elapsed since the last bids were received. Major
supply contracts such as fuels, etc., shall be reviewed annually. The City
Administrator, Department Heads, and Supervisors shall be responsible for
making sure that the requirements of this section are adhered to.
2.   Any purchase of materials, equipment, supplies, services, etc., where the
estimated cost is expected to exceed $10,000.00 in value, shall be done only
after having received written, sealed proposals, or as otherwise approved by
the Council. Proposals shall be taken from at least three qualified,
responsible bidders. Contracts over $10,000.00 shall be reviewed and acted upon
by the Council.
3.   Local Purchases. Any and all purchases by the City will be made within the
City in accordance with Section 23A.3 of the Code of Iowa, as amended, unless:
   A.   The times are not locally and readily available after a reasonable
attempt has been made in canvassing the local merchants for pricing and
availability status.
   B.   The items and quantities can be purchased elsewhere for a cheaper
amount, including transportation/delivery charges or our own pick-up costs.
   C.   The items are purchased while an employee is already in the greater
metropolitan area to purchase specialty or locally unavailable items and the
items are cheaper than those available locally.
4.   Purchase Orders Required. The use of purchase orders will be required for
any singular or cumulative purchases exceeding $2,500.00. The City
Administrator shall develop the necessary administrative policies and
safeguards needed to effect the provisions of this subsection.
5.   Emergency purchases may be utilized to make purchases outside of the above
bidding requirements if approved by the City Administrator and the Finance
Chairperson and are allowed under both State and federal law. Written proposals
should always be obtained for purchases over $10,000.00. Council approval, if
required, should be obtained at the earliest opportunity.
6.   Purchases for goods and services under State or federal grants or programs
must adhere to all applicable State and federal rules and laws. No grants
requiring any City match of any kind or nature greater than $2,500.00 will be
submitted for consideration until reviewed and approved by the City
Administrator and the Finance Chairperson or Council.
7.   All office supplies, operating supplies, cleaning materials, light bulbs,
batteries, etc., must be centrally purchased in bulk in the most cost-effective
manner possible, consistent with current City purchasing policies.
7.08   CASH CONTROLS.
To assure the proper accounting and safe custody of monies received, the
following procedures will apply:
1.   Any and all monies or fees collected for any purpose by any City officer,
employee, department, or commission or committee shall be deposited through the
office of the City Clerk. If any said fees are due to an officer, they shall be
paid to such officer by check drawn by the City Clerk and approved by the
Council only upon such officer making adequate reports relating thereto as
required by law, ordinance, or Council directive.
2.   Deposits and Investments. All moneys belonging to the City shall be
promptly deposited in depositories selected by the Council in amounts not
exceeding the authorized depository limitation established by the Council or
invested in accordance with the City’s written investment policy and State law,
including joint investments as authorized by Section 384.21 of the Code of
Iowa. Deposits shall be made at least once per week or at any time when there
is “cash on hand” in the amount of $5,000.00 or more.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 384.21, 12B.10, 12C.1)
3.   The City Clerk shall be custodian of a petty cash fund not to exceed
$200.00 for the payment of small claims for minor purchases, collect-on-
delivery transportation charges, and small fees customarily paid at the time of
rendering a service for which payments the City Clerk shall obtain some form of
receipt or bill acknowledged as paid by the vendor or agent. At such time as
the petty cash fund is approaching depletion, the City Clerk shall draw a check
for replenishment in the amount of the accumulated expenditures and said check
and supporting detail shall be submitted to the Council as a claim in the usual
manner for claims and charged to the proper funds and accounts.
7.09   FINANCIAL REPORTING AND RECORD KEEPING.
The City Administrator will cause to have prepared the following reports as
required by law or as otherwise directed by the Council:
1.   Monthly Reports. At the end of each month, a monthly Clerk’s report and a
monthly budget report showing the preceding month’s cash and budget activities
will be prepared. These reports’ content and format will consist of any and all
information to accurately reflect the City’s financial position as determined
by the City Administrator.
2.   Annual Report. Not later than December 1 of each year, there shall be
published an annual report containing a summary for the preceding fiscal year
of all collections and receipts, all accounts due the City, and all
expenditures, the current public debt of the City, and the legal debt limit of
the City for the current fiscal year. A copy of the annual report must be filed
with the Auditor of State not later than December 1 of each year.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 384.22)
3.   Not later than December 1 of each year, there shall be completed a Road
Use Tax Report as required by the Iowa Department of Transportation. A copy of
the report must be furnished to the Iowa Department of Transportation.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 312.14)
4.   Not later than September 30 of each year, there shall be completed fiscal
year reports itemizing:
   A.   Expenditures and receipts for each line item;
   B.   Budget year totals for each object code expenditure; and
   C.   Total of Clerk’s reports for the previous fiscal year.
7.10   PROPERTY IDENTIFICATION, CONTROL, AND INVENTORY.
The City shall maintain a capital asset inventory to comply with generally
accepted accounting principles, to ensure the security and maintenance of
municipal assets, and to ensure adequate insurance coverage. The City Clerk/
Treasurer shall maintain the capital asset records in accordance with a formal
capital assets policy as approved by the City Administrator and Council Finance
Chairperson. The City’s capital asset records will be updated on an ongoing
basis and will be reviewed and audited on an annual basis.
7.11   DISPOSAL OF CITY PROPERTY.
Any and all City property, regardless of type, value or other features, shall
be disposed of only provided for herein:
1.   This section provides guidance for the disposal of City-owned property. It
applies to all City officials, employees, and users including, but not limited
to, full-time, part-time, and intermittent/seasonal employees.
2.   A trail of documentation for audit purposes regarding the disposition of
property as all City owned property is public record, therefore records of
transfer, sale, or disposal of surplus property shall be maintained by the City
Clerk’s office.
3.   Transferring, selling, donating, scrapping, recycling, or disposing of
property by City officials or employees for personal gain or to benefit the
interest of any person or party other than the City, including handling of
disposal of trash or junk is strictly forbidden.
4.   City officials and employees shall not claim ownership of, give away,
recover, or salvage any materials abandoned, disposed of, or stored on City
premises, including trash or other materials. This includes giving any City
property or proceeds to any person or party other than for the benefit and
interest of the City, or authorizing any other person or party to accept,
receive, or take any surplus property to benefit their own interest.
5.   “Surplus property” is defined as City owned property that no longer is
needed or has no practical use to a particular City department including, but
not limited to, vehicles, bicycles, cabinets, electronics, furniture,
equipment, machinery, and tools, mowing equipment, office machines, and
playground equipment.
6.   Disposal Methods.
   A.   If the surplus property has an estimated value greater than $1,000.00,
the surplus property’s disposition must be approved by Council resolution.
   B.   If the estimated value of the surplus property is $1,000.00 or less,
the City Administrator may dispose of the property in a manner that is deemed
to be in the City’s best interests with the approval of the Council Finance
Chairperson.
   C.   Based on review by the City Administrator, with input from department
representatives, the following methods will be considered for disposal of
surplus property:
      (1)   Transfer to Other Departments.
         a.   Surplus property may be transferred to another City department.
         b.   The departments involved in the transfer shall exchange purchase
information, service manuals, and service records and all other applicable
information regarding the property.
      (2)   Trade-in of Surplus Property.
         a.   Surplus property may be used in trade if determined to provide
maximum return for the City.
      (3)   Sale by public auction, including public auctions of other
government agencies and online public auction services.
         a.   Surplus property may be sold at public auction if the quantity
and types of property on hand warrant such action.
         b.   The department that is in possession of the surplus property
shall coordinate auctions with the City Administrator’s approval.
      (4)   Sale, donation, or trade of surplus property to another
governmental agency without the necessity of advertising, bids, or auction
sale.
   D.   Sale of land or other real property requires Council authorization and
must be disposed of in accordance with Section 364.7 of the Code of Iowa.
   E.   Disposal of public right-of-ways.
7.   Special Considerations.
   A.   Items purchased with tax exempt bonds or grant funds shall be disposed
of in accordance with applicable federal, State or grant requirements. If no
disposal requirements exist, the City Administrator will determine how to best
dispose of such property.
   B.   Seized or unclaimed property within the Police Department shall be
handled and disposed of in accordance with applicable federal, State, and local
requirements.
   C.   Computer and electronic data storage equipment shall be reviewed for
appropriate data wiping and disposal. This includes, but is not limited to
computers, laptops, tablets, servers, routers and hubs, phones, cameras, fax
machines, copiers, scanners, monitors, external hard drives, and any similar
device that may hereafter become available for use.
   D.   Vehicles will have City logos and other markings identifying vehicles
as City property removed prior to sale.
7.12   COMPETING WITH PRIVATE ENTERPRISE.
The City, and any of its departments or utilities, will not compete with
private enterprise pursuant to the conditions as enumerated in Section 23A.2 of
the Code of Iowa, as amended.
7.13   FEES ESTABLISHED.
Any and all fees, charges, or rates for any products or services rendered by
the City (including UanyU employee, department, committee, commission, or
board) shall be as established by formal action of the City Council.
CHAPTER 8
RECORDS AND INFORMATION MANAGEMENT AND RELATED PROCEDURES
 
8.01 Purpose                                8.04 Personnel Records
8.02 Definition                             8.05 Records and Information
                                            Management in General
8.03 City Administrator’s Designation and 8.06 Release of Records Information
Responsibilities
 
8.01   PURPOSE.
The purpose of this chapter is to establish written policies and provide for
rules and procedures within this Code governing the management and operations
of the records management function and related affairs of the City (See Section
5.04 and Ch. 22 and 372 of the Code of Iowa, as amended).
8.02   DEFINITION.
“Public records” means any paper, correspondence, form, disk, book, photograph,
film, sound recording, tape, map, drawing, or other document, regardless of
physical form, characteristics, storage media, or condition of use, and
including all copies thereof that have been made, produced, executed, or
received by any agency of the City pursuant to law in connection with the
transaction of official business of the City, except those which may by law be
deemed privileged or otherwise restricted or confidential. A record does not
include a convenience copy made to assist the City in its day-to-day operations
and which is discarded when no longer needed, personal files, working drafts,
memos, and correspondence which is clearly and only incidental to the
activities of the City, adding machine tapes, rough notes, duplicate file
copies unless required by law, rule or regulation, and such related items.
8.03   CITY ADMINISTRATOR’S DESIGNATION AND RESPONSIBILITIES.
The City Administrator is hereby designated as the City’s public official
charged with the obligation of providing for, maintaining, securing, and
disposing of the City’s official records and information according to the
requirements of this Code, State, and federal law, and the guidelines set forth
in the “Records Retention Manual for Iowa Cities,” as amended. They shall
implement such practices and procedures as are necessary to effect the intent
of this chapter. This obligation extends to any and all City records of any
kind except those dealing with law enforcement issues requiring a law
enforcement certification.
8.04   PERSONNEL RECORDS.
The City will maintain a personnel record for each paid employee in the service
of the City showing the name, title of position held, the department to which
assigned, salary, changes in employment status, evaluations, and such other
information as may be considered pertinent. Each employee shall promptly report
all changes of name, address, and telephone number to the Clerk’s office. Any
assignment change in the employment status of an employee shall be reported to
the Clerk’s office in writing by the respective department head as soon as
possible. Any and all information regarding all City personnel-related matters
will be kept in a single location under the jurisdiction of the City
Administrator.
1.   Segregation of Certain Records. Personnel-related records will be
separated in a separate, secured, filing cabinet so that personal medical,
performance evaluation, disciplinary, and internal affairs investigative
materials will not be combined in the same working folders with normal “day-to-
day” payroll, attendance, and leave type records and will be labeled as
“CONFIDENTIAL.”
2.   Records Access. Access to an employee’s personnel file (information not
otherwise classified and labeled as “CONFIDENTIAL”) will be limited to the
employee, the Deputy City Clerk, the Clerk’s office, immediate supervisor,
department head, and others who will be directly involved in making a decision
as to terms and conditions of employment.
Employees shall have the right to inspect their own entire personnel files
(“CONFIDENTIAL” and otherwise) on their own time during normal City Hall
working hours. Access will be granted only in the presence of the City
Administrator. The employee may respond to any item in his or her personnel
file in writing. Such response by the employee will become a part of the
permanent record. Employees may receive copies of information in their
personnel files upon payment of the City’s standard copying fees. Access to
personnel records labeled as “CONFIDENTIAL” will be limited and will be allowed
only, when necessary, in the normal course of personnel administration to the
employee, the employee’s immediate supervisor, department head, City
Administrator, Mayor, and City Attorney. Access to these records will only be
allowed upon the direct approval and supervision of the City Administrator.
8.05   RECORDS AND INFORMATION MANAGEMENT IN GENERAL.
1.   Records Access. Only the City Administrator and their specific designees,
with case by case and matter specific authorization, shall have direct access
to the physical files, records, electronic media, and other information of the
City. As such, all official, legal, and other such requests for records shall
be coordinated with and approved by the City Administrator.
2.   Records Ownership. All records created by any City department, committee,
board, or other agency shall remain property of the City.
3.   Removal of Records. No record shall be removed from its place of
origination or storage unless specifically approved by the City Administrator.
4.   Record Retention and Disposition. All City records and documents, or
accurate reproductions, shall be maintained and disposed of by the City
Administrator according to the policies and procedures set forth by State Code
and those guidelines as established and set forth in the “Records Retention
Manual for Iowa Cities,” as amended.
5.   Intentional Destruction of Records. It is unlawful for anyone to
knowingly, willfully, and maliciously destroy or alter in any manner any City
record.
6.   Off-Site Storage of Records. Records may be stored off-site (in any place
other than a City-owned facility) in order to effect the intent of certain
security and information protection features contemplated by this chapter. The
content, location, timing, and other such details shall be approved by the City
Administrator.
7.   Protection of Security Measures. It is unlawful for any City employee or
official entrusted with such security means to divulge or compromise in any way
any electronic media access passwords, safe or lock combinations, to distribute
access lock keys, or to in any way divulge any security measure implemented, to
anyone (including other City employees) other than for an official City
business purpose.
8.   Computer Crime. Chapter 716A of the Code of Iowa, as amended, is hereby
adopted by reference in regard to computer crimes.
8.06   RELEASE OF RECORDS INFORMATION.
Except when authorized by a statement signed by the employee or former
employee, no information concerning an employee will be released to anyone
other than: confirmation of employment, confirmation of salary, dates of
employment, job title, and department.
CHAPTER 15
MAYOR
 
15.01 Term of Office    15.04 Compensation
15.02 Powers and Duties 15.05 Voting
15.03 Appointments
 
15.01   TERM OF OFFICE.
The Mayor is elected for a term of two years.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 376.2)
15.02   POWERS AND DUTIES.
The powers and duties of the Mayor are as follows:
1.   Chief Executive Officer. Supervise all departments of the City and give
direction to the City Administrator and/or department heads concerning the
functions of the departments, and have the power to examine all functions of
the municipal departments, their records and to call for special reports from
the City Administrator and/or department heads at any time.
2.   Presiding Officer. Act as presiding officer at all regular and special
Council meetings and establish the format and content for all agendas for said
meetings.
3.   Special Meetings. Call special meetings of the Council, when he or she
deems such meetings necessary to the interests of the City.
4.   Mayor’s Veto. (See Sections 380.5 and 380.6 of the Code of Iowa, as
amended.)
5.   Reports to Council. Make such oral or written reports to the Council at
each meeting as required. These reports shall concern municipal affairs
generally, the municipal departments, and recommendations suitable for Council
action.
6.   Absentee Officer. Make appropriate provision that duties of any absentee
officer be carried on during such absence.
15.03   APPOINTMENTS.
Appointments.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.4)
1.   The following appointments shall be made by the Mayor:
   A.   Mayor Pro Tem
   B.   Police Chief
   C.   Council Finance Chairperson
   D.   Public Works and Utilities Chairperson
   E.   Community Development Chairperson
   F.   Council Parks and Recreation Chairperson
   G.   Tourism and Economic Development Chairperson
   H.   Public Safety Chairperson
   I.   Council Community Library Chairperson
   J.   Council School District Chairperson
   K.   Council Civic Groups Chairperson
2.   The following appointments shall be made by the Mayor, with Council
approval:
   A.   Library Board of Trustees
15.04   COMPENSATION.
The salary of the Mayor is $4,000.00 per year, paid monthly.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13[8])
15.05   VOTING.
The Mayor is not a member of the Council and shall not vote as a member of the
Council.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.4)
CHAPTER 16
MAYOR PRO TEM
 
16.01 Vice President of Council 16.03 Voting Rights
16.02 Powers and Duties         16.04 Compensation
 
16.01   VICE PRESIDENT OF COUNCIL.
The Mayor shall appoint a member of the Council as Mayor Pro Tem, who shall
serve as vice president of the Council.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.14[3])
16.02   POWERS AND DUTIES.
Except for the limitations otherwise provided herein, the Mayor Pro Tem shall
perform the duties of the Mayor in cases of absence or inability of the Mayor
to perform such duties. In the exercise of the duties of the office the Mayor
Pro Tem shall not have power to appoint, employ, or discharge from employment
officers or employees that the Mayor has the power to appoint, employ, or
discharge without the approval of the Council.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.14[3])
16.03   VOTING RIGHTS.
The Mayor Pro Tem shall have the right to vote as a member of the Council.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.14[3])
16.04   COMPENSATION.
If the Mayor Pro Tem performs the duties of the Mayor during the Mayor’s
absence or disability for a continuous period of 15 days or more, the Mayor Pro
Tem may be paid for that period the compensation as determined by the Council,
based upon the Mayor Pro Tem’s performance of the Mayor’s duties and upon the
compensation of the Mayor.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13[8])
CHAPTER 17
CITY COUNCIL
 
17.01 Number and Term of Council 17.04 Council Meetings
17.02 Powers and Duties          17.05 Appointments
17.03 Exercise of Power          17.06 Compensation
 
17.01   NUMBER AND TERM OF COUNCIL.
The Council consists of five Council members elected at large for overlapping
terms of four years.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.4 and 376.2)
17.02   POWERS AND DUTIES.
The powers and duties of the Council include, but are not limited to the
following:
1.   General. All powers of the City are vested in the Council except as
otherwise provided by law or ordinance.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.2[1])
2.   Fiscal Authority. The Council shall apportion and appropriate all funds,
and audit and allow all bills, accounts, payrolls, and claims, and order
payment thereof.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.2[1], 384.16, and 384.38[1])
3.   Public Improvements. The Council shall make all orders for the
construction of any improvements, bridges, or buildings.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.2[1])
4.   Contracts. The Council shall make or authorize the making of all
contracts, and no contract shall bind or be obligatory upon the City unless
made by resolution adopted by the Council, or reduced to writing and approved
by the Council, or expressly authorized by resolution adopted by the Council,
unless otherwise provided for herein.
5.   Employees. The Council shall authorize, by resolution, the number, duties,
term of office, and compensation of employees or officers not otherwise
provided for by State law or the Code of Ordinances.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13[4])
6.   Records. The Council shall maintain records of its proceedings as
prescribed by State law or Council resolution.
7.   Setting Compensation for Elected Officers. Unless otherwise specifically
provided for herein, elected officials shall be compensated in accordance with
the provisions of Section 372.13(8) of the Code of Iowa, as amended, and said
section and provisions, as amended, are hereby adopted by reference.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13[8])
17.03   EXERCISE OF POWER.
The Council shall exercise a power only by the passage of a motion, a
resolution, an amendment, or an ordinance in the following manner:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.3[1])
1.   Action by Council. Passage of an ordinance, amendment, or resolution
requires a majority vote of all of the members of the Council. Passage of a
motion requires a majority vote of a quorum of the Council. A resolution must
be passed to spend public funds in excess of $100,000.00 on a public
improvement project, or to accept public improvements and facilities upon their
completion. Each Council member’s vote on a measure must be recorded. A measure
that fails to receive sufficient votes for passage shall be considered
defeated.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 380.4)
2.   Overriding Mayor’s Veto. Within 30 days after the Mayor’s veto, the
Council may pass the measure again by a vote of not less than two-thirds of all
of the members of the Council.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 380.6[2])
3.   Measures Become Effective. Measures passed by the Council become effective
in one of the following ways:
   A.   An ordinance or amendment signed by the Mayor becomes effective when
the ordinance or a summary of the ordinance is published, unless a subsequent
effective date is provided within the ordinance or amendment.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 380.6[1a])
   B.   A resolution signed by the Mayor becomes effective immediately upon
signing.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 380.6[1b])
   C.   A motion becomes effective immediately upon passage of the motion by
the Council.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 380.6[1c])
   D.   If the Mayor vetoes an ordinance, amendment, or resolution and the
Council repasses the measure after the Mayor’s veto, a resolution becomes
effective immediately upon repassage, and an ordinance or amendment becomes a
law when the ordinance or a summary of the ordinance is published, unless a
subsequent effective date is provided within the ordinance or amendment.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 380.6[2])
   E.   If the Mayor takes no action on an ordinance, amendment, or resolution,
a resolution becomes effective 14 days after the date of passage, and an
ordinance or amendment becomes law when the ordinance or a summary of the
ordinance is published, but not sooner than 14 days after the date of passage,
unless a subsequent effective date is provided within the ordinance or
amendment.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 380.6[3])
“All of the members of the Council” refers to all of the seats of the Council
including a vacant seat and a seat where the member is absent, but does not
include a seat where the Council member declines to vote by reason of a
conflict of interest.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 380.1[a])
17.04   COUNCIL MEETINGS.
Procedures for giving notice of meetings of the Council and other provisions
regarding the conduct of Council meetings are contained in Section
5.06 of this Code of Ordinances. Additional particulars relating to Council
meetings are the following:
1.   Regular Meetings. The regular meetings of the Council shall be on the
first and third Monday of each month in the Council Chambers at LeClaire City
Hall at a time prescribed by resolution of the City Council, and said time and
place may be temporarily modified by resolution of the City Council as needed.
When the date for a regularly scheduled meeting falls on an observed holiday,
the meeting shall be held at the time and place mentioned above on the next
regular business day following the holiday. Whenever a public hearing is
scheduled to be held on the same date as a regularly scheduled meeting, the
public hearing shall be held first with the regularly scheduled meeting to
follow immediately afterwards.
2.   Special or “Emergency” Meetings. Special meetings (including public
hearings) and/or “emergency” meetings shall be held: 1) upon the written
request of the Mayor; or 2) upon approval of a resolution by the City Council;
or 3) upon the written request of a majority of the members of the City Council
submitted to the City Clerk. Notice of a special meeting delivered to each
member of the Council shall specify the date, time, place, and subject of the
meeting and such notice shall be left in their usual City business files at
City Hall and delivered via their City email. A record of the service of notice
shall be maintained by the City Clerk.
3.   No Smoking. There shall be no smoking in the Council Chambers during any
type of Council meeting. This includes official Council meetings, Committee-of-
the-Whole meetings, and all public hearings of the Council. This prohibition
shall not apply to other committee board meetings.
4.   Meeting Notices. Any and all notices of any meetings to be held by the
Council, except “emergency” meetings, will be posted at City Hall, LeClaire
Community Library, LeClaire Post Office, and on the City’s website, in
accordance with the requirements of the Code of Iowa. Notification for
“emergency meetings” will conform to the requirements of Section 21.4 of the
Code of Iowa, as amended.
5.   Meeting Attendance Restrictions. In accordance with Section 21.2(2) of the
Code of Iowa, as amended, there shall not be more than two Council members (in
any capacity whatsoever) in attendance at any gathering where there is any
discussion, deliberation, or action upon any matter within the scope of the
Council’s policy making duties, unless said gathering is a public meeting held
pursuant to the requirements of Section 21.3 of the Code of Iowa.
6.   Any official meeting called for or requested to be held by the Council in
the administration of the zoning or subdivision ordinance will be held on the
first or third Monday of the month, unless otherwise provided for herein.
Further, the Council’s formal hearing, review, and/or consideration of any
zoning or subdivision ordinance related matters will take place no sooner than
10 days following the Planning and Zoning Commission’s hearing and final action
on the matter, unless another hearing date is otherwise established by
resolution of the Council.
17.05   APPOINTMENTS.
The Council shall appoint the following officials and prescribe their powers,
duties, compensation, and term of office:
1.   City Clerk
2.   City Attorney
3.   City Administrator
4.   Planning and Zoning Commission Members
5.   Board of Adjustment
6.   Parks and Recreation Commission Members
7.   LeClaire Tourism Board of Directors
17.06   COMPENSATION.
The salary of each Council member is $2,000.00 per year, paid monthly.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13[8])
CHAPTER 18
CITY ADMINISTRATOR
 
18.01 Purpose        18.04 Compensation
18.02 Appointment    18.05 Nature of Work
18.03 Term of Office 18.06 Roles, Expectations, Powers, Duties, and
                     Responsibilities
 
18.01   PURPOSE.
The purpose of this chapter is to create the office of City Administrator of
the City and to prescribe the duties of said office.
18.02   APPOINTMENT.
A search committee shall be formed at the Mayor’s direction whenever necessary
to select a City Administrator. The search committee shall consist of the
Mayor, two Council members, and two residents of the City, and the members of
the search committee shall be appointed by the Mayor. The search committee
shall screen the candidates and recommend a list of finalists. The Mayor and
full Council will then conduct finalist interviews after which the Mayor will
select one candidate from the finalists to recommend to the Council for
approval. If the Council approves, that person shall serve as City
Administrator.
(Section 18.02 – Ord._847 – Jan. 25 Supp.)
18.03   TERM OF OFFICE.
Unless the City Administrator has an employment contract, the City
Administrator shall serve as an at-will employee in said capacity at the
pleasure of the Council and shall be removed from office only by at least two-
thirds majority vote of the Council. The City Administrator may terminate their
employment with the Council, subject to the terms of any existing contract
agreements, if any. Either the Mayor or any member of the Council may initiate
the removal of the City Administrator.
18.04   COMPENSATION.
The compensation of the City Administrator shall be in such amount as may, from
time to time, be fixed by resolution of the Council.
18.05   NATURE OF WORK.
Under the general direction of the Mayor and the Council, the City
Administrator shall be responsible for the operational administration of all
City affairs, including supervision of all City department heads and functions,
other than specific exceptions relating to the Police Department and Library as
indicated in Subsections 3,11,19, 33, and 38 of Section
18.06, direct supervision of the City Administrator’s office, and coordination
of special projects. The City Administrator shall plan, direct, coordinate, and
manage the various services, activities, and policies set forth by the Mayor
and Council in accordance with the City’s Municipal Code. The nature of the
work performed require the City Administrator to establish and maintain
effective working relationships with the Mayor, Council, City employees,
business and community groups, State and federal officials, representatives of
the media, and the public. The principal duties are performed in a general
office environment.
1.   The City Administrator shall implement policy directives promulgated by
the Mayor in the Mayor’s executive capacity and Council in its legislative
capacity, organize the work of the departments through the department heads,
develop the staff needed to do the work, set priorities, and make sure that all
work is done to a high standard of quality and performance.
2.   The City Administrator is directly responsible to the Mayor and Council
for the administration of municipal affairs as directed and is the agent of the
Council and Mayor in all that is done. All departmental activity requiring the
attention of the Mayor and Council shall be brought before the body by the
Administrator, and all Council involvement in administration initiated by the
Mayor and Council must be coordinated through the City Administrator.
These responsibilities are extensions of those of the elected officials and as
such are done in close cooperation and coordination with those officials.
18.06   ROLES, EXPECTATIONS, POWERS, DUTIES, AND RESPONSIBILITIES.
The following, although not fully inclusive, are considered to be the roles,
expectations, powers, duties, and responsibilities of the City Administrator:
1.   Supervise enforcement and execution of all Municipal laws, resolutions,
Council policies, and directives.
2.   Recommend to the Council any measure necessary or expedient for the good
and welfare of the City.
