69.09   TRUCK PARKING LIMITED.
No person shall park a motor truck, semi-trailer, or other motor vehicle with
trailer attached in violation of the following regulations. The provisions of
this section shall not apply to pick-up, light delivery, or panel delivery
trucks.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.236[1])
1.   No person shall park a truck, semi-tractor and/or trailer, or other motor
vehicle with or without an attached trailer which has three or more axles
individually or combined between the tractor/trailer or which has a licensed
weight of 10,000 pounds or more or which exceeds any of the following maximum
size dimensions: 24 feet in length; seven feet in width (not including
mirrors); or 10 feet in height measured from the ground to the topmost point of
the vehicle, in any residential area of the City unless said vehicle is
actually engaged in the temporary (that period of time that is reasonably
necessary to park, load or unload, and remove the vehicle from the public
street) delivery or receiving of merchandise or cargo incidental to a
residential use and is legally parked so as not to interfere with the free flow
of traffic.
2.   Vehicles with three or more axles are allowed to park on Cody Road for a
maximum of one hour only if the driver is utilizing one of the City’s
commercial establishments.
3.   No semi-tractor/trailer combinations or semi-trailers shall be parked on
Cody Road or in any area of the City not specifically designated for such
purpose by resolution of the Council.
4.   Livestock. It is unlawful to stand or park any vehicle containing
livestock any place in the City for a period of time longer than three minutes,
except for loading or unloading.
5.   Any violation of the provisions of this section may be punishable by a
fine as established by resolution of the Council or may be abated as provided
for in the code.
69.10   SNOW ROUTES.
All streets and alleys within the corporate limits of the City shall hereafter
be designated as snow routes, and as such, shall be regulated in the following
manner:
1.   Parking shall be limited to the even-numbered side of the street on the
even-numbered calendar days and the odd-numbered side of the street on the odd-
numbered calendar days. For the purpose of enforcement of this section, days
shall begin at 7:00 a.m. and run for a period of 24 hours.
2.   This section shall be in full force and effect between 7:00 a.m. November
1 through 7:00 a.m. March 31 (inclusive).
3.   Warning tickets may be issued between 7:00 a.m. November 1 through 7:00
a.m. November 15 (inclusive) and after such time and throughout the duration of
the dates and times designated in Subsection 2 above, tickets may be issued for
any violation of this section.
4.   Any vehicle receiving a ticket and remaining in violation of this section
for a period greater than 24 hours shall be removed at the owner’s expense in
accordance with the provision of this section.
5.   In any prosecution with regard to a vehicle parked or left in a place or
in a condition in violation of any provision of this section, proof that the
particular vehicle described in the complaint was parked or left in violation
of a provision of this section, together with proof that the defendant named in
the complaint was at the time the registered owner of such vehicle, shall
constitute prima facie evidence that the defendant was the person who parked or
left the vehicle in violation of this section.
For the purpose of this section, parking in alleys, where it is absolutely
necessary, shall correspond to the street parking on those streets running
parallel to the alley. For the purposes of this section, snow route designated
parking on Cody Road within the corporate limits of the City shall only be
limited during the hours of 2:00 a.m. to 6:00 a.m. when the “odd-even” system
mentioned above in Subsection 1 shall be enforced. All other provisions related
to snow route designated parking shall be in full force and effect as otherwise
provided for herein. Snow route designation or snow route parking signs shall
not be required due to the extent of City-wide coverage and seasonal nature of
this section.
69.11   CONTROLLED ACCESS FACILITIES.
Parking restrictions on controlled access facilities are as specified in
Chapter 140 of this Code of Ordinances.
69.12   NON-MOTORIZED EQUIPMENT PARKING PROHIBITED.
No person shall park or store a trailer, camper, wagon, or other non-motorized
piece of equipment that is designed to be towed by a motor vehicle, which has
been disconnected from the tow vehicle, upon any public right-of-way. No person
shall park or store any other non-motorized piece of equipment upon any public
right-of-way without written consent of the City Public Works Director, Police
Chief, Fire Chief, or City Administrator.
69.13   SNOW EMERGENCY: PARKING PROHIBITED.
1.   Parking Prohibited. No person shall park, abandon, or leave unattended any
vehicle on any public street, alley, or City-owned off-street parking area
during any snow emergency proclaimed by the Mayor unless the snow has been
removed or plowed from said street, alley, or parking area and the snow has
ceased to fall. A snow emergency parking ban shall continue from its
proclamation through the duration of the snow or ice storm and the 48-hour
period after cessation of such storm, except as above provided upon streets
which have been fully opened. Such emergency may be extended or shortened when
conditions warrant.
2.   Proclamation. When weather forecasts or occurrences indicate the need, the
Mayor shall proclaim a snow emergency and request all news media to publicize
the proclamation and applicable parking restrictions.
3.   In all zoning districts, off-street accessory parking areas, in the open
or in a garage, shall be provided and used during proclaimed snow emergencies
of two inches or more, or at such time as the Council deems it necessary for
the betterment of the community. Such areas, in the case of “A” (Agricultural)
or “R” (Residential) Districts, shall be on the premises intended to be served;
and in the case of “C” (Commercial) or “I” (Industrial) Districts, such areas
shall be on the premises intended to be served or on adjoining or nearby
property within 100 feet of said premises and in the same or less restricted
district.
69.14   EMERGENCY VEHICLES EXCEPTION.
The provisions of this chapter do not apply to the parking of recognized
emergency vehicles (See Section 321.231 of the Code of Iowa, as amended) when
responding to an emergency request for service.
CHAPTER 71
TRAFFIC CODE ENFORCEMENT PROCEDURES
 
71.01 Arrest or Citation            71.04 Parking Violations: Vehicle
                                    Unattended
71.02 Scheduled Violations          71.05 Presumption in Reference to Illegal
                                    Parking
71.03 Parking Violations: Alternate 71.06 Impounding Vehicles
 
71.01   ARREST OR CITATION.
Whenever a peace officer has reasonable cause to believe that a person has
violated any provision of the Traffic Code, such officer may:
1.   Immediate Arrest. Immediately arrest such person and take such person
before a local magistrate; or
2.   Issue Citation. Without arresting the person, prepare in quintuplicate a
combined traffic citation and complaint as adopted by the Iowa Commissioner of
Public Safety, or issue a uniform citation and complaint utilizing a State-
approved computerized device.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 805.6 and 321.485)
71.02   SCHEDULED VIOLATIONS.
For violations of the Traffic Code that are designated by Section 805.8A of the
Code of Iowa to be scheduled violations, the scheduled fine for each of those
violations shall be as specified in Section 805.8A of the Code of Iowa.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 805.8 and 805.8A)
71.03   PARKING VIOLATIONS: ALTERNATE.
Uncontested violations of parking restrictions imposed by this Code of
Ordinances shall be charged upon a simple notice of a fine payable at the
office of the Clerk. The fine for each violation charged under a simple notice
of a fine shall be in the amount of $25.00 for all violations except improper
use of a persons with disabilities parking permit and snow emergency. If such
fine is not paid within 30 days, it shall be increased by $5.00. The fine for
improper use of a persons with disabilities parking permit is $100.00. The fine
for snow emergency fine amount is $50.00.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.236[1b] and 321L.4[2])
71.04   PARKING VIOLATIONS: VEHICLE UNATTENDED.
When a vehicle is parked in violation of any provision of the Traffic Code, and
the driver is not present, the notice of fine or citation as herein provided
shall be attached to the vehicle in a conspicuous place.
71.05   PRESUMPTION IN REFERENCE TO ILLEGAL PARKING.
In any proceeding charging a standing or parking violation, a prima facie
presumption that the registered owner was the person who parked or placed such
vehicle at the point where, and for the time during which, such violation
occurred shall be raised by proof that:
1.   Described Vehicle. The particular vehicle described in the information was
parked in violation of the Traffic Code; and
2.   Registered Owner. The defendant named in the information was the
registered owner at the time in question.
71.06   IMPOUNDING VEHICLES.
1.   A peace officer is hereby authorized to remove, or cause to be removed, a
vehicle from a street, public alley, public parking lot, or highway to the
nearest garage or other place of safety, or to a garage designated or
maintained by the City, under the circumstances hereinafter enumerated:
   A.   Disabled Vehicle. When a vehicle is so disabled as to constitute an
obstruction to traffic and the person or persons in charge of the vehicle are
by reason of physical injury incapacitated to such an extent as to be unable to
provide for its custody or removal.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.236[1])
   B.   Illegally Parked Vehicle. When any vehicle is left unattended and is so
illegally parked as to constitute a definite hazard or obstruction to the
normal movement of traffic.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.236[1])
   C.   Snow Removal. When any vehicle is left parked in violation of a ban on
parking during snow removal operations.
   D.   Parked Over Limited Time Period. When any vehicle is left parked for a
continuous period in violation of any limited parking time. If the owner can be
located, the owner shall be given an opportunity to remove the vehicle.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.236[1])
2.   Costs. In addition to the standard penalties provided, the owner or driver
of any vehicle impounded for the violation of any of the provisions of this
chapter shall be required to pay the reasonable cost of towing and storage.
CHAPTER 75
ATVS AND UTVS
 
75.01 Purpose                   75.07 Equipment
75.02 Definitions               75.08 UTV Hours of Operation
75.03 General Regulations       75.09 UTV Speed Limits
75.04 Operation of ATVs         75.10 Traffic Code
75.05 Operation of UTVs         75.11 Negligence
75.06  UTV Prohibited Locations 75.12 Accident Reports
 
75.01   PURPOSE.
The purpose of this chapter is to regulate the operation of all-terrain
vehicles and off-road utility vehicles within the City.
75.02   DEFINITIONS.
For use in this chapter the following terms are defined:
1.   “All-terrain vehicle” or “ATV” means a motorized vehicle, with not less
than three and not more than six non-highway tires, that is limited in engine
displacement to less than 1,000 cubic centimeters and in total dry weight to
less than 1,200 pounds and that has a seat or saddle designed to be straddled
by the operator and handlebars for steering control.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321I.1)
2.   “Off-road motorcycle” by the operator and handlebars for steering control
and that is intended by the manufacturer for use on natural terrain. “Off-road
motorcycle” includes a motorcycle that was originally issued a certificate of
title and registered for highway use under Chapter 321 of the Code of Iowa, but
which contains design features that enable operation over natural terrain. An
operator of an off-road motorcycle is also subject to the provisions of this
chapter governing the operation of ATVs and UTVs.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321I.1)
3.   “Off-road utility vehicle” or “UTV” means a motorized vehicle, with not
less than four and not more than eight non-highway tires or rubberized tracks,
that has a seat that is of bucket or bench design, not intended to be straddled
by the operator, and a steering wheel or control levers for control. “Off-road
utility vehicle” or “UTV” includes the following vehicles:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321I.1)
   A.   “Off-road utility vehicle – Type 1” includes vehicles with a total dry
weight of 1,200 pounds or less and a width of 50 inches or less.
   B.   “Off-road utility vehicle – Type 2” includes vehicles, other than Type
1 vehicles, with a total dry weight of 2,000 pounds or less and a width of 65
inches or less.
   C.   “Off-road utility vehicle – Type 3” includes vehicles with a total dry
weight of more than 2,000 pounds or a width of more than 65 inches, or both.
4.   “Snowmobile” means a motorized vehicle that weighs less than 1,000 pounds,
that uses sled-type runners or skis, endless belt-type tread with a width of 48
inches or less, or any combination of runners, skis, or tread, and is designed
for travel on snow or ice. “Snowmobile” does not include an all-terrain vehicle
that has been altered or equipped with runners, skis, belt-type tracks, or
treads. Snowmobile use is prohibited within the City limits except on
designated trails or private property.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321G.1)
75.03   GENERAL REGULATIONS.
ATVs, off-road motorcycles, or UTVs within the City must be operated in
compliance with Chapter 321I of the Code of Iowa, rules established by the
Natural Resource Commission of the Department of Natural Resources governing
their registration, equipment, and manner of operation, and this ordinance.
(Code of Iowa, Ch. 321G and Ch. 321I)
75.04   OPERATION OF ATVS.
1.   ATVs Not Permitted. ATVs are not permitted on any City street, alley,
park, or public property with the following exceptions and exceptions listed
per Chapter 321I.10 of the Code of Iowa.
2.   Exceptions. A person shall not operate an ATV upon roadways or highways
except as provided below:
   A.   A registered ATV may be operated on the roadways or alleys of City for
purpose of snow removal within 24 hours of the cessation of the snow fall.
   B.   The operation is between sunrise and sunset and is incidental to the
vehicle’s use for agricultural purposes. For purposes of this paragraph,
“incidental to the vehicle’s use for agricultural purposes” includes stopping
in the course of agricultural use to obtain fuel for the ATV or to obtain food
or a nonalcoholic beverage for the operator.
   C.   The operation is incidental to the vehicle’s use for the purpose of
surveying by a licensed engineer or land surveyor.
   D.   The ATV is operated by an employee or agent of a political subdivision
or public utility for the purpose of construction or maintenance on or adjacent
to the highway.
   E.   The ATV is operated by an employee or agent of a public agency as
defined in Section 34.1 of the Code of Iowa for the purpose of providing
emergency services or rescue.
   F.   The ATV is operated for the purpose of mowing, installing approved
trail signs, or providing maintenance on a snowmobile or ATV trail designated
by the Department of Natural Resources.
   G.   A person operating an ATV on a City street shall have a valid driver’s
license and the vehicle shall be operated at speeds of 35 miles per hour or
less.
   H.   ATVs shall not be operated on snowmobile trails.
3.   Direct Crossing. An ATV may make a direct crossing of a highway that is
not part of the interstate road system provided all of the following occur:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321I.10(5))
   A.   The crossing is made at an angle of approximately 90 degrees to the
direction of the highway and at a place where no obstruction prevents a quick
and safe crossing.
   B.   The ATV is brought to a complete stop before crossing the shoulder or
main traveled way of the highway.
   C.   The driver yields the right-of-way to all oncoming traffic which
constitutes an immediate hazard.
   D.   In crossing a divided highway, the crossing is made only at an
intersection of such highway with another public street or alley.
   E.   The crossing is made from a street, roadway, or highway on which the
ATV is authorized to operate to a street, roadway, or highway on which such
vehicle is authorized to operate.
75.05   OPERATION OF UTVS.  
UTVs may be operated upon the streets of the City by persons who are 18 years
of age or older and are possessing a valid State operator’s license, except as
prohibited in Section 75.06. While operated on a City street, the number of
passengers permitted on a UTV shall not exceed the number of seats intended for
passengers. While on City streets, operators must have on their person or in
the UTV proof of the required insurance.
75.06   UTV PROHIBITED LOCATIONS.
1.   Trails. UTVs shall not be operated on snowmobile trails except where
designated. UTVs shall not be operated on any recreational, bike, or walking
trail.
2.   Railroad Right-of-Way. UTVs shall not be operated on an operating railroad
right-of-way. A UTV may be driven directly across a railroad right-of-way only
at an established crossing and notwithstanding any other provision of law may,
if necessary, use the improved portion of the established crossing after
yielding to all oncoming traffic.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321I.14(1h))
3.   Parks and Other City Land. UTVs shall not be operated in any park,
playground, or upon any other City-owned property without the express
permission of the City.
4.   Sidewalk or Parking. UTVs shall not be operated upon the public sidewalk
or that portion of the street located between the curb line and the sidewalk or
property line commonly referred to as the “parking.”
5.   Direct Crossing. A UTV may make a direct crossing of a highway that is not
part of the interstate road system provided all of the following occur:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321I.10(5))
   A.   The crossing is made at an angle of approximately 90 degrees to the
direction of the highway and at a place where no obstruction prevents a quick
and safe crossing.
   B.   The UTV is brought to a complete stop before crossing the shoulder or
main traveled way of the highway.
   C.   The driver yields the right-of-way to all oncoming traffic which
constitutes an immediate hazard.
   D.   In crossing a divided highway, the crossing is made only at an
intersection of such highway with another public street or highway.
   E.   The crossing is made from a street, roadway, or highway on which the
UTV is authorized to operate to a street, roadway, or highway on which such
vehicle is authorized to operate.
6.   U.S. Highway 67. UTV’s shall not be operated on U.S. Highway 67 – “Cody
Road,” a primary road extension within the City. However, a UTV shall be
allowed to cross U.S. Highway 67 – “Cody Road” at a right-angle only.
7.   Special Exemptions. The Chief of Police is authorized to permit UTVs to
operate on restricted City areas for certain special events.
75.07   EQUIPMENT.
UTVs operated upon City streets shall be equipped with at least the following:
   1.   UTVs operated on City streets shall be equipped with a muffler,
headlights, taillights, turn signals, seatbelts, or safety restraints and
adequate brakes to stop and hold the UTV in a stopped position. Driver and all
passengers must comply with all seatbelt and occupant restraint requirements,
including the use of child safety seats, as required for motor vehicles
operating on a public roadway. Driver and all passengers shall each wear a
properly adjusted safety belt or safety harness any time the UTV is in motion
on a City street or alley.
   2.   UTVs operated on City streets shall be equipped with an adequate
exhaust systems.
75.08   UTV HOURS OF OPERATION
UTVs may be operated on City streets from 7:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. UTVs may be
operated during prohibited hours when being used for snow removal.
75.09   UTV SPEED LIMITS.
No UTV shall be operated at a speed in excess of 35 MPH or the posted speed
limit, whichever is lower. No UTV shall be operated at a speed greater than is
reasonable and proper for the existing conditions.
75.10   TRAFFIC CODE.
Any person operating a UTV shall strictly adhere to all traffic signs and
signals and all other traffic rules and regulations, and shall obey the orders
and direction of any law enforcement officer authorized to direct or regulate
traffic. No person shall leave an UTV unattended on public property while the
motor is running or the keys are in the ignition switch.
75.11   NEGLIGENCE.
The owner and operator of an ATV or UTV are liable for any injury or damage
occasioned by the negligent operation of the ATV or UTV. The owner of an ATV or
UTV shall be liable for any such injury or damage only if the owner was the
operator of the ATV or UTV at the time the injury or damage occurred or if the
operator had the owner’s consent to operate the ATV or UTV at the time the
injury or damage occurred.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321I.19)
75.12   ACCIDENT REPORTS.
Whenever an ATV or UTV is involved in an accident resulting in injury or death
to anyone or property damage amounting to $1,500.00 or more, either the
operator or someone acting for the operator shall immediately notify a law
enforcement officer and shall file an accident report, in accordance with State
law.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321I.11)
(Chapter 75 – Ord._844 – Jan. 25 Supp.)
CHAPTER 76
BICYCLES AND OTHER NON-MOTORIZED SELF-PROPELLED VEHICLES
 
76.01 Scope of Regulations 76.04 Equipment Requirements
76.02 Movement Regulations 76.05 Skateboards, Sleds, Roller Skates, Scooters,
                           etc.
76.03 Parking              76.06 Enforcement
 
76.01   SCOPE OF REGULATIONS.
These regulations, applicable to bicycles and other non-motorized, self-
propelled vehicles, except recognized emergency vehicles (see Sec. 321.231 of
the Code of Iowa, as amended) apply whenever such vehicle is operated upon any
public right-of-way, subject to those exceptions stated herein.
76.02   MOVEMENT REGULATIONS.
1.   Traffic Code Applies to Persons Riding Bicycles. Every person riding a
bicycle upon a roadway shall be granted all of the rights and will be subject
to all of the duties applicable to the driver of a vehicle by the laws of the
State declaring rules of the road applicable to the driver of a vehicle, except
as to those provisions which by their nature can have no application. Whenever
such person dismounts from a bicycle, they shall be subject to all regulations
applicable to pedestrians.
2.   Riding on Bicycles. A person propelling a bicycle shall not ride other
than astride a permanent and regular seat attached thereto. No bicycle shall be
used to carry more persons at one time than the number for which it is designed
and equipped.
3.   Riding Abreast. Persons riding bicycles upon a roadway shall not ride more
than two abreast except on paths or parts of roadways set aside for the
exclusive use of bicycles.
4.   Use of Bicycle Paths. Whenever a usable path for bicycles has been
provided adjacent to a roadway, bicycle riders shall use such path and shall
not use the roadway.
5.   Speed. No person shall operate a bicycle at a speed greater than is
reasonable and prudent under the conditions then existing.
6.   Emerging from Alley or Driveway. The operators of a bicycle emerging from
an alley, driveway, or building shall, upon approaching a sidewalk area
extending across any alleyway, yield the right-of-way to pedestrians
approaching on said sidewalk or sidewalk area, and upon entering the roadway
shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles approaching in said roadway.
7.   Carrying Articles. No person operating a bicycle shall carry any package,
bundle, or article which prevents the rider from keeping at least one hand upon
the handlebars.
8.   Riding on Sidewalks.
   A.   No person shall ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk in the Business
District, which is that area along Cody Road (U.S. 67) from May Street to
Walnut Street.
   B.   When signs are erected on any public right-of-way prohibiting the
riding of bicycles thereon, no person shall do so.
   C.   Whenever any person is riding a bicycle upon a sidewalk, such person
shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and shall give an audible signal
before overtaking and passing.
9.   Towing. It is unlawful for any person riding a bicycle to be towed or to
tow any other vehicle upon the streets of the City, except those commercially
available vehicles or apparatus so designed for that use.
10.   Following Fire Truck. No person riding a bicycle shall follow a fire
truck or other fire equipment at any time.
11.   Improper Riding. No person shall ride a bicycle in an irregular or
reckless manner such as zigzagging, stunting, speeding, or otherwise, so as to
disregard the safety of or the operations of others.
76.03   PARKING.
No person shall park a bicycle upon a street other than upon the roadway
against the curb, or upon the sidewalk in a rack to support the bicycle, or
against a building or at the curb, in such manner as to afford the least
obstruction to pedestrian traffic.
76.04   EQUIPMENT REQUIREMENTS.
1.   Lamps Required. Every bicycle, when in use at nighttime, shall be equipped
with a lamp on the front which shall emit a white light visible from a distance
of at least 300 feet to the front and with a lamp on the rear exhibiting a red
light visible from a distance of 300 feet to the rear, except that a red
reflector on the rear, of a type which shall be visible from all distances from
50 feet to 300 feet to the rear when directly in front of lawful upper beams of
headlamps on a motor vehicle, may be used in lieu of a rear light.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.397)
2.   Brakes Required. Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake which will
enable the operator to make the braked wheel skid on dry, level, or clean
pavement.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.236 [10])
76.05   SKATEBOARDS, SLEDS, ROLLER SKATES, SCOOTERS, ETC.
Skateboards, sleds, roller skates, scooters, tricycles, and similar self-
propelled and/or motorized vehicles shall not be used or operated on any U.S.
Highway right-of-way, any City street or upon any sidewalk or upon any other
public place where signs have been placed prohibiting such use. The operator of
such a self-propelled and/or motorized vehicle shall yield the right-of-way to
pedestrians at all times.
76.06   ENFORCEMENT.
Upon discovering a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, police
officers are encouraged to:
1.   Issue a verbal warning for the first offense;
2.   Confiscate the device and then return it only upon the personal request
and appearance at the Police Department of a parent or legal guardian of the
offender for the second offense; and
3.   Issue a citation for the third offense.
Any device confiscated under the provisions of this chapter, and not claimed
within six months from the date of confiscation, will automatically be
forfeited and become the property of the City. Upon discovering a violation of
any of the provisions of this chapter, any police officer may issue a citation
for a City violation into County traffic court.
CHAPTER 78
GOLF CARTS
 
78.01 Definitions 78.02 Golf Cart Operation Allowed
 
78.01   DEFINITIONS.
For purposes of this chapter, the following terms are defined:
1.   “Golf cart” means three- or four-wheeled recreational vehicle generally
used for transportation of person(s) in the sport of golf.
2.   “Operate” means to ride in or on, other than as a passenger, use or the
operation of a golf cart in any manner, whether or not the golf cart is moving.
3.   “Operator” means a person, who operates or is in actual physical control
of a golf cart.
4.   “Roadway” means that portion of a highway improved, designated, or
ordinarily used for vehicular travel.
5.   “Street” or “Highway” means the entire width between property lines of
every way or place of whatever nature when any part thereof is open to the use
of the public, as a matter of right, for the purpose of vehicular travel.
78.02   GOLF CART OPERATION ALLOWED.
1.   Pursuant to the authority granted under Section 321.247 of the Code of
Iowa, golf carts, only equipped as specified herein, may be operated on
specifically, designated public streets, as listed in Subsection 2, between
sunrise and sunset by any person at least 18 years of age possessing a valid
driver's license and proof of security against liability as specified in
Section 321.20.B. of the Code of Iowa. In addition, the number of passengers
permitted on a golf cart shall not exceed the number of seats intended for
passengers. Further, any golf cart operated on any public street pursuant to
this section shall be equipped with each of the following:
   A.   A clearly visible slow moving vehicle emblem displayed to the rear.
   B.   A bicycle safety flag of at least six feet in height.
   C.   Adequate brakes.
   D.   Fully operating headlights and taillights.
   E.   Child restraint devices as follows:
      (1)   A child under one year of age and weighing less than twenty pounds
shall be secured during transit in a rear-facing child restraint system that is
used in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions.
      (2)   A child under six years of age who does not meet the description in
Paragraph “(1)” and shall be secured during transit by a child restraint system
that is used in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions.
      (3)   A child at least six years of age but under eighteen years of age
shall be secured during transit by a child restraint system that is used in
accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions or a safety belt or safety
harness of a type approved under Iowa Code 321.445.
(Subsection 1 – Ord._845 – Jan. 25 Supp.)
2.   Public Streets Designated. Golf carts operated pursuant to the provisions
of this section may not be operated on the following, specifically, designated
public streets:
   A.   Truck routes as designated in
Chapter 66.
   B.   City streets with a speed limit greater than 30 mph.
   C.   South Eighth Street from Wisconsin Street to U.S. Highway 67 (Cody
Road).
   D.   U.S. Highway 67 (Cody Road), a primary road extension within the City.
However, a golf cart shall be allowed to cross U.S. Highway 67 (Cody Road) at a
right-angle only.
CHAPTER 80
ABANDONED VEHICLES
 
80.01 Definitions                       80.06 Fees for Impoundment
80.02 Authority to Take Possession of   80.07 Disposal of Abandoned Vehicles
Abandoned Vehicles
80.03 Notice by Mail                    80.08 Disposal of Totally Inoperable
                                        Vehicles
80.04 Extension of Time                 80.09 Proceeds from Sales
80.05 Reclamation of Abandoned Vehicles 80.10 Duties of Demolisher
 
80.01   DEFINITIONS.
For use in this chapter, the following terms are defined:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.89[1] and Sec. 321.90)
1.   “Abandoned vehicle” means any of the following:
   A.   A vehicle that has been left unattended on public property for more
than 24 hours and lacks current registration plates or two or more wheels or
other parts which renders the vehicle totally inoperable.
   B.   A vehicle that has remained illegally on public property for more than
24 hours. In order for any vehicle to be exempt from the provisions set forth
in this section, it is necessary for an additional one mile to appear on the
vehicle’s odometer every 24 hours.
   C.   A vehicle that has been unlawfully parked or placed on private property
without the consent of the owner or person in control of the property for more
than 24 hours.
   D.   A vehicle that has been legally impounded by order of a police
authority and has not been reclaimed for a period of 10 days. However, a police
authority may declare the vehicle abandoned within the 10-day period by
commencing the notification process.
   E.   Any vehicle parked on the highway determined by a police authority to
create a hazard to other vehicle traffic.
   F.   A vehicle that has been impounded pursuant to Section 321J.4B of the
Code of Iowa by order of the court and whose owner has not paid the impoundment
fees after notification by the person or agency responsible for carrying out
the impoundment order.
2.   “Demolisher” means a person licensed under Chapter 321H of the Code of
Iowa whose business it is to convert a vehicle to junk, processed scrap, or
scrap metal, or otherwise to wreck, or dismantle vehicles.
3.   “Garage keeper” means any operator of a parking place or establishment,
motor vehicle storage facility, or establishment for the servicing, repair, or
maintenance of motor vehicles.
4.   “Police authority” means the Iowa State Patrol or any law enforcement
agency of a county or city.
80.02   AUTHORITY TO TAKE POSSESSION OF ABANDONED VEHICLES.
A police authority, upon the authority’s own initiative or upon the request of
any other authority having the duties of control of highways or traffic, shall
take into custody an abandoned vehicle on public property and may take into
custody any abandoned vehicle on private property. The police authority may
employ its own personnel, equipment, and facilities or hire a private entity,
equipment, and facilities for the purpose of removing, preserving, storing, or
disposing of abandoned vehicles. A property owner or other person in control of
private property may employ a private entity that is a garage keeper to dispose
of an abandoned vehicle, and the private entity may take into custody the
abandoned vehicle without a police authority’s initiative. If a police
authority employs a private entity to dispose of abandoned vehicles, the police
authority shall provide the private entity with the names and addresses of the
registered owners, all lienholders of record, and any other known claimant to
the vehicle or the personal property found in the vehicle.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.89[2])
80.03   NOTICE BY MAIL.
1.   A police authority or private entity that takes into custody an abandoned
vehicle shall send notice by certified mail that the vehicle has been taken
into custody, no more than 20 days after taking custody of the vehicle. Notice
shall be sent to the last known address of record of the last known registered
owner of the vehicle, all lienholders of record, and any other known claimant
to the vehicle.
2.   Notice shall be deemed given when mailed. The notice shall include all of
the following:
   A.   A description of the year, make, model and vehicle identification
number of the vehicle.
   B.   The location of the facility where the vehicle is being held.
   C.   Information for the persons receiving the notice of their right to
reclaim the vehicle and personal property contained therein within 10 days
after the effective date of the notice. Persons may reclaim the vehicle or
personal property upon payment of all towing, preservation, and storage charges
resulting from placing the vehicle in custody and upon payment of the costs of
the notice required pursuant to this section.
   D.   A statement that failure of the owner, lienholders, or claimants to
exercise their right to reclaim the vehicle or personal property within the
time provided shall be deemed a waiver by the owner, lienholders, and claimants
of all right, title, claim, and interest in the vehicle or personal property.
   E.   A statement that failure to reclaim the vehicle or personal property is
deemed consent for the police authority or private entity to sell the vehicle
at a public auction or dispose of the vehicle to a demolisher and to dispose of
the personal property by sale or destruction.
3.   If the abandoned vehicle was taken into custody by a private entity
without a police authority’s initiative, the notice shall state that the
private entity may claim a garage keeper’s lien as described in Section 321.90,
Subsection 1, of the Code of Iowa, and may proceed to sell or dispose of the
vehicle.
4.   If the abandoned vehicle was taken into custody by a police authority or
by a private entity hired by a police authority, the notice shall state that
any person claiming rightful possession of the vehicle or personal property who
disputes the planned disposition of the vehicle or property by the police
authority or private entity, or of the assessment of fees and charges provided
by this section, may ask for an evidentiary hearing before the police authority
to contest those matters.
5.   If the persons receiving notice do not ask for a hearing or exercise their
right to reclaim the vehicle or personal property within the 10-day reclaiming
period, the owner, lienholders, or claimants shall no longer have any right,
title, claim, or interest in or to the vehicle or the personal property.
6.   A court in any case in law or equity shall not recognize any right, title,
claim, or interest of the owner, lienholders, or claimants after the expiration
of the 10-day reclaiming period.
7.   If it is impossible to determine with reasonable certainty the identities
and addresses of the last registered owner and all lienholders, notice by one
publication in one newspaper of general circulation in the area where the
vehicle was abandoned shall be sufficient to meet all requirements of notice
under Subsection 2 of this section. The published notice may contain multiple
listings of abandoned vehicles, but shall be published within the same time
requirements and contain the same information as prescribed for mailed notice
in Subsection 2 of this section.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.89[3])
80.04   EXTENSION OF TIME.
The owner, lienholders, or claimants may, by written request delivered to the
police authority or private entity prior to the expiration of the one day
reclaiming period, obtain an additional five days within which the motor
vehicle or personal property may be reclaimed.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.89[3c])
80.05   RECLAMATION OF ABANDONED VEHICLES.
Prior to driving an abandoned vehicle away from the premises, a person who
received (or who is reclaiming the vehicle on behalf of a person who received)
notice under Section
80.03 shall present to the police authority or private entity, as applicable,
the person’s valid driver’s license and proof of financial liability coverage
as provided in Section 321.20B of the Code of Iowa.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.89[3a])
80.06   FEES FOR IMPOUNDMENT.
The owner, lienholder, or claimant shall pay all towing and storage fees as
established by the storage facility, whereupon the vehicle shall be released.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.89[3a])
80.07   DISPOSAL OF ABANDONED VEHICLES.
If an abandoned vehicle has not been reclaimed as provided herein, the police
authority or private entity shall make a determination as to whether or not the
motor vehicle should be sold for use upon the highways, and shall dispose of
the motor vehicle in accordance with State law.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.89[4])
80.08   DISPOSAL OF TOTALLY INOPERABLE VEHICLES.
The City or any person upon whose property or in whose possession is found any
abandoned motor vehicle, or any person being the owner of a motor vehicle whose
title certificate is faulty, lost, or destroyed, may dispose of such motor
vehicle to a demolisher for junk, without a title and without notification
procedures, if such motor vehicle lacks an engine or two or more wheels or
other structural part which renders the vehicle totally inoperable. The police
authority shall give the applicant a certificate of authority. The applicant
shall then apply to the County Treasurer for a junking certificate and shall
surrender the certificate of authority in lieu of the certificate of title.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.90[2e])
80.09   PROCEEDS FROM SALES.
Proceeds from the sale of any abandoned vehicle shall be applied to the expense
of auction, cost of towing, preserving, storing, and notification required, in
accordance with State law. Any balance shall be held for the owner of the motor
vehicle or entitled lienholder for 90 days, and then shall be deposited in the
State Road Use Tax Fund. Where the sale of any vehicle fails to realize the
amount necessary to meet costs the police authority shall apply for
reimbursement from the Department of Transportation.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.89[4])
80.10   DUTIES OF DEMOLISHER.
Any demolisher who purchases or otherwise acquires an abandoned motor vehicle
for junk shall junk, scrap, wreck, dismantle, or otherwise demolish such motor
vehicle. A demolisher shall not junk, scrap, wreck, dismantle, or demolish a
vehicle until the demolisher has obtained the junking certificate issued for
the vehicle.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.90[3a])
CHAPTER 90
WATER SERVICE SYSTEM
 
90.01 Definitions 90.02 Water Well Construction Prohibition
 
90.01   DEFINITIONS.
In addition to the definitions contained in Section
95.01 of this Code of Ordinances and other definitions as used throughout this
Code and various other applicable City codes, and unless the context
specifically indicates otherwise, the meanings of terms used in this chapter
are as follows:
1.   “Building lateral” or “private water service pipe” means that pipe and all
associated appurtenances (including any corporation and/or saddle attached to
the public water main), extending from the public water main to the building
which it is intended to service.
2.   “Customer” means any person who utilizes, in any manner, water provided by
the public water system.
3.   “Property line” means the line or lines defining the lot upon which the
structure or proposed structure is located which is intended to be served by
the water system.
4.   “Public water main” means a water main supply pipe, owned, controlled,
maintained, and subject to the jurisdiction of the Iowa-American Water Company,
its successors, and assigns, which is provided for public or community use.
5.   “Readily and reasonably available” means that connection to the public
water main can be made without incurring any provable financial hardship or
other hardship as the City Council may determine.
6.   “Water emergency” means that period of time during which water is not
available, or its availability is limited, due to severe shortages in supplies,
interruptions in the water transmission or distribution systems, contamination
of water supplies, or other conditions where use restrictions or prohibitions
are necessary in order to safeguard the safety and health of the general public
and to provide water for essential public uses (e.g., fire protection).
7.   “Water system” or “water works” means all public facilities for securing,
collecting, storing, pumping, treating, and distributing potable water.
90.02   WATER WELL CONSTRUCTION PROHIBITION.
No person shall drill, construct, install, replace, or rehabilitate any water
well used for any purpose on any property located within the City where the
dwelling or other structure to be supplied with water is within 200 feet from a
readily and reasonably available public water main and access is not required
by easements or other encumbrances caused by passage through property owned by
another. The City reserves the right to make the final determination as to the
availability of a public water main. Exceptions to this limitation on future
well permits may be made for non-potable water wells for the purpose of
irrigation, livestock watering, industrial non-drinking uses and “closed-loop”
systems. Any exceptions will comply with the rules and guidelines of the Iowa
Department of Natural Resources in place at that time.
CHAPTER 93
WATER CONSERVATION
 
93.01 Water Conservation Emergency 93.04 Level III
93.02 Level I                      93.05 Level IV
93.03 Level II
 
93.01   WATER CONSERVATION EMERGENCY.
Whenever a water emergency, as defined in Subsection
90.01(6), is determined to exist based upon all the available data at hand, the
procedures, measures, and provisions given in this chapter shall be in effect
to produce an orderly and equitable reduction of water consumption until the
Council declares the water emergency to be ended. There shall be four levels of
water emergencies.
93.02   LEVEL I.
Under a Level I water emergency, all customers of the water system are
encouraged to limit or curtail all nonessential uses of water in order to
preserve the resources available. Customers are encouraged to comply with the
following voluntary standards:
1.   No watering of lawns, shrubs, or gardens between the hours of 8:00 a.m.
and 8:00 p.m. (If a hand-held hose or drip irrigation system is used, watering
may be done at any time.)
2.   No water should be used to fill private swimming pools, children’s wading
pools, reflecting pools, ornamental fountains, or any other outdoor pool or
pond, or any other such structure making similar use of water.
3.   No water should be used to wash streets, parking lots, driveways,
sidewalks, porches, or building exteriors.
4.   No water should be used for nonessential cleaning of commercial and
industrial equipment, machinery, and interior spaces.
5.   Water should be served at restaurants only upon the request of the
customer.
6.   Private car/truck washing should be done using a bucket. No hoses should
be used. (Vehicles may be washed at a commercial car wash where the water is
recycled.).
93.03   LEVEL II.
Under a Level II water emergency, no person shall use potable processed water
of the water system in any manner contrary to the following:
1.   Outdoor watering or irrigation of lawns is prohibited.
2.   Watering or irrigation of flower and vegetable gardens, trees, and shrubs
less than four years old; and new seedling or sod is permitted once per week
with an application not to exceed one inch or four hours, whichever is less,
and then only between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m.
3.   The washing of cars, trucks, trailers, and other vehicles or equipment is
prohibited except at commercial establishments which provide that service.
4.   No water shall be used to fill private swimming pools, children’s wading
pools, reflecting pools, ornamental fountains, or any other outdoor pool or
pond, or any other such structure making similar use of water.
5.   No water shall be used to wash streets, parking lots, driveways,
sidewalks, porches, or building exteriors.
6.   No water shall be used for nonessential cleaning of commercial and
industrial equipment, machinery, and interior spaces.
7.   Water shall be served at restaurants only upon the request of the
customer.
8.   Use of water-consuming comfort air conditioning equipment which consumes
in excess of five percent of the water circulating in such equipment is
prohibited.
9.   Tank load water sales may be curtailed or eliminated.
93.04   LEVEL III.
Under a Level III water emergency, no person shall use potable processed water
of the water system in any manner contrary to the following:
1.   All outside water use, except for domestic, sanitation, and fire
protection, is prohibited.
2.   All commercial and industrial uses of water not essential in providing
services is prohibited.
3.   Irrigation of agricultural crops is prohibited. (Watering of livestock is
permitted.)
4.   Recreational and leisure water use, including land and golf course
watering and other incidental or recreational use, is prohibited.
5.   Water use not essential for the preservation of life, or the general
welfare of the community is prohibited.
6.   The sale of water to customers outside of the City limits will be
discontinued.
93.05   LEVEL IV.
Under a Level IV water emergency, no person shall use potable processed water
of the water system in any manner contrary to the following:
1.   Any and all domestic, commercial, industrial, and agricultural (including
the watering of livestock) water use is strictly prohibited under any
circumstances.
2.   Water reclaimed or recycled after some other primary use, such as water
that has been used for washing or cooling, may be used without restrictions.
Additionally, water derived from sources other than the City water system, such
as water condensed from the atmosphere by air conditioners or collected from
rain or snow, may be used without restrictions.
3.   The Mayor may immediately proclaim any level of water emergency and such
proclamation and the provisions enumerated herein accompanying that
proclamation will remain in effect until such time as the Council can adopt a
resolution confirming such emergency.
4.   The resolution declaring a water emergency shall be published once in a
local newspaper serving the City and, upon publication, shall serve as notice
to and shall require compliance with this section by all persons using water
from the water system until such time as the Council, by resolution, declares
the emergency to be terminated.
5.   Any person found to be using City water in violation of this section may
be subject to any legal remedy specified in this Code.
CHAPTER 95
SANITARY SEWER SYSTEM
 
95.01 Definitions                       95.07 Interruption of Service
                                        (Liability Limited)
95.02 Duties and Responsibilities of    95.08 Indemnity
City and Officials
95.03 Standard Penalties, Enforcement,  95.09 Compliance with Other Applicable
Legal Remedies, and Discontinuation of  Codes
Service; Surcharges
95.04 Customer’s Contract with the Cit95.10 Adoption of Rules and Regulations
95.05 Right of Access, Inspection, and  95.11 Sewer Main Back-Up Damages and
Grant of Easements                      Claims Reimbursement
95.06 Right to Refuse Service
 
95.01   DEFINITIONS.
For use in these chapters, unless the context specifically indicates otherwise,
the following terms are defined:
1.   “ANSI” means standards of the American National Standard Institute, latest
edition.
2.   “ASTM” means standard of the American Society of Testing Materials, latest
edition.
3.   “Biohazard” means any infectious or potentially infectious materials
including, but not limited to the following: semen, vaginal secretions,
cerebrospinal fluid, synovial fluid, pleural fluid, pericardial fluid,
peritoneal fluid, amniotic fluid, saliva in dental procedures, any body fluid
visibly contaminated with blood, and all body fluids in situations where it is
difficult or impossible to differentiate between body fluids. Also included are
any unfixed tissue or organ other than intact skin from a human (living or
dead), and human immune-deficiency virus (HIV) - containing cell or tissue
cultures, organ cultures and HIV or Hepatitis B (HBV) -containing culture
medium or other solutions as well as blood, organs, or other tissues from
experimental animals infected with HIV or HBV.
4.   “B.O.D.” (denoting Biochemical Oxygen Demand) means the quantity of oxygen
utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard
laboratory procedure in five days at 20?, expressed in milligrams per liter or
parts per million.
5.   “Building drain” means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a
building drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste, and
other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the
building sewer, beginning five feet (one and one-half meters) outside the inner
face of the building wall.
6.   “Building lateral” means the sewer piping from the building sewer,
beginning five feet outside the inner face of the building wall and extending
to the public sanitary sewer.
7.   “Building sewer” means that part of the horizontal piping from the
building wall to its connection with the main sewer or the primary treatment
portion of an on-site wastewater treatment and disposal system conveying the
drainage of one building site.
8.   “Combined sewer” means a sewer receiving both surface run-off and sewage.
9.   “Customer” means any person responsible for the production of discharged
domestic, commercial or industrial wastes, directly or indirectly, into the
public sewer system.
10.   “Domestic wastewater” means any sewage produced and originating from
residential dwelling units with a (BOD) of not more than 250 milligrams per
liter and suspended solids of not more than 300 milligrams per liter.
11.   “Eligible senior citizen” means any residential user of the public sewer
system over the age of 65 whose income level, as verified annually through the
use of the various income verification statements (i.e., federal income tax
return, bank statements, W-2’s, social security statements, etc.) as determined
and approved by the City Administrator, is less than 150 percent of the Federal
Office of Management and Budget (OMB) designated poverty level (which includes
social security benefits).
12.   “Garbage” means solid wastes from the domestic and commercial
preparation, cooking and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage,
and sale of produce.
13.   “Health department” means the County Health Department.
14.   “IDNR” means the Iowa Department of Natural Resources.
15.   “Industrial wastewater or process wastewater” means any wastewater
permitted to flow or escape from any industrial, manufacturing, commercial, or
business establishment or process, or from the development, recovery, or
processing of any natural resource as distinct from domestic wastewater.
16.   “Industrial wastes” means the liquid wastes from industrial manufacturing
processes, trade, or business as distinct from sanitary sewage.
17.   “Inspector” means the person duly authorized by the Council to inspect
and approve the installation of building sewers and their connections to the
public sewer system; and to inspect such sewage as may be discharged therefrom.
18.   “Natural outlet” means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake,
or other body of surface or groundwater.
19.   “On-site wastewater treatment and disposal system” means all equipment
and devices necessary for proper conduction, collection, storage, treatment,
and disposal of wastewater from four or fewer dwelling units or other
facilities serving the equivalent of 15 persons (1,500 gpd) or less.
20.   “Person” means any and all persons, natural or artificial, including any
individual, firm, company, municipal, or private corporation, association,
society, institution, enterprise, political subdivision, governmental agency,
trust, estate, or other legal entity, or their legal representatives, agents,
successors, heirs, or assigns.
21.   “pH” means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen ions
in grams per liter of solution.
22.   “Property line” means the line or lines defining the lot upon which the
structure or proposed structure is located which is intended to be served by
the public sewer.
23.   “Property owner” means the contract purchaser of real estate, if there is
one of record, otherwise the record holder of legal title to real estate as
shown on the records of the County Assessor’s Office.
24.   “Properly shredded garbage” means the wastes from the preparation,
cooking, and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that
all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally
prevailing in the public sewer, with no particle greater than one-half inch in
any dimension.
25.   “Public sewer main” means a sewer main owned, controlled, maintained, and
subject to the jurisdiction of the City Municipal Utilities Department, its
successors, and assigns, which is provided for public or community use.
26.   “Readily and reasonably available” means that connection to the public
sewer main can be made without incurring any provable financial hardship or
other hardship as the Council may determine.
27.   “Sanitary sewage” means sewage discharging from the sanitary conveniences
of dwellings (including apartment houses and hotels), office buildings,
factories, or institutions, and free from storm, surface water, and industrial
waste.
28.   “Sanitary sewer” means a sewer that carries sewage and to which storm,
surface, and ground waters are not intentionally admitted.
29.   “Sewage treatment plant” means any arrangement of devices and structures
used for treating sewage.
30.   “Sewage works” or “sewage system” means all facilities for collecting,
pumping, treating, and disposing of sewage.
31.   “Sewer” means a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage.
32.   “Sewer service charges” means any and all charges, rates or fees levied
against and payable by customers, as consideration for the servicing of said
customers by said sewer system.
33.   “Slug” means any discharge of water, sewage, or industrial waste that in
concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any
period of duration longer than 15 minutes more than five times the average 24-
hour concentration or flows during normal operation.
34.   “Standard sampling manhole” means a structure located on-site from which
industrial wastewater is discharged. The purpose of a “standard sampling
manhole” is to provide access to the sewer for the City to sample or measure
discharges.
35.   “Storm drain” or “storm sewer” means a sewer that carries storm and
surface waters and drainage but excludes sewage and industrial wastes, other
than unpolluted cooling water.
36.   “Superintendent” means the Superintendent of sewage works and/or of water
pollution control of the City or any authorized deputy, agent, or
representative.
37.   “Suspended solids” means solids that either float on the surface of, or
are in suspension in water, sewage, or other liquids, and that are removable by
laboratory filtering.
38.   “Unpolluted water” means water of quality equal to or better than the
effluent criteria in effect, or water that would not cause violation of
receiving water quality standards and would not be benefited by discharge to
the sanitary sewers and wastewater treatment facilities provided.
39.   “User unit” means each single-family, multi-family, or mobile home
dwelling unit; each commercial building unit; each governmental building unit;
or each industrial building unit.
40.   “Watercourse” means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either
continuously or intermittently.
95.02   DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF CITY AND OFFICIALS.
1.   The City Administrator is responsible for the appropriate and timely
administration of the provisions of this chapter. The City shall supervise the
installation of building laterals and their connection to the public sewer main
and enforce all regulations pertaining to sewer services in this City in
accordance with this chapter. This chapter applies to all replacements of
existing building lateral pipes as well as to the installation of new ones. The
City Administrator shall make such rules, not in conflict with the intent and
provisions of this chapter, as may be needed for the detailed, day-to-day
operations of the sewer system. In the event of an emergency, they may make
temporary rules, which may conflict and not conform with the intent of this
chapter, for the protection of the system until a final decision can be
rendered by the Council.
2.   Authorized employees of the City bearing proper credentials and
identification shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of
inspection, installation of metering devices, observation, measurement,
sampling, and testing in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
3.   While performing the necessary work on private property, authorized
employees of the City shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises
established by the company/owner and the company/owner shall be held harmless
for injury or death to the City employees and the City shall indemnify the
company/owner against loss or damage to its property by City employees and
against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damage
asserted against the company/owner, except as such may be caused by negligence
or failure of the company/owner to maintain safe conditions as required.
4.   The authorized employees of the City, bearing proper credentials and
identification, shall be permitted to enter all private properties through
which the City holds a duly negotiated easement for the purposes of, but not
limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair, and
maintenance of any portion of the sewage works lying within said easement. All
entry and subsequent work, if any, on said easement shall be done in full
accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated easement pertaining to the
private property involved.
95.03   STANDARD PENALTIES, ENFORCEMENT, LEGAL REMEDIES, AND DISCONTINUATION OF
SERVICE; SURCHARGES.
In addition to those legal remedies and enforcement procedures enumerated in
Chapter 3 of this Code of Ordinances and others listed in this chapter, the
City may institute any remedy allowed by law including the following to
administer the provisions of this chapter. The City Administrator may impose a
monthly “surcharge” in an amount approved by Council resolution under the
following conditions:
1.   Without notice, in the event that evidence is found indicating tampering
with the equipment furnished and owned by the City.
2.   Without notice, in the event that evidence is found indicating
unauthorized use of the system.
3.   For failure of a customer to permit the City reasonable access, after due
notice is given, to change out or to check for metering system accuracy.
4.   For failure of a customer to adequately safeguard, locate or relocate a
meter after due notice is given.
5.   For failure of a customer to repair any faulty building lateral or service
piping within a building after due notice is given.
6.   Without notice, in the event of a condition determined by the City to be
hazardous.
95.04   CUSTOMER’S CONTRACT WITH THE CITY.
The rules, regulations, and sewer rates hereinafter referred to shall be
considered a part of the contract with every person supplied service through
the sewer system and every such person, by utilizing such service, shall be
considered as expressing consent to be bound by this contract whether having
signed an application or contract for said service or not.
95.05   RIGHT OF ACCESS, INSPECTION, AND GRANT OF EASEMENTS.
Each person supplied with sewer service through the City sewer system shall
permit and grant to the City, after due notice and presentation of proper
identification (if requested), reasonable access to the property and buildings
served by the City sewer system for the purposes of inspecting, maintaining,
and/or repairing or disconnecting any and all metering equipment and devices or
any other piping or fixtures connected in any matter to the sewer system or for
the purpose of inspecting for compliance with the provisions of this chapter.
Further, there is hereby established a permanent easement across and through
those properties served by the City sewer system for the use of the City to
read and/or maintain all metering devices.
95.06   RIGHT TO REFUSE SERVICE.
The City may refuse service to persons, not presently customers, when, in the
opinion of the City, the capacity of the sewer system will not permit such
service.
95.07   INTERRUPTION OF SERVICE (LIABILITY LIMITED).
The City does not guarantee a constant supply of sewer service to any customer
and shall not be liable for damages for any failure to supply the same, nor
shall it be liable for any claims or damage by reason of the breaking or
blockage of any building lateral, building drain, or other equipment not
specifically attributable to proven City negligence in the maintenance and
performance of the public sewer system.
95.08   INDEMNITY.
If any loss or damage is caused to the property of the City or any accident or
injury to persons or property is caused by or results from the negligence or
wrongful act of the customer, member of the customer’s household, or any agent
or employee of the customer, the cost of the necessary repairs or replacements
shall be paid by the customer to the City and any liability otherwise resulting
shall be that of the customer.
95.09   COMPLIANCE WITH OTHER APPLICABLE CODES.
In addition to the specifically highlighted and mentioned provisions in the
Sanitary Sewer chapters, the construction and installation of any building
lateral and any such connection with the public sewer system shall comply with
all pertinent and applicable provisions, whether regulatory, procedural, or
enforcement provisions, of any code or regulations currently in use by the
City.
95.10   ADOPTION OF RULES AND REGULATIONS.  
Amendments to this and all subsequent chapters dealing with the public sewer
system shall be adopted by ordinance of the Council only after first having
duly held a public hearing to consider said amendments.
95.11   SEWER MAIN BACK-UP DAMAGES AND CLAIMS REIMBURSEMENT.  
No reimbursements will be granted for any damages allegedly caused by any sewer
main jetting activities. Reimbursements may be granted for damages allegedly
caused by sewer main back-ups (except those caused by “flood waters”), provided
each of the following conditions are met:
1.   The City’s backed-up sewer main must be the sole, indisputable cause of
the alleged back-up damages.
2.   The City must be notified of the alleged damages within one hour of the
back-up or the discovery thereof.
3.   The City must have on-site, visual confirmation within the structure and
the City’s sewer main of the back-up and resulting, alleged damages within one
hour of notification of an alleged back-up or the discovery thereof.
4.   The City will pay all reasonable costs up to a maximum, not-to-exceed
$1,500.00 incurred in the mitigation of clean-up of, repair of, and/or
replacement of property, allegedly damaged, based upon detailed supporting
invoices. The City will retain the right to repair property to a satisfactory
condition as opposed to replacement.
5.   All property damaged and selected to be replaced by the City will become
the property of the City immediately upon reimbursement.
6.   All reimbursement offers will be final and any offer accepted will be
considered as payment in full for any and all damages incurred, and the
property owner/tenant will agree that no further actions and/or compensation of
any kind will be sought regarding the claim in question.
CHAPTER 96
BUILDING SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS
96.01 Mandatory Connection Required   96.10 Connection Requirements
96.02 Building Lateral Installation   96.11 Completion by the City

96.03 Building Lateral Installation/  96.12 Depth Requirement
