96.01   MANDATORY CONNECTION REQUIRED.  
The owner of all houses, buildings, or properties used for human habitation,
employment, recreation, or other purposes, situated within the City and
abutting on any street, alley, or right-of-way in which there is now located,
or may in the future, be located a public sanitary or combined sewer of the
City, is hereby required, at said owner’s expense, to install suitable sewage
facilities therein, and to connect such facilities directly with the proper
public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, within 60 days
from the date of receipt of the official written notice to do so, provided that
said public sewer is within 200 feet of the property line, is readily and
reasonably available, and does not require the need to obtain easements or
other encumbrances caused by the passage through property owned by another, or
require an addition to the existing main, if the City deems that such addition
is necessary for said connection.
96.02   BUILDING LATERAL INSTALLATION PERMIT REQUIRED.
No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening
into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without
first obtaining a written permit from the City. Before or in conjunction with
the issuance of a building permit for any first-time, new construction where
sewer service will be provided by the City and before any person makes a
connection or reconnection with the public sewer system, a written permit must
be obtained from the City. The application shall be filed with the City on
blanks furnished by the City. The application shall include any and all
information deemed necessary by the City to adequately describe the work being
done, protect the property owner’s and the City’s interests in the work being
performed, and to serve as a permanent utility record of the pertinent
information involved with the building lateral. The permit application shall be
supplemented by any plans, specifications, or other information deemed
necessary to affect the intent of the foregoing statement. The City shall issue
the permit if the proposed work meets all the requirements of this chapter and
if all fees required under this chapter have been paid. The City may at any
time revoke the permit for any violation of this chapter and require that the
work be stopped.
96.03   BUILDING LATERAL INSTALLATION/CONNECTION PERMIT AND INSPECTION FEES.
There are two classes of sewer installation/connection permits and fees: (a)
for residential installation/connections; (b) for commercial or industrial
installation/connections. The property owner or agent shall make an application
on a special form furnished by the City. The permit application shall be
supplemented by any plans, specifications, or other information considered
pertinent in the judgment of the City. At such time as an application for a
building lateral installation/ connection permit is filed with the City, a
permit and inspection fee shall be paid to the City in the following amounts:
1.   For each new residential connection, a permit request shall be accompanied
by a fee as established by resolution of the Council, except as specifically
noted otherwise herein.
2.   For each existing residential reconnection† 4 , a permit request shall be
accompanied by a fee as established by resolution of the Council, except as
specifically noted otherwise herein.
3.   For each new commercial or industrial connection, a permit request shall
be accompanied by a fee as established by resolution of the Council, except as
specifically noted otherwise herein.
4.   For each existing commercial or industrial reconnection† 5 , a permit
request shall be accompanied by a fee as established by resolution of the
Council, except as specifically noted otherwise herein.
The Council may, under special conditions or circumstances, negotiate and
require other, higher connection fees than those established by resolution of
the Council, but shall not, under any circumstance, require a fee less than
those established by resolution of the Council.
 
Notes
  † EDITOR’S NOTE: For purposes of this chapter, the term “reconnection” means any
4 replacement, reattachment, relocation, excavation of or the repair of any building
  lateral or any portion thereof, except for the repair of an inoperable or buried curb
  stop.
  † EDITOR’S NOTE: For purposes of this chapter, the term “reconnection” means any
5 replacement, reattachment, relocation, excavation of or the repair of any building
  lateral or any portion thereof, except for the repair of an inoperable or buried curb
  stop.
96.04   CONNECTION DEADLINE.
All approved connection and reconnection permits shall require the owner to
complete construction and connection of the building lateral to the public
sewer main within 30 days from the issuance of the permit, and under any
circumstances no later than 60 days after receipt of the official notice to
connect, except that when, in the judgment of the Inspector, the applicant has
made sufficient showing that due to conditions beyond the applicant’s control
or peculiar hardship the period of time set forth for the completion of the
connection shall be inequitable or unfair to the applicant, an extension of
time within which to comply with the provisions herewith may be granted.
96.05   INSPECTION REQUIRED.
All new, first-time connections with the public sewer system before being
covered, shall be inspected and approved, in writing, by the City. As soon as
all pipe work from the public sewer system to inside the building has been
completed and before any backfilling is done, the City shall be notified and
shall cause to be inspected the work as to workmanship and material. No sewer
service pipe laid underground shall be covered or trenches filled until after
the lateral has been so inspected and approved. If the City refuses to approve
the work, the contractor or owner must proceed immediately to correct the work.
96.06   ABANDONED CONNECTIONS.
When any portion of a building lateral is permanently abandoned, the lateral
shall be disconnected at the public sewer main, and the connection shall be
made absolutely watertight to the satisfaction of the City.
96.07   CONTRACTOR QUALIFICATIONS AND APPROVAL.
Any connection to a public sewer main shall be made only by a person, approved
by the City, who, by education, license, or training, is so qualified to do so.
The City Administrator shall have the right to suspend the approval of the
person making the connection for any violation of any provision of this
chapter. A suspension, unless revoked, shall continue until the next regular
Council meeting. The City Administrator shall notify the person immediately by
certified mail of the suspension, the reasons for the suspension, and the time
and place of the Council meeting at which he or she will be granted a hearing.
At this Council meeting the City Administrator shall present a written report
to the Council. After said hearing time, the Council may revoke the suspension
or take any further action that is necessary and proper.
96.08   BOND AND AGREEMENT REQUIRED.
Prior to the installation and construction of a building lateral within the
public right-of-way and/or any connection of a building lateral to a public
sewer main, the person doing the work shall submit to the City an executed Hold
Harmless and Waiver of Liability Statement on a form supplied by the City and a
License and Permit Bond in an amount not less than $10,000.00. Said bond shall
be obtained from and secured by a responsible surety bonding company authorized
to operate within the State, conditioned to indemnify and save the City
harmless against all losses or damages that may arise from or be occasioned by
the making of connections with the public sewer main, or excavations therefore,
or by carelessness, negligence, or unskillfulness in making the same.
96.09   TAPPING MAINS.
All taps into public sewer mains shall be made by an approved contractor and in
accordance with the following:
1.   Connection of the building lateral into the public sewer main shall be
made at an existing wye branch, if such branch is available at a suitable
location. If no existing, properly located wye branch is available, the
property owner shall, at the owner’s expense, install a wye branch in the
public sewer main at the location specified by the City or use an approved
banded, saddle w/hub attached to the main. No building laterals will be
installed directly into any hole cut into the public sewer main. The invert of
the building lateral at the point of connection shall be at the same or a
higher elevation than the invert of the public sewer. A smooth, neat joint
shall be made, and the connection shall be made secure and watertight by
encasement in concrete or by some other method approved by the Inspector.
Special fittings may be used for the connection only when approved by the City.
At no time shall a building lateral be constructed so as to enter a manhole
unless special written permission is received from the City and then only in
accordance with any special conditions as may be required by the City.
2.   A separate and independent building lateral shall be provided for every
building, except where one building stands at the rear of another on an
interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the
rear building through an adjoining alley, courtyard, or driveway. The building
lateral from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the
whole considered as one building lateral, provided, however, that the minimum
size shall then be not less than six inches for the building sewer lateral. Any
multi-family or multi-use structure may utilize one building lateral sized
accordingly, but in no case shall it be less than six inches in diameter.
3.   An accurate and dimensional sketch showing the exact location of the tap
and lateral routing shall be filed with the City and attached to or recorded on
the permanent application form.
96.10   CONNECTION REQUIREMENTS.
The installation of the building sewer and its connection to the public sewer
shall conform to the requirements of the Uniform Plumbing Code, the current
edition of SUDAS as adopted by the City in
Chapter 163, the laws of the State, and other applicable rules and regulations
of the City. Old building laterals may be used in connection with new building
construction only when they are found, on examination and test by the City, to
meet all requirements of this chapter.
96.11   COMPLETION BY THE CITY.
Should any excavation be left open or only partially refilled for more than 24
hours after the building lateral is installed and connected with the sewer
system, or should the work be improperly done and not approved, the City shall
have the right to finish or correct the work, and the City may assess the costs
to the property owner. If the contractor is responsible for the uncompleted or
improperly completed work, said contractor must reimburse the City any and all
associated costs incurred in remedying the situation before the contractor will
be granted another installation/construction permit. If the property owner is
assessed, such assessment shall be collected with and in the same manner as
general property taxes. Any such condition is hereby deemed to be a nuisance
and as such may be abated per the process as defined in
Chapter 50 of this Code of Ordinances.
96.12   DEPTH REQUIREMENT.
Whenever possible, the building lateral shall be brought to the building at an
elevation below the basement floor. The depth of cover above the sewer shall be
sufficient to afford protection from frost, and in all cases shall be a minimum
of 12 inches below the finished grade. In all buildings in which any building
drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer main, sanitary
sewer carried by such building drain may be lifted by an approved means and
discharged to the building lateral. (See Section
96.16.)
96.13   STORMWATER.
No person shall make a connection of roof downspouts, interior and exterior
foundation drains, areaway drains, garage floor drains, or other sources of
surface run-off or groundwater to a building lateral or building drain which in
turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer.
96.14   OWNER’S RESPONSIBILITY.
All costs and expense incident to the installation and connection of the
building lateral and associated appurtenances to the public sewer main shall be
borne by the property owner. The property owner shall indemnify the City from
any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the
installation of the building lateral. It shall be the responsibility of the
property owner of the property connected to the public sewer system to keep in
good repair, operable, and free of any leaks the building lateral and
associated appurtenances whether located upon private property or in the public
right-of-way. When any building lateral and/or associated appurtenances become
defective and create a nuisance in violation of this code, the nuisance shall
be corrected at the property owner’s expense within 30 days after the date of
receipt of official notice from the City of such violation. If not made within
such time, the City shall, in addition to the other penalties herein provided,
have the right to finish and correct the work and assess the cost thereof to
the property owner. Such assessment shall be collected with and in the same
manner as general property taxes.
96.15   LIMITED RESPONSIBILITY FOR PERMIT REVOCATION.
All permits to connect with the public sewer shall be issued with the express
condition that the City may, at any time before the work is completed, revoke
and annul the same and no interested party shall have a right to claim damages
as a consequence of any such permit being revoked or annulled.
96.16   USE OF SEWAGE LIFT/SUMP PUMPS PROHIBITED.
No new construction shall be built below the usable level of the public
sanitary sewer system so as to require the installation and use of a sewage
lift/sump pump, without the express written consent of the Council.
96.17   PRIVATE CONSTRUCTION OF PUBLIC SEWER MAINS PROHIBITED.
The City will construct or contract for the construction of all public sewer
mains within an established public right-of-way except as pertains to approved
subdivision development. No private party shall otherwise construct any type of
sewer within these public right-of-ways. This does not include the approved
installation of any building lateral being attached to an already existing
public sewer main. The cost of all public sewer main construction will be borne
by the City except during the course of an approved subdivision development or
except when a property owner desires an extension of the existing public sewer
main in advance of the City’s projected construction date. The property owner
can request that the City proceed with this construction as soon as is
practical, with the cost to be borne by the property owner making the request.
The cost of all building laterals connecting to the public sewer main shall be
borne by the property owner.
CHAPTER 97
USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS
 
97.01 Stormwater                         97.06 Special Facilities
97.02 Prohibited Activities              97.07 Control Manholes
97.03 Specifically Prohibited Discharges 97.08 Testing of Wastes
97.04 Powers of City                     97.09 Special Agreements
97.05 Waste Interceptors Required        97.10 Interference with Equipment
                                         Prohibited
 
97.01   STORMWATER.
No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any storm water, surface
water, groundwater, pool water, roof run-off, subsurface drainage including
interior and exterior foundation drains, uncontaminated cooling water, or
unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. Storm water and all
other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are
specifically designated as combined sewer or storm sewers, or to a natural
outlet approved by the Inspector. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted
process waters may be discharged upon the approval of the Inspector to a storm
sewer, combined sewer, or natural outlet.
97.02   PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES.
It is unlawful for any person to place, deposit, or permit to be deposited in
any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the City, or in any
area under the jurisdiction of said City, any human or animal excrement,
garbage, or other objectionable waste.
It is unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the City, or in any
area under the jurisdiction of said City, any sewage or other polluted waters,
except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent
provisions of this chapter.
Except as hereinafter provided, it is unlawful to construct or maintain any
privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other facility intended or used
for the disposal of sewage.
97.03   SPECIFICALLY PROHIBITED DISCHARGES.
No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged the following described
substances, materials, waters, or wastes if it appears likely in the opinion of
the City that such wastes can jam either the sewers, sewage treatment process
or equipment, have an adverse effect on the receiving stream, or can otherwise
endanger life, limb, public property, or constitute a nuisance. In forming an
opinion as to the acceptability of these wastes, the City will give
consideration to such factors as the quantities of subject wastes in relation
to flows and velocities in the sewers, materials of construction of the sewers,
nature of the sewage treatment process, capacity of the sewage treatment plant,
degree of treatability of wastes in the sewage treatment plant, and other
pertinent factors. The following substances are specifically prohibited:
1.   Flammable or Explosive Material. Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil,
or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid, or gas.
2.   Toxic or Poisonous Materials. Any waters or wastes containing toxic or
poisonous solids, liquids, infectious or biological wastes, or gases in
sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, to
injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a hazard to
humans or animals, create a public nuisance, or create any hazard in the
receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant including, but not limited to,
cyanides in excess of two mg/l as CN in the wastes as discharged to the public
sewer.
3.   Corrosive Wastes. Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5 or
higher than 9.5 or having any other corrosive property capable of causing
damage or hazard to structures, equipment, and personnel of the sewage works.
4.   Solid or Viscous Substances. Solid or viscous substances in quantities or
of such size capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers, or other
interference with the proper operation of the sewage works such as, but not
limited to, ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags,
feathers, tar, plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure,
hair, fleshing entrails, paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc., either
whole or ground by garbage grinders.
5.   Excessive B.O.D., Solids or Flow.
   A.   Any waters or wastes having:
      (1)   A five-day biochemical oxygen demand greater than 250 parts per
million by weight; or
      (2)   Containing more than 300 parts per million by weight of suspended
solids; or
      (3)   Having an average daily flow greater than two percent of the
average sewage flow of the sewage treatment plant shall be subject to the
review of the Inspector.
   B.   Where necessary, in the opinion of the City, the property owner shall
provide, at the owner’s expense, such preliminary treatment as may be necessary
to:
      (1)   Reduce the biochemical oxygen demand to 250 parts per million by
weight; or
      (2)   Reduce the suspended solids to 300 parts per million by weight; or
      (3)   Control the quantities and rates of discharge of such water or
wastes.
   C.   Plans, specifications, and any other pertinent information relating to
the proposed preliminary treatment facilities shall be submitted for the
approval of the City and no construction of such facilities shall be commenced
until said approvals are obtained in writing.
6.   High Temperature. Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than
150?.
7.   Fat, Oil, Grease. Any water or waste containing fats, wax, grease, or oils
whether emulsified or not, in excess of 100 mg/l or containing substances which
may solidify or become viscous at temperatures between 32º and 150º F.
8.   Garbage. Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. The installation
and operation of any garbage grinder equipped with a motor of one and one-half
horsepower or greater shall be subject to the review and approval of the City.
9.   Acids. Any waters or wastes containing strong acid, iron pickling wastes,
or concentrated plating solutions whether neutralized or not.
10.   Toxic or Objectionable Wastes. Any waters or wastes containing iron,
chromium, copper, zinc, and similar objectionable or toxic substances; or
wastes exerting an excessive requirement to such degree that any such material
received in the composite sewage at the sewage treatment works exceeds the
limits established by the City for such materials.
11.   Odor or Taste. Any waters or wastes containing phenols or other tastes or
odor producing substances in such concentrations exceeding limits which may be
established by the City as necessary, after treatment of the composite sewage
to meet the requirements of State, federal, or other public agencies or
jurisdictions for such discharge to the receiving waters.
12.   Radioactive Wastes. Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life
or concentration as may exceed limits established by the City in compliance
with applicable State or federal regulations.
13.   Any water or wastes containing a toxic or poisonous substance or a
chlorine demand of sufficient concentration or quantity to injure or interfere
with any sewage treatment process, constitute a hazard to animals or humans, or
create any hazard in the receiving waters or the effluent of the sewage
treatment plant. The introduction of heavy metals and similar toxic substances
to the system shall be limited in accordance with current State and federal
pretreatment standards and effluent guidelines with respect to average and
maximum concentrations and quantities. In the absence of specific constituent
pretreatment standards, limits will be established by the City.
14.   Unusual Wastes. Materials that exert or cause:
   A.   Unusual concentrations of inert suspended solids (such as, but not
limited to, Fullers earth, lime slurries, and lime residues) or of dissolved
solids (such as, but not limited to, sodium chloride and sodium sulfate).
   B.   Excessive discoloration (such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and
vegetable tanning solutions).
   C.   Unusual B.O.D., chemical oxygen demand, or chlorine requirements in
such quantities as to constitute a significant load on the sewage treatment
works.
   D.   Unusual volume of flow or concentration of wastes constituting “slugs”
as defined herein.
15.   Untreatable Wastes. Waters or wastes containing substances which are not
amenable to treatment or reduction by the sewage treatment process employed, or
are amenable to treatment only to such degree that the sewage treatment plant
effluent cannot meet the requirements of other agencies having jurisdiction
over discharge to the receiving waters.
97.04   POWERS OF CITY.
If any waters are discharged or are proposed to be discharged to the public
sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess the characteristics
enumerated in Section
97.03 of this chapter, and which in the judgment of the City may have a
deleterious effect upon the sewage works, processes, equipment, or receiving
waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a public
nuisance, the City may:
1.   Reject the wastes;
2.   Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the
public sewers;
3.   Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge;
4.   Require payment to cover the added cost of handling and treating the
wastes not covered by the regularly listed sewer charges under the provisions
of
Chapter 100 of this Code of Ordinances.
If the City permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows, the design
and installation of the plants and equipment shall be subject to the review and
approval of the City and subject to the requirements of all applicable codes,
ordinances, and laws.
97.05   WASTE INTERCEPTORS REQUIRED.
Grease, oil, sludge, and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the
opinion of the City, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid
wastes containing grease in excessive amount, or any flammable wastes, sand, or
other harmful ingredients; except that such interceptors shall not be required
for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a
type and capacity approved by the City and shall be located as to be readily
and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. All interceptors of grease,
oils, sludge, and sand shall be maintained by the property owner, at his or her
expense, in continuously efficient operations at all times.
97.06   SPECIAL FACILITIES.
Where preliminary treatment or flow-equalizing facilities are provided for any
waters or wastes, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and
effective operation by the property owner at such owner’s expense.
97.07   CONTROL MANHOLES.
When required by the City, the owner of any property serviced by a building
lateral carrying industrial wastes or which possess the properties enumerated
in Section
97.03 shall install a suitable control manhole together with such necessary
meters, flow control valves, and other appurtenances in the building lateral to
facilitate observation, sampling, and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole,
when required, shall be continuously accessible and safely located and shall be
constructed in accordance with plans approved by the City. The manhole shall be
installed by the owner, at the owner’s expense, and shall be maintained by the
owner so as to be safe and accessible at all times.
97.08   TESTING OF WASTES.
All measurements, tests, and analysis of the characteristics of waters and
wastes to which reference is made in this chapter shall be obtained and
determined by the City or by a certified laboratory in accordance with the
latest edition of Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater,
published by the American Public Health Association, and shall be determined at
the control manhole provided or upon suitable samples taken at said control
manhole. In the event that no special manhole has been required, the control
manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public
sewer to the point at which the building lateral is connected. Sampling shall
be carried out by a certified laboratory utilizing customarily accepted methods
to reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works and to determine
whether a 24-hour composite of all outfalls of a premise is appropriate or
whether a grab sample or samples should be taken. (Normally, but not always,
B.O.D. and suspended solids analysis are obtained from 24-hour composites of
all outfalls whereas pH’s are determined from periodic grab samples.)
97.09   SPECIAL AGREEMENTS.
No statement contained in this chapter shall be construed as preventing any
special agreement or arrangement between the City and any commercial or
industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character
may be accepted by the City for treatment, subject to payment therefore by the
commercial or industrial concern.
97.10   INTERFERENCE WITH EQUIPMENT PROHIBITED.
No unauthorized person shall maliciously, willfully, or negligently break,
damage, destroy, uncover, deface, or tamper with any structure, appurtenance.
or equipment which is part of the public sewage works. No person shall open or
enter any manhole of the sewer system except by authority of the City.
CHAPTER 98
ON-SITE WASTEWATER SYSTEMS
 
98.01 When Prohibited             98.06 Maintenance of System
98.02 When Required               98.07 Systems Abandoned
98.03 Compliance with Regulations 98.08 Disposal of Septage
98.04 Permit Required             98.09 Minimum Lot Area
98.05 Discharge Restrictions
 
98.01   WHEN PROHIBITED.
Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, it is unlawful to construct or
maintain any on-site wastewater treatment and disposal system or other facility
intended or used for the disposal of sewage.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[3f])
98.02   WHEN REQUIRED.
When a public sanitary sewer is not available under the provisions of Section
95.05, every building wherein persons reside, congregate, or are employed shall
be provided with an approved on-site wastewater treatment and disposal system
complying with the provisions of this chapter.
(567 IAC 69.1[3])
98.03   COMPLIANCE WITH REGULATIONS.
The type, capacity, location, and layout of a private on-site wastewater
treatment and disposal system shall comply with the specifications and
requirements set forth by the Iowa Administrative Code 567, Chapter 69, and
with such additional requirements as are prescribed by the regulations of the
County Board of Health.
(567 IAC 69.1[3 and 4])
98.04   PERMIT REQUIRED.
No person shall install or alter an on-site wastewater treatment and disposal
system without first obtaining a permit from the County Board of Health.
98.05   DISCHARGE RESTRICTIONS.
It is unlawful to discharge any wastewater from an on-site wastewater treatment
and disposal system (except under an NPDES permit) to any ditch, stream, pond,
lake, natural or artificial waterway, drain tile or to the surface of the
ground.
(567 IAC 69.1[3])
98.06   MAINTENANCE OF SYSTEM.
The owner of an on-site wastewater treatment and disposal system shall operate
and maintain the system in a sanitary manner at all times and at no expense to
the City.
98.07   SYSTEMS ABANDONED.
At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by an on-
site wastewater treatment and disposal system, as provided in Section
95.05, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with
these Sanitary Sewer chapters and the on-site wastewater treatment and disposal
system shall be abandoned and filled with suitable material.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[3f])
98.08   DISPOSAL OF SEPTAGE.
No person shall dispose of septage from an on-site treatment system at any
location except an approved disposal site.
98.09   MINIMUM LOT AREA.
No permit shall be issued for any on-site wastewater treatment and disposal
system employing sub-surface soil absorption facilities where the area of the
lot is less than 20,000 square feet.
CHAPTER 99
SERVICE METERING AND METER REQUIREMENTS
 
99.01 All Water Used to be Metered 99.06 Meter Accuracy Testing and Service
                                   Test Charge
99.02 Meter Locations              99.07 Metering Equipment Replacement
                                   Required
99.03 Meter Setting                99.08 Unauthorized Tampering
99.04 Cost of Repairs              99.09 Reading of Meters Required
99.05 Sizing of Meters             99.10 Second or Water-Only Meters Authorized
 
99.01   ALL WATER USED TO BE METERED.
All water shall pass through and shall be accurately measured through meters
furnished by the City and/or Iowa American Waterworks (IAW). The only
exceptions to this requirement will be fire suppression systems, authorized and
required on-site appliances (which may be connected to the public water mains
by direct connection without meters under the direct supervision of the City
and/or IAW), and situations where there can be calculated a defined known
volume of water. In the case of fire sprinkler systems or on-site appliances,
no other connections can be incorporated in the piping supporting the system
and there shall be no valves except main control valves at the entrance to the
building which must be sealed open in the case of fire sprinkler systems or a
hydrant valve which must be left open in the case of on-site hydrants.† 6  (See
Chapter 159)
 
Notes
  † EDITOR’S NOTE: This chapter is applicable to those customers who are also
6 serviced by the Municipal Water System or to those customers who are not
  serviced by the Municipal Water System and who have elected to utilize metered
  billing per the provisions of this chapter.
99.02   METER LOCATIONS.
All meters shall be located as near as practicable to the point where the
building lateral first enters the premises, and the inlet side of the meter
base shall be no farther than a maximum of 12 inches from that point. All
meters shall be located so that they are easily and readily accessible to meter
readers and repairmen and protected from freezing and other potentially
damaging conditions, including strain imposed by adjacent plumbing, and shall
only be located within the particular premises which they directly serve. (In
multi-use buildings, meters may be grouped together for convenience in a
common, public use area). Any meter found to be in violation of this provision
shall be relocated at the expense of the property owner within 30 days after
receipt of notice to do so from the City. If relocation is not able to be done,
radio read equipment will be provided/installed by the City at the expense of
the property owner.
99.03   METER SETTING.
1.   The property owner shall provide all necessary piping and fittings for the
proper setting of the meter base including shut-off valves no more than six
inches distance from the meter, one on either side. Meter pits may be used only
upon approval of the City and shall be of a design and construction approved by
the City. Plumbing adjacent to the meter shall be supported mechanically by a
meter yoke or other approved means so that removal of the meter will not cause
the meter connections to be out of line or shift lengthwise.
2.   The City may, if necessary, require remote or data endpoint transmitters
to be placed wherever they may be necessary to facilitate reading. All new
construction and reconstruction will be required to have remote or data
endpoint capable equipment. This equipment will be supplied/installed by the
IAW or the City. All new, first-time meters and meters installed after a
reconnection shall be installed immediately upon the completion of the plumbing
rough-in inspection. Customers failing to install a meter within such time
frame will be charged the monthly “Contractor’s Fee” as shown in
Chapter 100 until such time as the meter is installed and inspected as required
herein.
99.04   COST OF REPAIRS.
Whenever a water meter or outside meter reader is found to be inoperative, it
shall be replaced as soon as possible. If it is found that damage to the device
has occurred due to the carelessness or negligence of the customer and/or
property owner, then the customer and/or property owner shall be liable for the
cost of repairs or replacement and said cost shall be added to the monthly bill
as an additional charge.
99.05   SIZING OF METERS.
Water meter sizes shall be determined solely by the City or IAW.
99.06   METER ACCURACY TESTING AND SERVICE TEST CHARGE.
Any customer may submit a written request to have a meter tested to verify its
accuracy at any time. There will be a service test charge added to the
customer’s next billing for this test (see
Chapter 100). Should the meter register more than two percent fast, the
customer shall be entitled to a credit adjustment on the next bill following
the testing based on the over registration of the meter computed on the number
of gallons or cubic feet consumed in the previous six-month period. Should the
meter register more than two percent slow, the customer shall be charged an
additional amount on the next bill following the testing based on the under
registration of the meter computed on the number of gallons consumed in the
previous six-month period.
99.07   METERING EQUIPMENT REPLACEMENT REQUIRED.
All meters shall be replaced by the City or IAW on an as needed basis to be
determined by the City or IAW.
Any and all meters and remote readers shall be replaced immediately when they
cease to record accurately.
99.08   UNAUTHORIZED TAMPERING.
It is unlawful for any person, except the City or IAW, to disconnect, alter, or
move any meter, metering wire, or remote meter reading device, or to break any
seal wire of the City or IAW.
(In any prosecution with regards to tampering with any meter or any meter
appurtenances as described above, proof that tampering did occur in some
fashion, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was at
the time the registered customer utilizing that particular meter and associated
appurtenances, shall constitute prima facie evidence that the defendant was the
person who tampered with the meter or associated appurtenances in violation of
this section.)
99.09   READING OF METERS REQUIRED.
In order to insure and maintain system accuracy, all meters shall be read at
least once per month by the City. When service is to be changed into another
customer’s name, or service is to be permanently discontinued, or in the normal
course of changes in occupancies (“moves”), the remote or data endpoint device
shall be read, compared, and adjusted or replaced as necessary.
99.10   SECOND OR WATER-ONLY METERS AUTHORIZED.
When requested, any customer may install and utilize one (1) or more additional
City supplied meters at any property location in accordance with all other
requirements of this Code and the following situation-specific requirements
where such installation is for the metering of water-only uses and where it can
be conclusively shown that any such water metered will not be discharged to or
entering the City’s sanitary sewer system in any way (i.e. lawn & garden
watering, “hot-water heating systems,” swimming pools, other exterior-only
uses, etc.):
1.   The customer must purchase the additional meter(s) from the City for the
purchase cost of the meter and there shall be an activation/installation/
deactivation fee per additional meter installed which shall be payable at the
time of application.
2.   Charges may be assessed against any property for failure to pay any amount
due and owing on said additional meter(s). (Ord.#622 12/1/03)
3.   Each property’s plumbing configuration shall be inspected by the City
prior to supplying and immediately following the installation of any additional
meter and not less than every six months thereafter, prior to the refund of any
consumer deposit in connection therewith, prior to the deactivation of any
additional meter account, and upon a change in ownership and/or occupancy, to
assure metering accuracy.
4.   Any water acquired and recorded through an additional meter which enters
the City’s sanitary sewer system shall be considered a violation of this Code
and may be prosecuted in any manner allowed for herein and/or the City may
immediately begin charging for sewer service on the additional meter account
(s).
5.   Prior to deactivating an additional meter account, the customer must
modify the property’s plumbing so that any and all water use is acquired and
recorded through a single metering point, the additional meter must be returned
to the City in good working order, and the property’s plumbing reconfiguration
must be inspected and approved by the City. (Ord. #600 8/19/02)
6.   The repair, upkeep, and replacement of any water-only meters installed are
the customer’s responsibility and shall abide by the above regulations.
(Section 99.10 – Ord._840 – Jan. 25 Supp.)
CHAPTER 100
SEWER SERVICE CHARGES

for Special Services
 
100.01   SEWER SERVICE CHARGES REQUIRED.
Each customer shall pay for sewer service provided by the City based upon the
amount of water used as determined by meters provided for in
Chapter 99 of this Code of Ordinances, or based upon a flat rate as specified
below, unless specifically waived in writing by the City Council or as
specified herein. Each location, building, premises, or connection shall be
considered a separate and distinct customer whether owned or controlled by the
same person or not.
100.02   RATE.
There shall be and there is hereby established a sewer service charge for the
use of and for the service supplied by the Municipal Sanitary Swer Utility
based upon the amount of water used, flat rates, or excess discharges as
follows:
Charge Descriptors                     Sewer Service Charges
Charge Descriptors                     Sewer Service Charges
Regular metered charge                 $24.75 per user unit
Eligible senior monthly metered charge $22.15 per user unit
Depreciation and replacement reserve   $5.50 per user unit (included in base
                                       meter charge)
Monthly metered usage charge           $2.04/500 gallons (above first 500)
Non-metered monthly flat rates         $73.87 (flat rate)
                                       $56.78 (contractor rate)
Meter activation/Deactivation fee      $48.30 $50.00 per additional meter
                                       installed
(Section 100.02 – Ord._841 – Jan. 25 Supp.)
1.   “Seniors” means any residential customers of the Sanitary Sewer Utility,
65 years of age or older, that have registered for said discount at City Hall
prior to any billing date. (See definition of “eligible senior citizen” for
further clarification.) Any such user shall be charged the “Monthly Metered
Minimum Charge, Eligible Seniors Only” amount as spelled out above, provided
that such user elects to use “metered” billing. Any such user, who would
otherwise qualify, that elects not to use “metered” billing shall then be
charged the “Non-Metered Monthly Flat Rate, Seniors” amount as spelled out
above.
2.   “Eligible Senior Citizen” discount shall apply only to senior citizens
residing within the City and the dwelling unit, and not to rental units, rental
houses, rental apartments, laundry rooms/common areas, etc., that may be owned
but not occupied by a senior citizen. Senior citizens will not be eligible for
this discount if anyone other than a spouse or other senior citizen resides at
that service location for a period greater than 30 days. Senior citizens
seeking this discount must annually verify their eligibility by no later than
May 15. Eligibility will be verified through methods determined and approved by
the City Administrator as outlined in Section
95.01(11). Absent timely and appropriate verification as specified herein,
billing will be at the regular, non-discounted rate.
3.   Governmental and specifically designated “quasi-governmental” user units
will be charged for services at the City Council’s discretion.
4.   All “user units” or multiples thereof who are also connected to the
municipal water system shall be metered to define water consumption, upon which
sewer service charges are based. Any single-family residential “user unit” that
is not connected to the municipal water system and that elects NOT to utilize
metered billing for sewer services shall be billed the applicable “Non-Metered
Monthly Flat Rate” amount as spelled out above.
5.   All commercial, industrial, and governmental “user units” or multiples
thereof shall be metered under all circumstances. (Any such “user unit” that is
not metered as of the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter
(September 9, 1993) shall make arrangements for and shall be metered within 30
days from the receipt of a notice from the City to do so.
6.   Common areas, such as laundry rooms in apartments, etc., shall be
considered as single user units regardless of the number of users who use it.
7.   The billing period for each “user unit” shall be monthly.
8.   In no case shall the minimum service charge be less than that shown in the
rate chart in Section
100.02.
9.   In the event that multiple “user units” are served by a single meter, the
minimum monthly service charge per “user unit” shall be applied to each
connected “user unit” to determine the total minimum monthly service charges
applicable to the multiple use meter. If two or more users are serviced off of
one meter, they are to be granted the minimum number of gallons (500) times the
number of user units (i.e., 2 x 500 = 1,000).
10.   In the event that a property containing multiple “user units” is served
by a single meter, the plumbing shall be modified to provide a separate meter
for each “user unit” at such time as the property is sold or otherwise changes
ownership or control. Until such time as the plumbing is modified to comply
with this chapter, the billing will be administered as mentioned above with no
consideration for the number of occupied versus vacant units.
11.   The monthly billing for each “user unit” shall include both the minimum
charge and the metered usage charge as spelled out herein based upon the meter
reading, unless otherwise noted herein.
12.   All flat rate billings will continue in force until service is
permanently terminated. There will be no discontinuation in billing for such
things as vacations, temporary occupancies, etc. Metered billings only may be
discontinued for a period of time to accommodate vacations, vacancies,
temporary occupancies, etc. (similar to the provisions in Chapter 92) if a
request is confirmed with the Billing Clerk ahead of time, specific start and
stop dates are given, and inside/outside meter readings are obtained.
13.   The monthly billing method will automatically be changed to a flat rate
billing and will remain so until the situation is corrected for those “user
units” NOT connected to the Municipal Water Supply System who have elected to
use metered billing where individual private well debris has plugged the City’s
water meter three or more times during any six-month period.
14.   “Contractor’s Fees” as shown herein shall be charged to all utility hook-
up applicants commencing upon the completion of the plumbing rough- in
inspection.
100.03   CUSTOMER DEPOSITS REQUIRED.
Customer deposits, covering all services supplied by the City, shall be
required for each and every service provided to each and every user unit in
connection with new customers and of those who have an unacceptable credit
record or who have a prior record of failure to pay service charges rendered by
the City.
1.   Such deposits shall be as follows and shall be submitted prior to
supplying said services and/or issuing a building lateral installation/
connection permit:
Classification Amount
Classification                       Amount
Sewer/garbage (with meter)           $150.00
Sewer/garbage (without meter)        $150.00
Sewer only (with meter)              $100.00
Sewer only (without meter)           $100.00
Garbage only - Residential           $50.00
Sewer only (with meter) - Commercial $100.00
Deposits listed are MINIMUMS ONLY and are based on a maximum meter size of not
more than ¾”. Customers requiring larger or multiple meters will be required to
pay a proportionally larger deposit based on the size and number of meters.
 
2.   Customer deposits may be transferred from one location to another, or into
another person’s name, provided that the customer’s bill is paid in full and is
not delinquent in any way, and the customer deposit amount shall be adjusted
upward, if necessary, to reflect the current required amount as specified
herein and paid prior to said transfer.
3.   Customer deposits are required to guarantee payment for any customer-
related damages to any metering device and payment for any municipal service-
related charges. To this end, the customer deposit shall be credited and then
refunded, if appropriate, in the following manner: first to any metering device
damages; next to any garbage service-related charges; next to any sewer
utility-related charges; and the remainder thereafter may be refunded to the
customer.
4.   For those “Sewer Only” single-family residential customers who are on a
“metered billing” basis and request that the meter be removed from the
premises, then the customer deposit service status difference shall be
refunded. Otherwise, the meter will remain on the premises, the billing will be
adjusted accordingly to reflect the flat rate amount, and the customer deposit
shall not be refunded until such time as the meter is removed.
100.04   BILLING PROCEDURES FOR SEWER SERVICE.
1.   The charges aforesaid shall be billed monthly by such methods as shall be
adopted by the City Administrator subject to Council approval. Said billings
and the minimum monthly billings (and surcharges, if applicable) shall be
billed no later than the last day of each month and all bills for said services
shall be due and payable and received in the office of the Billing Clerk on or
before the 15th day of the month following the date of the billing and will be
considered delinquent and eligible for assessment if not paid in full by that
time. “On or before the 15th day” means on or before 5:00 p.m. on the close of
the normal business day if paying in the office or by drop box or 4:45 p.m. if
paying on-line on the 15th. If the 15th of the month falls on a Saturday,
Sunday, or a holiday, then payment must be received no later than the close of
the next following business day. If any payment is not received in the office
of the Billing Clerk on or before the 15th day of the month following the date
of the billing, it shall be deemed delinquent, and a late charge shall be added
thereto in the amount of 10 percent. (Governmental units, sub-units, and
designated “quasi- governmental units will not be charged any penalties.) There
will be no compounding of collection charges (i.e., penalties on penalties).
Delinquent accounts may also have their water shut-off in accordance with Iowa
law and be charged for a water shut-off fee. If the total accumulated
collection charges and/or certified mailing charges reach or exceed $10.00,
these charges will be assessed as any other charges as provided for herein. The
Billing Clerk may waive the late charge mentioned above once per calendar year
per customer.
2.   Billings for those industrial wastewater load charges as shown in the
above table shall be done monthly in conjunction with the regular billing and
shall be calculated based on the usage recorded for that month adjusted for the
quantities calculated as determined by the City’s sampling. Any unpaid amount
covered by this paragraph shall be subject to the same procedures for
collection as specified for other types of service charges listed herein.
3.   Billing for contract “bulk disposal” shall be done as soon as possible
after service is provided.
4.   Billing to leased or rental properties may be either to the property owner
or to the tenant/renter, but the property owner shall ultimately be responsible
for any unpaid charges, and/or assessments.
5.   Residential customers of the Municipal Sanitary Sewer Utility, as defined,
who are not also customers of the Municipal Water System may elect to use or
change the billing method from flat rate to metered billing, or vice versa,
provided appropriate customer deposits are on file. If going from metered to
flat rate billing, a reading will be taken on the day requested. If the request
falls before the 15th of the month, then the final metered bill will be based
on usage only, and then that current month’s billing will reflect the non-
metered, monthly flat rate as applicable. If the request falls after the 15th
of the month, then the final metered bill will be based on the final usage
combined with the monthly minimum charges. If going from flat rate billing to
metered billing, the meter will be installed by the 15th of the month to be
reflected in that month’s billing. If the meter is installed after the 15th of
the month, then the customer will be billed the flat rate charge for the
current month and the metered billing will begin with the next month’s billing.
6.   If a customer deposit and request for service is filed with the Billing
Clerk on or before the 15th of any month, the billing shall start with that
month’s billing and if it is filed after the 15th of the month, the billing
will begin with the next month’s billing. If a person moves out of the City or
is no longer a customer of the sanitary sewer system on or before the 15th of
any month, such person shall not be charged a minimum service charge but shall
be charged for any actual usage of service.
7.   In the event that the City receives any returned checks from the bank for
lack of sufficient funds, the customer will have three days to pay for the
check and the NSF charges.
8.   Billing may be temporarily discontinued to accommodate vacations,
vacancies, etc., to those “metered” users if a request is confirmed with the
Billing Clerk ahead of time, specific start and stop dates are given, and
inside/outside meter readings are obtained.
9.   The bill format, structure, content, and wording will be determined by the
City Administrator. In addition to specifying any and all amounts due,
information contained on the bill must clearly indicate to the customer that
the bill serves as the customer’s only form of notice and that the customer
will receive only one other prior notice in the event that charges must be
assessed for nonpayment.
100.05   BILLING PROCEDURES AND CHARGES FOR SPECIAL SERVICES.
Following is a listing of special service charges not associated with actual
water consumption:
 
Description                              Amount
Meter service test                       $50.00/test
Leak test                                $50.00/test
Meter damage charges                     Cost plus $50.00
NSF check charge                         $30.00
Building lateral and/or curb stop locate $50.00
Water shut-off fee                       $46.00 (or contractual rate with IAW)
 
100.06   BILL ADJUSTMENT.
Adjustments to bills may be made only by the City Administrator or City Council
to take into account such occurrences as billing errors, meter errors,
incorrect readings, etc. Where metered billing is used and when all or a
portion of the metering system experiences some type of metering failure, the
following procedures shall be used for bill adjustments:
1.   When the water meter itself fails to properly record the usage, the next
billing, after discovery of the failure, will be based on the usage that may
have been recorded since the last reading or on an estimated amount based on
the average of the last 12 readings observed, whichever is higher.
2.   When only the remote reader fails to properly record the usage, the next
billing, after discovery of the failure, will be based on the actual reading
obtained from the water meter itself. In these instances when a bill is
incurred where it is more than twice the customer’s normal monthly bill payment
arrangements may be established whereby:
   A.   In addition to their current monthly bill, the amount of the “large
bill” above the normal monthly bill can be paid back over a period of months
equal to the amount of the “large bill” minus the normal monthly bill divided
by the normal monthly bill (i.e. (100- 25)/25=3 months), or;
   B.   In addition to their current monthly bill, an amount equal to 20% of
the “large bill” can be paid until such time as there is no outstanding amount
due.
Failure to make payment in full each month under one of the above-referenced
programs will automatically make the full amount due and owing with the next
bill issued following the missed or partial payment.
100.07   BILL COMPLAINTS.
Questions and/or complaints about the bills will first be handled or processed
through the Billing Clerk. If satisfaction is not achieved, an appeal may then
be made, in writing, to the City Administrator for a decision on the matter.
After this decision, an appeal may then be made, in writing, to the City
Council, whose decision shall be final.
100.08   CHARGES ASSESSED AND/OR SERVICE TERMINATION FOR NONPAYMENT.
The Billing Clerk shall notify each sewer service customer classified as the
“property owner” and “sewer-only” tenants and the respective property owner,
whose sewer service bill, or any portion thereof, is past due, that any unpaid
sewer service charges will be certified as delinquent to the Scott County
Auditor by the City, assessed, and act as a lien against the property and hence
collected as property taxes, unless the total outstanding sewer service charges
and other related charges are paid in full and received in the office of the
Billing Clerk by the close of business on or before the date specified in the
notice. (For the purpose of this section, “date of notice” shall be the date
that the notice is dated.) If any due date above falls on a holiday, Saturday,
or Sunday, the payment must be received no later than the close of the next
following business day.) The above stated notice will be the sewer utility
bill. If past due sewer charges and/or related charges are not paid in full 30
days after the billing date on the utility bill, that amount will be assessed.
A separate notice will be sent to the property owner of past due tenant
accounts by regular mail on the same day as the above-mentioned utility bill
informing them of the past due amount and the assessment proceedings. Pursuant
to the provisions allowed within Section 476.20(1)(b) of the Code of Iowa, as
amended, in addition to the assessment provisions contained herein, or in lieu
thereof, the City may cause to have a property’s water service terminated for
nonpayment of charges after due notice is provided.
100.09   AUTHORITY TO RENDER AND COLLECT BILLS AND SYSTEM ACCOUNTABILITY.
1.   It is hereby made the duty of the City Administrator to render bills for
sewer service and all other charges in connection therewith and to collect all
monies due therefrom.
2.   All revenues and monies derived from the operation of the sewer system
shall be paid to and held by the City separate and apart from all other funds
of the City. All of said sums and all other funds and monies incident to the
operation of said system as may be delivered to the City, shall be deposited in
a separate fund designated the “Sewer Revenue Fund.” The City shall administer
said fund in every respect in the manner provided by the Code of Iowa and all
other laws pertaining thereto, except that all such revenues collected shall
remain a permanent part of this fund and shall not be transferred to any other
fund except upon specific written approval of the City Council.
3.   The City shall establish a proper system of accounts and shall keep proper
records, books, and accounts in which complete and correct entries shall be
made of all transactions relative to the sewer system, and, at regular annual
intervals, the Council shall cause to be made an audit, by an independent
auditing firm or the State of Iowa, of the books to show the receipts and
disbursements of the sewer system. The City shall be required annually to
prepare a budget of the sanitary sewer system to show the required revenues and
expenses. If necessary, sewer service charges will be adjusted to produce
adequate income to retire the indebtedness; meet operation, maintenance, and
replacement needs; and required reserves.
CHAPTER 105

Nuisance Conditions
105.04 Health and Fire Hazard            105.11 Prohibited Practices
105.05 Open Burning Prohibited           105.12 Public Sanitary Landfills
                                         Designated
105.06 Separation of Yard Waste Required 105.13 Presumption of Liability in
                                         Enforcement
105.07 Littering Prohibited
 
105.01   PURPOSE.
The purpose of the chapters in this Code of Ordinances pertaining to Solid
Waste Control and Collection is to provide for the sanitary storage,
collection, and disposal of solid waste and, thereby, to protect the citizens
of the City from such hazards to their health, safety, and welfare as may
result from the uncontrolled disposal of solid waste.
105.02   DEFINITIONS.
For use in these chapters the following terms are defined:
1.   “Collector” means any person authorized to gather solid waste from public
and private places.
2.   “Discard” means to place, cause to be placed, throw, deposit, or drop.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 455B.361[1])
3.   “Dwelling unit” means any room or group of rooms located within a
structure and forming a single habitable unit with facilities that are used or
are intended to be used for living, sleeping, cooking, and eating.
4.   “Garbage” means all solid and semisolid, putrescible animal and vegetable
waste resulting from the handling, preparing, cooking, storing, serving, and
consuming of food or of material intended for use as food, and all offal,
excluding useful industrial by-products, and includes all such substances from
all public and private establishments and from all residences.
(567 IAC 100.2)
5.   “Landscape waste” means any vegetable or plant waste except garbage. The
term includes trees, tree trimmings, branches, stumps, brush, weeds, leaves,
grass, shrubbery, and yard trimmings.
(567 IAC 20.2)
6.   “Litter” means any garbage, rubbish, trash, refuse, waste materials, or
debris not exceeding 10 pounds in weight or 15 cubic feet in volume. Litter
includes but is not limited to empty beverage containers, cigarette butts, food
waste packaging, other food or candy wrappers, handbills, empty cartons, or
boxes.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 455B.361[2])
7.   “Owner” means, in addition to the record titleholder, any person residing
in, renting, leasing, occupying, operating, or transacting business in any
premises, and as between such parties the duties, responsibilities,
liabilities, and obligations hereinafter imposed shall be joint and several.
8.   “Processing facility” means any incinerator, baler, shredder, or similar
facility or process employed to reduce the volume of or change the
characteristics of solid waste prior to final disposal.
9.   “Property served” means any property which is being used or occupied and
is eligible to receive refuse collection and disposal service as provided
herein.
10.   “Refuse” means putrescible and non-putrescible waste, including but not
limited to garbage, rubbish, ashes, incinerator residues, street cleanings,
market and industrial solid waste, and sewage treatment waste in dry or
semisolid form.
(567 IAC 100.2)
11.   “Residential premises” means a single-family dwelling and any multiple-
family dwelling up to and including five separate dwelling units.
12.   “Residential waste” means any refuse generated on the premises as a
result of residential activities. The term includes landscape waste grown on
the premises or deposited thereon by the elements, but excludes garbage, tires,
trade wastes, and any locally recyclable goods or plastics.
(567 IAC 20.2)
13.   “Rubbish” means non-putrescible solid waste consisting of combustible and
non-combustible waste, such as ashes, paper, cardboard, tin cans, yard
clippings, wood, glass, bedding, crockery, or litter of any kind.
(567 IAC 100.2)
14.   “Sanitary disposal” means a method of treating solid waste so that it
does not produce a hazard to the public health or safety or create a nuisance.
(567 IAC 100.2)
15.   “Sanitary disposal project” means all facilities and appurtenances
(including all real and personal property connected with such facilities) that
are acquired, purchased, constructed, reconstructed, equipped, improved,
extended, maintained, or operated to facilitate the final disposition of solid
waste without creating a significant hazard to the public health or safety, and
which are approved by the Director of the State Department of Natural
Resources. “Sanitary disposal project” does not include a pyrolysis or
gasification facility as defined in Section 455B.301 of the Code of Iowa.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 455B.301)
16.   “Scavenging” means the collecting, picking up, or gathering of discarded
material no longer of value for its original purpose, but which has value if
reclaimed.
17.   “Single-family dwelling” means a structure containing one dwelling unit
only.
18.   “Solid waste” means garbage, refuse, rubbish, and other similar discarded
solid or semisolid materials, including but not limited to such materials
resulting from industrial, commercial, agricultural, and domestic activities.
Solid waste may include vehicles, as defined by Section 321.1 of the Code of
Iowa. Solid waste does not include any of the following:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 455B.301)
   A.   Hazardous waste regulated under the Federal Resource Conservation and
Recovery Act, 42 U.S.C. § 6921-6934.
   B.   Hazardous waste as defined in Section 455B.411 of the Code of Iowa,
except to the extent that rules allowing for the disposal of specific wastes
have been adopted by the State Environmental Protection Commission.
   C.   Source, special nuclear, or by-product material as defined in the
Atomic Energy Act of 1954, as amended to January 1, 1979.
   D.   Petroleum contaminated soil that has been remediated to acceptable
State or federal standards.
   E.   Steel slag which is a product resulting from the steel manufacturing
process and is managed as an item of value in a controlled manner and not as a
discarded material.
   F.   Material that is legitimately recycled pursuant to Section 455D.4A of
the Code of Iowa.
   G.   Post-use polymers or recoverable feedstocks that are any of the
following:
      (1)   Processed at a pyrolysis or gasification facility.
      (2)   Held at a pyrolysis or gasification facility prior to processing to
ensure production is not interrupted.
19.   “Toxic and hazardous waste” means waste materials, including (but not
limited to) poisons, pesticides, herbicides, acids, caustics, pathological
waste, flammable or explosive materials, and similar harmful waste that
requires special handling and that must be disposed of in such a manner as to
conserve the environment and protect the public health and safety.
(567 IAC 100.2)
20.   “Yard waste” means any debris such as grass clippings, leaves, garden
waste, brush, and trees. Yard waste does not include tree stumps.
105.03   SANITARY DISPOSAL REQUIRED AND NUISANCE CONDITIONS.
It is the duty of each owner to provide for the sanitary disposal of all refuse
accumulating on the owner’s premises. The keeping of garbage in containers
other than containers prescribed by this chapter or the keeping upon premises
of garbage or rubbish which is allowed to become offensive and noisome shall
constitute a public nuisance and may be abated in accordance with the
provisions of
Chapter 50. (The fact that garbage, refuse, or other waste remains on any
premises in the City in violation of this chapter shall be prima facie evidence
that the property owner of such premises is responsible for the violation).
105.04   HEALTH AND FIRE HAZARD.
It is unlawful for any person to permit to accumulate on any premises, improved
or vacant, or on any public place, such quantities of solid waste that
constitute a health, sanitation, or fire hazard.
105.05   OPEN BURNING PROHIBITED.
No person shall allow, cause, or permit open burning of combustible materials
where the products of combustion are emitted into the open air without passing
through a chimney or stack, except that open burning is permitted in the
following circumstances:
(567 IAC 23.2 and 100.2)
1.   Disaster Rubbish. The open burning of rubbish, including landscape waste,
for the duration of the community disaster period in cases where an officially
declared emergency condition exists, provided that the burning of any
structures or demolished structures is conducted in accordance with 40 CFR
Section 61.145.
(567 IAC 23.2[3] “a”)
2.   Trees and Tree Trimmings. The open burning of trees and tree trimmings at
a City-operated burning site, provided such burning is conducted in compliance
with the rules established by the State Department of Natural Resources.
(567 IAC 23.2[3] “b”)
3.   Flare Stacks. The open burning or flaring of waste gases, provided such
open burning or flaring is conducted in compliance with applicable rules of the
State Department of Natural Resources.
(567 IAC 23.2[3] “c”)
4.   Landscape Waste. The disposal by open burning of landscape waste
originating on the premises. However, the burning of landscape waste produced
in clearing, grubbing, and construction operations shall be limited to areas
located at least one-fourth mile from any building inhabited by other than the
landowner or tenant conducting the open burning. Rubber tires shall not be used
to ignite landscape waste.
(567 IAC 23.2[3] “d”)
5.   Outdoor Recreational Fires. Open fires for cooking, heating, recreation,
and ceremonies (including such as the American Legion Flag Retirement),
contained within commercially produced, outdoor fireplaces, wood burning
stoves, barbecue grills, outdoor fire pits/rings, chimineas, and other such
devices intended for such purposes may be used. Commercially produced,
combustible wood products (logs, chips, etc.) sold and intended solely for the
purpose of use in such fireplaces, wood burning stoves, fire pits/rings,
chimineas, etc., may be used.
6.   Training Fires. Fires set for the purpose of conducting bona fide training
of public or industrial employees in firefighting methods, provided that the
training fires are conducted in compliance with rules established by the State
Department of Natural Resources.
(567 IAC 23.2[3] “g”)
7.   Variance. Any person wishing to conduct open burning of materials not
permitted herein may make an application for a variance to the Director of the
State Department of Natural Resources.
(567 IAC 23.2[2])
8.   Rubber tires, chemicals, furniture, carpeting, household appliances, vinyl
products (such as flooring or siding), trade waste, garbage, rubbish,
residential waste, railroad ties, and other structural materials shall not be
burned.
9.   Use of Accelerants Prohibited. With the exception of the use of
commercially produced and available “charcoal lighter fluid,” the use of any
accelerant in connection with any listed permitted open burning activity is
prohibited. The term “accelerant” as used in this section means any manmade,
processed liquid or material used for the purpose of artificially increasing
the natural burn rate of any material, (i.e., gasoline, diesel fuel, etc.).
10.   Unattended Fires Prohibited. At least one adult shall visually monitor
and must be physically present in the immediate vicinity of any listed
permitted open burning activity. There must be a sustainable water source
present and/or another means readily available for extinguishing the fire until
such fire is completely extinguished. In remote areas where an extinguishment
source or other extinguishment method is not readily available, an adult shall
be present at all times with a viable means of communication for alerting
emergency services whenever a fire is present.
105.06   SEPARATION OF YARD WASTE REQUIRED.
All yard waste shall be separated by the owner or occupant from all other solid
waste accumulated on the premises and shall be composted on the premises or
placed in acceptable containers and set out for collection.
105.07   LITTERING PROHIBITED.
No person shall discard any litter onto or in any water or land, except that
nothing in this section shall be construed to affect the authorized collection
and discarding of such litter in or on areas or receptacles provided for such
purpose. When litter is discarded from a motor vehicle, the driver of the motor
vehicle shall be responsible for the act in any case where doubt exists as to
which occupant of the motor vehicle actually discarded the litter.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 455B.363)
105.08   TOXIC AND HAZARDOUS WASTE.
No person shall deposit in a solid waste container or otherwise offer for
collection any toxic or hazardous waste. Such materials shall be transported
and disposed of as prescribed by the Director of the State Department of
Natural Resources.
(567 IAC 100.2)
(567 IAC 102.13[2] and 400 IAC 27.14[2])
105.09   OPEN DUMPING.
No person shall dump or deposit or permit the dumping or depositing of any
solid waste at any place other than a sanitary disposal project approved by the
Directors of the State Department of Natural Resources unless the person has
been granted a permit by the State Department of Natural Resources which allows
the dumping or depositing of solid waste on land owned or leased by the person.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 455B.307)
105.10   WASTE STORAGE CONTAINERS.
Every person owning, managing, operating, leasing, or renting any premises,
dwelling unit, or any place where refuse accumulates shall provide and at all
times maintain in good order and repair portable containers capable of holding
all refuse which would ordinarily accumulate on such premises between the times
of successive collection. The owner of any multiple dwelling shall furnish or
require the tenants to furnish proper garbage containers.
1.   Container Specifications. Waste storage containers shall comply with the
following specifications:
   A.   Container Specifications. Unless otherwise waived by resolution of the
Council, the only waste storage containers to be used for collection purposes
shall be those as approved and provided by the City. The City shall deliver to
every dwelling unit one container (roll cart) for waste storage and collection
and one container (roll cart) for recycling storage and collection. There shall
be a $10.00 service and processing charge for any permitted change in container
size after an initial 60-day trial period. There shall be no such charge during
the 60-day trial period immediately following the initial delivery of the carts
to the dwelling unit.
   B.   Commercial. Every person owning, managing, operating, leasing, or
renting any commercial premises, where refuse accumulates and where its storage
in portable containers as required above is impractical, shall maintain metal
bulk storage receptacles of sufficient size and number with lids or covers.
   C.   Residential Yard Waste. Residential yard waste shall be collected as
specified and approved by the City and/or contractor. Only those types and
styles of yard waste collection containers (biodegradable-photodegradable
polyethylene bags, paper bags, etc.) and/or banding devices for shrubbery/
brush, or a combination of the above, as designated by the City and/or
contractor, shall be used for the collection of yard waste.
2.   Storage of Containers. Residential solid waste containers shall be stored
upon the residential premises. Commercial solid waste containers shall be
stored upon private property, unless the owner has been granted written
permission from the City to use public property for such purposes. The storage
site shall be well drained and fully accessible to collection equipment, public
health personnel, and fire inspection personnel. All owners of residential and
commercial premises shall be responsible for proper storage of all garbage and
yard waste to prevent materials from being blown or scattered around
neighboring yards and streets.
3.   Location of Containers for Collection. Containers for the storage of
refuse awaiting collection shall be placed out-of-doors at a point as close as
possible to the curb line or driving surface edge by the owner or occupant of
the premises served. Containers or other wastes placed at the curb line or
driving surface edge shall not be so placed more than 12 hours in advance of
the regularly scheduled collection day and shall be promptly removed from the
curb line following collection.
4.   Nonconforming Containers and Extraneous Waste. Only those containers as
specified and approved by the City shall be placed at the street’s edge for the
collection and disposal of waste and recyclables. Unless otherwise approved by
the City, any waste, recyclables, or other materials not placed within approved
containers shall not be collected and shall be deemed a nuisance and may be
immediately abated as provided for in this code.
105.11   PROHIBITED PRACTICES.
It is unlawful for any person to:
1.   Unlawful Use of Containers. Deposit refuse in any solid waste containers
not owned by such person without the written consent of the owner of such
containers.
2.   Interfere with Collectors. Interfere in any manner with solid waste
collection equipment or with solid waste collectors in the lawful performance
of their duties as such, whether such equipment or collectors be those of the
City, or those of any other authorized waste collection service.
3.   Unlawful Disposal. Dispose of refuse at any facility or location which is
not an approved sanitary disposal project.
4.   Scavenging. Scavenge (as defined herein) materials from any premises. This
does not include the collection of cans or bottles which are eligible to be
refunded under Iowa law, provided that the cans or bottles are not scavenged
from within solid waste storage containers.
5.   Unlawful Collection. Engage in the business of collecting, transporting,
processing, or disposing of refuse within the City without a license therefore
issued by the City.
6.   Burn Barrels. Burn anything in any barrel, device, or enclosure other than
such burning, or the use of commercial burning devices approved by this Code or
the Iowa Department of Natural Resources, or the supervised burning of official
documents or records which are required by law to be destroyed by burning or
mutilation.
105.12   PUBLIC SANITARY LANDFILLS DESIGNATED.
Solid waste generated or produced within the City shall be disposed of at a
processing facility approved by the City and by the Director. Such processing
facilities are designated as official “public sanitary landfills.”
105.13   PRESUMPTION OF LIABILITY IN ENFORCEMENT.
In addition to the provisions contained within Section
105.07 (Littering Prohibited) and Section
1.08 (Presumption of Liability), the owner of any vehicle which is positively
identified at the scene of and involved in an incident of open or illegal
dumping of solid waste, or the owner (as identified by the presence of
reasonably conclusive evidence discovered amongst any illegally dumped solid
waste) shall be deemed prima facie responsible for the violation so evidenced
and shall be subject to any penalties or other remedial action as set forth
herein. (It is the intent of this section to effect those provisions of the
Code of Iowa enumerated in Sections 455B.361 through 455B.364, as amended).
CHAPTER 106
COLLECTION OF SOLID WASTE
 
106.01 Collection Service      106.05 Bulky Rubbish
106.02 Collection Vehicles     106.06 Collector’s License
106.03 Loading                 106.07 Collection Fees
106.04 Frequency of Collection 106.08 Lien for Nonpayment
 
106.01   COLLECTION SERVICE.
The collection of solid waste within the City shall be only by collectors
licensed by the City.
106.02   COLLECTION VEHICLES.
Vehicles or containers used for the collection and transportation of garbage
and similar putrescible waste or refuse containing such materials shall be
leakproof, durable, and of easily cleanable construction. They shall be cleaned
to prevent nuisances, pollution, or insect breeding and shall be maintained in
good repair. Vehicles shall not exceed 25 cubic yards when making pickups in
residential areas. Larger units may be used in commercial and industrial areas.
Vehicles shall also be equipped with rotating yellow lights or flashing lights
and shall have said lights in operation when pickups are being made.
106.03   LOADING.
