Administrator may revoke any license issued pursuant to this chapter for the
following reasons:
1.   Fraudulent Statements. The licensee has made fraudulent statements in the
application for the license or in the conduct of the business.
2.   Violation of Law. The licensee has violated this chapter or has otherwise
conducted the business in an unlawful manner.
3.   Endangered Public Welfare, Health, or Safety. The licensee has conducted
the business in such manner as to endanger the public welfare, safety, order,
or morals.
The City Administrator shall send the written notice to the licensee at the
licensee’s local address. The notice shall contain particulars of the
complaints against the licensee, the ordinance provisions or State statutes
allegedly violated, and the date, time, and place for hearing on the matter.
122.13   HEARING.
The City Administrator shall conduct a hearing at which both the licensee and
any complainants shall be present to determine the truth of the facts alleged
in the complaint and notice. Should the licensee, or authorized representative,
fail to appear without good cause, the City Administrator may proceed to a
determination of the complaint.
122.14   RECORD AND DETERMINATION.
The City Administrator shall make and record findings of fact and conclusions
of law and shall revoke a license only when upon review of the entire record
the City Administrator finds clear and convincing evidence of substantial
violation of this chapter or State law.
122.15   APPEAL.
If the City Administrator revokes or refuses to issue a license, the City
Administrator shall make a part of the record the reasons for such revocation
or refusal. The licensee, or the applicant, shall have a right to a hearing
before the Council at its next regular meeting. The Council may reverse,
modify, or affirm the decision of the City Administrator by a majority vote of
the Council members present and the City Administrator shall carry out the
decision of the Council.
122.16   EFFECT OF REVOCATION.
Revocation of any license shall bar the licensee from being eligible for any
license under this chapter for a period of one year from the date of the
revocation.
122.17   LICENSE EXEMPTIONS.
The following are excluded from the application of this chapter.
1.   Newspapers. Persons delivering, collecting for, or selling subscriptions
to newspapers.
2.   Club Members. Members of local civic and service clubs, Boy Scout, Girl
Scout, 4-H Clubs, Future Farmers of America, and similar organizations.
3.   Garage Sales by Local Residents and Farmers. Local residents conducting a
“garage sale” as defined in the City’s Zoning chapter (Section
170.07(7)(C), as amended) and farmers who offer for sale their own products.
4.   Students. Students representing the local school districts conducting
projects sponsored by organizations recognized by the school.
5.   Route Sales. Route delivery persons who only incidentally solicit
additional business or make special sales.
6.   Resale or Institutional Use. Persons customarily calling on businesses or
institutions for the purposes of selling products for resale or institutional
use.
7.   Individual peddlers, solicitors, and transient merchants who are a pre-
identified and pre-registered participant conducting business within the area
of, during, and as an approved, integral part of a recognized and approved
City-Wide or Special Event only. (See Sections
122.04 and
49.05)
8.   Minor Businesses. An on-site transactional business traditionally operated
exclusively by a person under the age of 18, operated on an occasional basis
for no more than 89 calendar days in a calendar year.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.3[15])
9.   Individual peddlers, solicitors, and transient merchants who are
conducting business within the public vending areas identified in
Chapter 123 shall conform to all of the limitations and requirements identified
in
Chapter 123.
122.18   CHARITABLE, NONPROFIT, AND LOCAL CIVIC ORGANIZATIONS REQUIREMENTS.
“Local Civic organizations” defined as those recognized organizations domiciled
within the corporate City limits, holding a “non-profit” or “not-for-profit”
status, or any City Council-recognized organization domiciled within the
corporate City limits, and authorized representatives of charitable or
nonprofit organizations domiciled within the corporate City limits operating
under the provisions of Chapter 504 of the Code of Iowa, desiring to solicit
money or to distribute literature only are exempt from the operation of
Sections
122.04 and
122.05,
122.17, and
122.18. All such organizations are required to submit in writing to the City
the name and purpose of the cause for which such activities are sought, names
and addresses of the officers and directors of the organization, the period
during which such activities are to be carried on, and whether any commissions,
fees, or wages are to be charged by the solicitor and the amount thereof. If
the City Administrator finds that the organization is a bona fide locally
domiciled charity, nonprofit organization, or Council-recognized organization,
the City Administrator may issue, free of charge, a license containing the
information as required herein to the applicant.
122.19   USE OF PUBLIC PROPERTY PROHIBITED.
Unless otherwise identified and licensed as a participant in a City-Wide or
Special Event, any person engaging in peddling, soliciting, or in the business
of a transient merchant in this City shall be prohibited from using any public
property for any reason whatsoever without express, written, prior permission
from the City for said use.
CHAPTER 123
PUBLIC VENDING AND VENDORS
 
123.01 Purpose                         123.04 Operational Period
123.02 Definitions                     123.05 Permitted Public Vending
123.03 Public Vending Areas Designated 123.06 Conditions and Requirements
 
123.01   PURPOSE.
This chapter establishes requirements for the public vending of foodstuffs,
goods, and merchandise, under certain circumstances, on public streets,
sidewalks, or alleys. It is the purpose of this chapter, to provide those
persons who engage in those types of vending operations with clear and concise
regulations to prevent safety, traffic, and health hazards, as well as to
preserve the peace, safety, and welfare of the community.
123.02   DEFINITIONS.
For purposes of this chapter the following terms are defined:
1.   “Public vending” means the permitted sale or offering for sale of
foodstuffs and/or other permitted goods or merchandise for immediate on-site
delivery or consumption on public property within those areas specifically
designated herein.
2.   “Vendor” means any person or entity specifically permitted to conduct
“public vending” activities by the City.
123.03   PUBLIC VENDING AREAS DESIGNATED.
Public vending will only be permitted in the public areas specifically
designated by the City. The recognized public areas are: those public
properties within the larger area bounded by the southerly street right-of-way
line of May Street, the westerly street right-of-way line of Cody Road, the
northerly street right-of-way line of Territorial Road, and the meander line of
the westerly bank of the Mississippi River and those public properties
including and adjacent to LeClaire Public Library, LeClaire City Hall, and the
City Center Plaza. The specific, fixed locations - of not more than 100 square
feet in area and not more than 10 feet in any dimension - and the number of
locations within the generally designated area above will be determined by the
City Administrator, who will first consult with the Tourism Board, Police
Chief, Fire Chief, and the Public Works Director, prior to designating a
specific vending area or areas.
123.04   OPERATIONAL PERIOD.
Public vending will be allowed only pursuant to the time frames specified
within the vendor’s permit and only between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 10:00
p.m., seven days a week. (Other hours of operation may be granted for vendors
when the products are related to a specific activity, and such other
considerations and conditions are incorporated to affect the intent of this
chapter.)
123.05   PERMITTED PUBLIC VENDING.
Fixed location, public vending (as herein specified) where the sale or offering
for sale of various foods and foodstuffs (as approved and permitted by the
County Health Department) and dry goods or merchandise (i.e., crafts,
souvenirs, etc.) are hereby permitted.
123.06   CONDITIONS AND REQUIREMENTS.
The City may issue a permit for public vending at those fixed, designated
locations after careful consideration and consultation with the parties
identified in Section
123.03 above, consideration of the applicant’s proposed business, and
assurances that the following conditions are in existence or have been or will
be met:
1.   All applications for fixed location public vending must be received at
least 30 days before the proposed start of operations unless otherwise waived
by the Council. All applications and requested locations, special conditions,
or exceptions will be approved by the Council.
2.   Fixed locations will be assigned, and permits will be issued on a first-
come, first-served basis, with consideration of existing vendors in the area.
Locations may be changed by request and/or at the discretion of the City only
upon review and consideration of the provisions as spelled out above for the
issuance of a new permit.
3.   The sale or assignment of a location and/or permit is expressly
prohibited.
4.   The applicant will operate with a minimum of equipment.
5.   The applicant’s proposed mode of operation will neither impede the free
flow of pedestrian or vehicular traffic in the designated area, nor interfere
with such pedestrian movement into or out of retail establishments and
businesses in the downtown area.
6.   The applicant will conduct vending from one site only and completely
within the boundaries described in the permit. The applicant’s permit may be
immediately revoked if business is operated at a location other than the one
specified, unless otherwise approved by the City.
7.   The applicant must obtain all necessary permits and abide by any and all
health regulations as required by the Scott County Health Department or other
agencies.
8.   A fixed, designated location must be available that will not interfere
with the operation of an existing vendor or business establishment in the
designated area.
   A.   At least 200 feet will separate vendors from existing vendors and
storefront businesses selling the same product unless the established vendors
and businesses provide written permission.
   B.   Vendors will consult with the owner or tenant of the property
immediately adjacent to the site and must secure written permission to operate
in that area. Written permission(s) must be submitted to the City for its
records.
9.   Vendors will be limited to the use of only those facilities (i.e. mobile
push carts, tents, vending trailers, etc.), that are specifically intended or
pre-manufactured for said use from which to sell their items. (Other
facilities, vehicles, trailers, materials, or items of any nature are expressly
prohibited.) The maximum exterior dimensions of the applicant’s facilities will
not exceed a size of 10 feet wide by 20 feet long by eight feet high. Signage
must be permanently attached to the facilities.
10.   Vendors will be neatly dressed at all times. No cut-offs, ragged T-
shirts, or any attire containing any reference to, or indication of drugs, sex,
or profanity of any nature will be permitted.
11.   The applicant will completely remove their facilities and any and all
associated appurtenances and refuse at the close of each business day and
storage will be at a location other than the one specified on the permit.
12.   The applicant will seek permission to conduct public vending by
submitting a letter (along with a completed application form) describing the
vending plan in detail, including a complete listing of goods to be sold, hours
of operation, and a detailed diagram or picture of their facilities.
13.   The applicant will execute and submit to the City the City’s standard
Hold-Harmless, Waiver of Liability, and Indemnification Agreement.
14.   Vendors will have five working days from the date of approval of their
permit application(s) to submit an approved certificate of insurance to the
City as required herein.
15.   The fixed location, Public Vending Permit fee shall be set by Council
resolution.
16.   The applicant shall, at their own expense, procure and maintain and
provide evidence for each permit location and for the duration of each permit,
not less than $1,000,000.00 CSL in casualty and liability insurance (including
completed products liability) in a responsible company or companies authorized
to do business in the State, as approved by the City, and that the City will be
named and shown as an “additional insured” on such policy. The applicant and
any person(s) claiming through or under the applicant and any respective
sureties, covenant and agree to defend, protect, completely indemnify, and hold
harmless the City, its agents, employees, and assigns from any and all actions,
claims demands for damages, expenses, (including attorney’s fees), or liability
of any kind or nature whatsoever, which may be occasioned by or arising out of
any accident or other occurrence causing or inflicting injury and/or damage to
any person(s) or injury and/or damage to property, in, upon, or about the
permitted property which may in any way be caused by the accidental,
intentional, or negligent action of the applicant or any person(s) claiming
through or under the applicant, or which may result there-from as a result of
the authorized use, occupancy, or tenancy of the permitted property for the
public vending.
17.   The applicant shall file, in the Office of the Clerk, a certificate of
insurance evidencing the coverage(s) as outlined above. The policy will have an
effective date of at least the day the permit is effective and shall provide 30
days’ notice to the City of cancellation or change in policy amounts or types.
Cancellation or a decrease in the amounts or types of coverage is sufficient
grounds for immediate revocation of the permit without hearing or other due
process.
18.   The City shall not be liable to the applicant for any business
interruption, or any loss or damage to property, or injury to or death of
persons, occurring or in any manner growing out of or connected with
applicant’s operation, whether or not caused by the alleged negligence or other
fault of the City or by any of the City’s agents, employees, invitees,
licensees, or assignees.
19.   The applicant is responsible for maintaining the area within and in
proximity to their location in a clean and hazard-free condition at all times.
No food preparation by-products (i.e., grease, oil, liquids, or materials of
any nature, smoke, noxious fumes, etc.) shall emanate from the facilities nor
be allowed to come in contact with any public property at any time. Sufficient,
supplementary waste receptacles must be provided at all times during the
applicant’s operations. The exterior of all facilities must be maintained in
good condition by the applicant. Facilities may be temporarily anchored or held
in place only through the use of weighted items (water barrels/jugs, sandbags,
etc.) and no anchor drilling or staking on public property will be permitted.
20.   Vendors shall abide by all regulations of this chapter and further agree
to relocate, at the discretion of the City, during festivals and at other times
should conditions warrant. Also, the vendor may be required to discontinue
their operation in order to accommodate and eliminate conflicts with “special
events or City-wide events.”
21.   Failure to comply with any of the requirements of this chapter shall
result in the immediate revocation of the vendor’s permit to operate and cause
the immediate removal of the facilities and any and all associated
appurtenances and refuse.
22.   Request for exceptions to the provisions of this chapter must be
submitted to the City Administrator in writing and will only be reviewed and
considered on a case-by-case basis by the Council.
23.   Any vendor, not holding an annual vendor’s permit as mentioned above and
not classified as a “local civic organization,” who is interested in selling
during festivals or special events must comply with all sections of this
chapter.
24.   City-wide and Special Events. A recognized “Local Civic Organization”
conducting a special event may file with the City the specified certificates of
insurance and the indemnification waiver form covering any and all vendors
participating in that organization’s event in lieu of those provisions
contained in Subsections 13 through 17 above pertaining to individual vendor
insurance and indemnification requirements. Applicants participating in a City-
wide or special events may also be exempted from the provisions of Subsections
9 (facility limits) and 15 (permit fees) above if waived by the City Council.
All other provisions of this Code not expressly waived either herein or by
action of the City Council will apply.
25.   “Local businesses” defined as those recognized commercial businesses
owning, renting, leasing, or otherwise regularly occupying and operating a
commercial business from a permanent, fixed, commercially zoned structure
within the City, which only exhibit, offer, or sell products from their
respective businesses, may provide public vending under the following
circumstances:
   A.   The local business may exhibit, offer, or sell those products from
specifically designated public vending locations outside of and immediately
adjacent to the commercial premises, providing that the appropriate ADA
clearances and access-ways are maintained at all times.
   B.   The local business may apply for a Public Vending Permit for a private
or public parking location immediately adjacent to their premises. The
specified business location may be filled with any single vendor provided that
each vendor has met all of the requirements above except that the local
business may pay a one-time blanket permit fee, as set by Council resolution,
to cover the vendors at this location.
   C.   All other provisions and requirements not expressly waived either
herein or by action of the City Council will apply.
   D.   This section DOES NOT apply to, nor is it to be construed to afford
relief to, those vendors or local businesses hired by, contracted with,
organized under, or in any way offered to participate in any festival or City-
wide or special event.
CHAPTER 124
MOVING BUILDINGS
124.01 Permit Required                    124.12 Control and Supervision
124.02 Application for Permit             124.13 Notice Required
124.03 Investigation                      124.14 Default in Performance of
                                          Conditions
124.04 Issuance of Permit                 124.15 Approval of Route
124.05 Denial of Permit                   124.16 Obstructing Streets
124.06 Terms and Conditions of Permit     124.17 Lights and Barricades
124.07 Public Property Damage and Deposit 124.18 Wires and Structural Supports
124.08 Certificate of Liability Insurance 124.19 Trees, Plants, and Shrubs
124.09 Owner’s Completion Bond or Deposi124.20 Repairs of Public Property
124.10 Clearance of Site and Safety       124.21 Refunding of Deposits
Measures Required
124.11 Suspension or Revocation of Permit
 
124.01   PERMIT REQUIRED.
It is unlawful for any person to move or cause to be moved any building in,
into, through, or from the City without first obtaining a permit therefore.
Such permit shall be known as a “House Moving Permit.”
124.02   APPLICATION FOR PERMIT.
Any person desiring such a permit shall file an application therefore in
writing on a form to be furnished by the City for that purpose. Such
application shall specify the following:
1.   The character and size of the building to be moved.
2.   The reason for such moving.
3.   The use, purpose, and occupancy for which said building or structure is to
be used.
4.   The location from which, and to which, said building is to be moved.
5.   A plot plan showing the proposed location of the building upon the
property to which said building is to be moved, provided said location is in
the City.
6.   The streets on, over, or through which it is desired to move said
building.
7.   Whether the building conforms to the zoning laws in the location to which
it is to be moved.
124.03   INVESTIGATION.
Upon the filing of the application, the Building Inspector and/or Building and
Zoning Enforcement Officer will investigate the building and record the results
of such investigation, together with recommended action thereon. 
124.04   ISSUANCE OF PERMIT.
The City may approve the issuance of a House Moving Permit when all the
necessary requirements and conditions of this chapter have been complied with.
A permit fee in the sum set by Council resolution shall be paid to the City
upon the issuance of each house moving permit.
124.05   DENIAL OF PERMIT.
No permit shall be issued to move any building or structure which, in the
opinion of the Building Inspector and/or Building and Zoning Enforcement
Officer:
1.   Is so constructed or in such condition as to be dangerous.
2.   Is infested with pests or is unsanitary.
3.   If it is a dwelling or habitation, is unfit for human habitation.
4.   Is so dilapidated, defective, unsightly, or in such a condition of
deterioration, disrepair, or infestation that its relocation at the proposed
site within the City would cause appreciable harm to or be materially
detrimental to the property or improvements in the district within a radius of
600 feet from the proposed site.
5.   If the proposed use is prohibited by the zoning laws of the City.
6.   If the structure is of a type prohibited at the proposed location by any
ordinance of the City; or
7.   If the moving of the building or structure causes unreasonable damage to
the trees, plants, and shrubs on and along the public streets.
Provided, however, if the condition of the building or structure, in the
judgment of the Building Inspector and/or Building and Zoning Enforcement
Officer, admits of practicable and effective repair, the permit may be issued
upon the terms and conditions as set forth herein.
124.06   TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF PERMIT.
When a House Moving Permit is granted, such terms and conditions as may be
deemed reasonable and proper may be imposed, including, but not limited to,
conditions involving the public streets or other public property in the City
on, over, or through which the building or structure shall be moved and the
requirements of changes, alterations, additions, or repairs to be made to or
upon the building or structure, or land, to the end that the relocation thereof
will not be materially detrimental or injurious to public safety or to public
welfare or to the property and improvements, or either, in the district to
which it is to be moved. Such terms and conditions shall be written upon the
permit or appended in writing thereto.
124.07   PUBLIC PROPERTY DAMAGE AND DEPOSIT.
The applicant shall deposit with the City a cash deposit in the amount of
$5,000.00 to cover any damages to public property that may be caused by said
action.
124.08   CERTIFICATE OF LIABILITY INSURANCE.
Every person moving a building in the City shall file with the City a
certificate of liability insurance issued by a solvent corporation holding a
certificate of authority to do insurance business in the State, which
certificate shall conform in all respects to the requirements of this section.
The certificate of liability insurance required under this section shall insure
the person moving a building against loss from the liability imposed by law for
injury to or death of any person, or damage to any property growing out of the
moving of such building, to the amount or limit of $500,000.00 exclusive of
interest and costs, on account of injury to or death of any one person, and
subject to the same limit as respects injury to or death of one person, of
$500,000.00 exclusive of interest and costs, on account of moving any one
building resulting in injury to or death of more than one person, and of
$500,000.00 for damage to property of others, resulting from moving any one
building and shall list the City as an additional insured.
124.09   OWNER’S COMPLETION BOND OR DEPOSIT.
Prior to the issuance of a permit to move a building, the owner or lessee of
the property upon which the building is to be located shall file with the City
a State corporate surety bond, conditioned as follows: that all of the work
required to be done to complete the relocation, alteration, and reconstruction
of the building pursuant to the conditions of the said permit shall be fully
performed and completed within a reasonable time to be specified by the City in
the permit. Such bond shall be in principal amount equal to the estimated cost
of the work proposed to be done plus 10 percent thereof, and shall name the
City as thereof, and shall be in a form approved by the City Administrator. In
lieu of furnishing such a corporate surety bond, the owner or lessee may post
an additional cash deposit in the amount of said bond. An extension of time for
said completion may be granted in writing by the City when circumstances shall
so justify, but no such extension shall release any surety or other security.
124.10   CLEARANCE OF SITE AND SAFETY MEASURES REQUIRED.
Prior to and during the process of moving a building, the owner shall perform
the following, if applicable:
1.   Before any work is started on a building or structure, the permittee or
authorized agent shall notify the appropriate utilities in order that all gas,
water, and sewer pipelines that are to be disconnected from the building may be
securely capped and sealed.
2.   Immediately after the moving of any building or structure, the permittee
or authorized agent shall securely barricade all basement excavations and other
holes or openings.
3.   Within 10 days after the moving of any building or structure, the
permittee or authorized agent shall complete the following work:
   A.   Securely close and seal any sanitary piping located on the property.
   B.   Fill with dirt or sand any septic tank or cesspools located on the
property.
   C.   Fill any openings, excavations, or basements remaining on the land with
dirt or sand to street level or the natural level of adjoining property, unless
otherwise directed by the Director of Public Works.
   D.   Remove any buried underground tanks formerly used for storage of
flammable liquids.
   E.   Remove all refuse, debris, and waste materials from the property.
124.11   SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF PERMIT.
The City, at any time for sufficient cause, may revoke or suspend any permit
granted under this chapter.
124.12   CONTROL AND SUPERVISION.
Every building which is moved on, over, or through the public street, way, or
park in the City shall be under the control of the City and every such building
shall be moved in a careful manner and the work shall be prosecuted with
diligence and to the satisfaction and approval of the City. This section in no
way relieves the person having charge of the moving of any building of the
obligation to furnish proper supervision.
124.13   NOTICE REQUIRED.
Notice must be given by the person to whom the permit is issued or by an
authorized representative, to the City not less than 36 hours or more than 48
hours before the actual work of moving a building or structure is to commence.
124.14   DEFAULT IN PERFORMANCE OF CONDITIONS.
Whenever a default has occurred in the performance of any term or condition of
any permit, written notice thereof shall be given to the permittee by the City,
said notice to state the work to be done, the estimated cost thereof, and the
period of time deemed to be reasonably necessary to complete such work. After
receipt of such notice, the permittee must, within the time therein specified,
either cause the work to be done or forfeit to the City the completion bond or
cash deposit as required herein. If the permittee defaults, the City shall have
the option, in lieu of completing the work required, to demolish the building
or structure and to clear, clean, and restore the site or sites.
124.15   APPROVAL OF ROUTE.
The streets over which any building or structure is to be moved must be
approved by the City.
124.16   OBSTRUCTING STREETS.
No person owning or having charge of the moving of any building into, on, over,
through, or from any public streets, ways, or parks in the City shall permit
said building to remain in any one location of any such street, way, or park
for a period longer than 24 hours except by written permission obtained from
the Police Chief, or to obstruct traffic on any railroad.
124.17   LIGHTS AND BARRICADES.
The person having charge of the moving of any structure shall maintain proper
lights and barricades whenever such structure is on any public street, way, or
park during the hours of darkness.
124.18   WIRES AND STRUCTURAL SUPPORTS.
In the event that the moving of any building for which a permit has been
granted hereunder makes it necessary to move, remove, or displace any pole or
other structure supporting the wires, cables or other equipment of any public
utility or of the City or to cut, displace, or change the location of any wire,
cable, or other equipment upon said pole or structure, the person to whom such
permit has been granted or an authorized representative shall obtain permission
in writing from the owner or owners of such pole, structure, or the wires,
cables, or other equipment thereon, and shall notify the owner or owners at
least 48 hours prior to the time that the moving of such building will
necessitate the removal of such obstructions. The person to whom said permit is
granted shall not, at the expiration of said time of notice or at any time,
cut, move, or in any way disturb such public utility or City property; and such
work shall be done daily by the authorized workers of the utility or the City,
whichever is the owner. The person to whom said permit is granted shall pay to
said public utility or to the City, as the case may be, any and all costs or
expense for the removal, rearrangement, or replacement of any pole or
structural support of wires, cables, or equipment thereon or of any damage to
such property.
124.19   TREES, PLANTS, AND SHRUBS.
In the event that the moving of any building for which a permit shall have been
granted hereunder makes it necessary to trim, move, remove or replant any tree,
plant, or shrub belonging to or under the control of the City, the person to
whom such permit has been granted or an authorized representative shall notify
the City at least 48 hours prior to that time that the moving of such building
will necessitate the removal of such obstructions. The person to whom said
permit is granted shall not, at the expiration of said time of notice or at any
time, trim, move, remove, replant, or otherwise disturb such trees, plants, or
shrubs; and such work shall be done only by the authorized workers of the City
unless otherwise approved and so ordered by the City. The person to whom said
permit is granted shall pay to said City any and all costs or expense for the
trimming, moving, removing, or replanting of any trees, plants or shrubs, or of
any damage thereto.
124.20   REPAIRS OF PUBLIC PROPERTY.
In the event that the moving of any building for which a permit has been
granted hereunder causes damage to the public streets or other public property,
in addition to any other remedies the City may have, the City may cause such
damage to be repaired and the cost thereof shall be deducted from the deposit
required herein, or the City may require the person to whom such a permit has
been granted, and to whom said notice has been given, or an authorized
representative to effect such repairs. If such person fails to make necessary
repairs within the period of time designated in said written notice, the City
may cause such necessary repairs to be made and the cost thereof deducted from
the deposit required therein.
124.21   REFUNDING OF DEPOSITS.
When the moving of any building for which a permit has been granted is
completed, and all damage to public streets or other public property has been
repaired to the satisfaction of the City, and all costs of repairing damage or
performing other work, as provided herein, have been paid, the deposit, as
required by Section
124.06 hereof, or such portion thereof then remaining unused under the
provisions of this chapter shall be refunded upon surrender of the deposit
receipt representing the said money so deposited. Should the cost, however, of
repairing damages and/or performing other work as in this chapter provided,
exceed the total amount of money deposited, the person to whom said permit was
granted shall be held liable for the amount of damage and/or other costs which
are in excess of the amount deposited, and the City shall collect such part of
the claim which is in excess of the deposit from the person to whom the permit
was granted.
CHAPTER 125
WRECKING BUILDINGS
 
125.01 Permit Required                   125.06 Approval and Issuance of Permit
125.02 Application for Permit            125.07 Permit Fees
125.03 Deposit                           125.08 Regulations for Proceeding with
                                         Work
125.04 Certificate of Insurance and Hold 125.09 Supervision
Harmless Waiver
125.05 Inspection of Premises
 
125.01   PERMIT REQUIRED.
It is unlawful to wreck or demolish any building or structure in the City
without first securing a permit therefore. Any building or structure means any
building or accessory building that includes any vertical structure surrounding
greater than 50 percent of the building footprint, includes removing any water,
sewer, electrical, gas, or other utility connection, or is within 10 feet of
another building or accessory building.
125.02   APPLICATION FOR PERMIT.
An application for a permit to wreck or demolish any building or structure in
the City shall be made in writing to the City. Such application shall give the
location of the building or structure, the date when wrecking or demolition is
to commence, and the approximate time which such wrecking or demolition shall
take place.
125.03   DEPOSIT.
Before a permit is issued, the permittee or applicant shall deposit with the
City the following sums (in the form of cash, money order, or a cashier’s
check) to ensure that the property is in a proper and safe condition after such
wrecking or demolition.
For buildings not exceeding 10,000 cubic feet   $5,000.00
For buildings not exceeding 25,000 cubic feet   $6,000.00
For buildings not exceeding 30,000 cubic feet   $7,000.00
For buildings not exceeding 40,000 cubic feet   $8,000.00
For buildings not exceeding 50,000 cubic feet   $9,000.00
Plus, an additional $1,000.00 for each additional 10,000 feet or fractional
portion thereof. By “proper and safe condition” it is meant that all debris is
cleared away and that any excavation remaining is filled in, compacted, and
seeded over. If the Building Inspector and/or Building and Zoning Enforcement
Officer finds that such property has been put into the proper condition as
provided for in this section, the City shall return the deposit. If the site is
not cleared of any and all debris and any excess fill, or work is not commenced
to do so within 10 days of the finish of the wrecking or demolition, the City
shall proceed with the work and the cost of such work shall be deducted from
the deposit. If any amount is left from such deposit after the City has
performed the work, such balance shall be returned to the person who deposited
it. If said deposit is not sufficient to cover the cost of such work, the City
may assess the property to recover any amount due and outstanding.
125.04   CERTIFICATE OF INSURANCE AND HOLD HARMLESS WAIVER.
A certificate of insurance showing that public liability insurance in an amount
not less than $500,000.00 has been obtained by the applicant shall accompany
any such application along with a signed original of the City’s standard Hold
Harmless and Waiver of Liability.
125.05   INSPECTION OF PREMISES.
Before any such permit shall be approved, the Building Inspector and/or
Building and Zoning Enforcement Officer shall inspect the premises where the
wrecking and demolition work is to take place and ascertain that provision for
proper care has been made so as not to endanger any sewer or water connections
with the City sewer and water systems, or any electrical wires or
installations.
125.06   APPROVAL AND ISSUANCE OF PERMIT.
If the Building Inspector and/or Building and Zoning Enforcement Officer finds
that the terms of this chapter are being complied with by the applicant, such
officer shall issue a permit for such wrecking or demolition.
125.07   PERMIT FEES.
The Council shall establish by resolution, the permit fees and other costs
associated with any provision of this chapter as referenced herein.
125.08   REGULATIONS FOR PROCEEDING WITH WORK.
All wrecking or demolition shall be performed in a workmanlike manner and with
the least amount of noise possible. Care shall be taken to protect neighboring
structures with adequate shoring and whatever else is needful to protect such
structures. Adequate protection shall be provided to prevent injury to any City
or public utility appurtenances. It shall be the duty of all persons working on
or responsible for such wrecking or demolition to see to it that the general
public is warned to keep away from such premises, and is not permitted to enter
in or on or frequent such structures.
125.09   SUPERVISION.
The Building Inspector and/or Building and Zoning Enforcement Officer shall
supervise such wrecking or demolition and shall inspect such premises at least
once daily during such wrecking or demolition.
CHAPTER 135
STREET USE AND MAINTENANCE

135.06 Use for Business Purposes  135.13 Driveway Culverts
135.07 Washing Vehicles
 
135.01   REMOVAL OF WARNING DEVICES.
It is unlawful for a person to willfully remove, throw down, destroy, or carry
away from any street or alley any lamp, obstruction, guard, or other article or
things, or extinguish any lamp or other light, erected, or placed thereupon for
the purpose of guarding or enclosing unsafe or dangerous places in said street
or alley without the consent of the person in control thereof.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 716.1)
135.02   OBSTRUCTING OR DEFACING.
It is unlawful for any person to obstruct, deface or injure any street or alley
in any manner.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 716.1)
135.03   PLACING DEBRIS ON.
It is unlawful for any person to throw or deposit on any street or alley any
glass, glass bottle, nails, tacks, wire, cans, trash, garbage, rubbish, litter,
offal, leaves, grass, or any other debris likely to be washed into the storm
sewer and clog the storm sewer, or any substance likely to injure any person,
animal, or vehicle.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.369)
135.04   PLAYING IN.
It is unlawful for any person to coast, sled, or play games on streets or
alleys, except in the areas blocked off by the City for such purposes.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[2])
135.05   TRAVELING ON BARRICADED STREET OR ALLEY.
It is unlawful for any person to travel or operate any vehicle on any street or
alley temporarily closed by barricades, lights, signs, or flares placed thereon
by the authority or permission of any City official, police officer, or member
of the Fire Department.
135.06   USE FOR BUSINESS PURPOSES.
It is unlawful to park, store, or place, temporarily or permanently, any
machinery or junk or any other goods, wares, and merchandise of any kind upon
any street or alley for the purpose of storage, exhibition, sale, or offering
same for sale, without permission of the City.
135.07   WASHING VEHICLES.
It is unlawful for any person to use any public sidewalk, street, or alley for
the purpose of washing or cleaning any automobile, truck equipment, or any
vehicle of any kind when such work is done for hire or as a business. This does
not prevent any person from washing or cleaning his or her own vehicle or
equipment when it is lawfully parked in the street or alley.
135.08   BURNING PROHIBITED.
No person shall burn any trash, leaves, rubbish, or other combustible material
in any curb and gutter or on any paved or surfaced street or alley.
135.09   EXCAVATIONS.
Excavations of streets, parking, and alleys shall be done in accordance with
the provisions of
Chapter 141 of this code.
135.10   PROPERTY OWNER’S RESPONSIBILITY FOR MAINTENANCE.
The abutting property owner shall maintain all property outside the lot and
property lines and inside the curb lines upon public streets and shall keep
such area in a safe condition, free from nuisances, obstructions, and hazards.
In the absence of a curb, such property shall extend from the property line to
that portion of the public street used or improved for vehicular purposes. The
abutting property owner shall not be required to remove diseased trees or dead
wood on the publicly owned property or right-of-way. Maintenance includes, but
is not limited to, timely mowing, trimming trees and shrubs, and picking up
litter and debris. The abutting property owner may be liable for damages caused
by failure to maintain the publicly owned property or right-of-way.† 10
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[2c])
 
Notes
10 † EDITOR’S NOTE: See also Section 136.03 relating to property owner’s
   responsibility for maintenance of sidewalks.
135.11   FAILURE TO MAINTAIN.
If the abutting property owner does not perform an action required under the
above section within a reasonable time, the City may perform the required
action and assess the cost against the abutting property for collection in the
same manner as a property tax.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[2e])
135.12   DUMPING OF SNOW.
It is unlawful for any person to throw, push, or place or cause to be thrown,
pushed or placed, any ice or snow from private property, sidewalks, or
driveways onto the traveled way of a street or alley so as to obstruct gutters,
or impede the passage of vehicles upon the street or alley or to create a
hazardous condition therein; except where, in the cleaning of large commercial
drives in the Business District it is absolutely necessary to move the snow
onto the street or alley temporarily, such accumulation shall be removed
promptly by the property owner or agent. Arrangements for the prompt removal of
such accumulations shall be made prior to moving the snow.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[2])
135.13   DRIVEWAY CULVERTS.
The property owner shall, at the owner’s expense, install any culvert deemed
necessary under any driveway or any other access to the owner’s property, and
before installing a culvert, permission must first be obtained from the City.
In the event repairs are needed at any time with respect to culverts, it shall
be the responsibility of the property owner to make such repairs, and, in the
event the owner fails to do so, the City shall have the right to make the
repairs. If the property owner fails to reimburse the City for the cost of said
repairs, the cost shall be certified to the County Treasurer and specially
assessed against the property as by law provided.
CHAPTER 136
SIDEWALK REGULATIONS
136.01 Purpose                               136.11 Awnings
136.02 Removal of Snow, Ice, and             136.12 Encroaching Steps
Accumulations
136.03 Property Owner’s Responsibility for 136.13 Openings and Enclosures
Maintenance
136.04 City May Order Repairs                136.14 Fires or Fuel on Sidewalks
136.05 Sidewalk Construction Ordered         136.15 Defacing
136.06 Permit Required                       136.16 Debris on Sidewalks
136.07 Sidewalk Standards                    136.17 Merchandise Display
136.08 Barricades and Warning Lights         136.18 Sales Stands
                                             136.19 Objects Obstructing
136.09 Failure to Repair or Barricade        Pedestrian Use of Sidewalks
                                             Prohibited
136.10 Interference with Sidewalk
Improvements
 
136.01   PURPOSE.
The purpose of this chapter is to enhance safe passage by citizens on
sidewalks, to place the responsibility for the maintenance, repair,
replacement, or reconstruction of sidewalks upon the abutting property owner
and to minimize the liability of the City.
136.02   REMOVAL OF SNOW, ICE, AND ACCUMULATIONS.
It shall be the responsibility of the abutting property owners to remove snow,
ice, and accumulations promptly from sidewalks.
136.03   PROPERTY OWNER’S RESPONSIBILITY FOR MAINTENANCE.
The abutting property owner shall maintain in a safe and hazard-free condition
any sidewalk outside the lot and property lines and inside the curb lines or,
in the absence of a curb, any sidewalk between the property line and that
portion of the public street used or improved for vehicular purposes. The
abutting property owner may be liable for damages caused by failure to maintain
the sidewalk.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[2c])
136.04   CITY MAY ORDER REPAIRS.
If the abutting property owner does not maintain sidewalks as required, the
Council may serve notice on such owner, by certified mail, requiring the owner
to repair, replace or reconstruct sidewalks within a reasonable time and if
such action is not completed within the time stated in the notice, the Council
may require the work to be done and assess the costs against the abutting
property for collection in the same manner as a property tax.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[2d and e])
136.05   SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION ORDERED.
The Council may order the construction of permanent sidewalks upon any street
or court in the City and may specially assess the cost of such improvement to
abutting property owners in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 384 of
the Code of Iowa.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 384.38)
136.06   PERMIT REQUIRED.
No person shall remove, reconstruct, or install a sidewalk unless such person
has obtained a permit from the City and has agreed in writing that said
removal, reconstruction, or installation will comply with all ordinances and
requirements of the City for such work. A written application for such permit
shall be filed with the City and shall be accompanied by a permit fee as set by
Council resolution.
136.07   SIDEWALK STANDARDS.
(See
Chapter 163 – Standard Public Works Improvements Specifications.)
136.08   BARRICADES AND WARNING LIGHTS.
Whenever any material of any kind is deposited on any street, avenue, highway,
passageway or alley when sidewalk improvements are being made or when any
sidewalk is in a dangerous condition, it shall be the duty of all persons
having an interest therein, either as the contractor or the owner, agent, or
lessee of the property in front of or along which such material may be
deposited, or such dangerous condition exists, to put in conspicuous places at
each end of such sidewalk and at each end of any pile of material deposited in
the street, a sufficient number of approved warning lights or flares, and to
keep them lighted during the entire night and to erect sufficient barricades
both at night and in the daytime to secure the same. The party or parties using
the street for any of the purposes specified in this chapter shall be liable
for all injuries or damage to persons or property arising from any wrongful act
or negligence of the party or parties, or their agents or employees or for any
misuse of the privileges conferred by this chapter or of any failure to comply
with provisions hereof.
136.09   FAILURE TO REPAIR OR BARRICADE.
It is the duty of the owner of the property abutting the sidewalk, or the
owner’s contractor or agent, to notify the City immediately in the event of
failure or inability to make necessary sidewalk improvements or to install or
erect necessary barricades as required by this chapter.
136.10   INTERFERENCE WITH SIDEWALK IMPROVEMENTS.
No person shall knowingly or willfully drive any vehicle upon any portion of
any sidewalk or approach thereto while in the process of being improved or upon
any portion of any completed sidewalk or approach thereto, or shall remove or
destroy any part or all of any sidewalk or approach thereto, or shall remove,
destroy, mar, or deface any sidewalk at any time or destroy, mar, remove, or
deface any notice provided by this chapter.
136.11   AWNINGS.
It is unlawful for a person to erect or maintain any awning over any sidewalk
unless all parts of the awning are elevated at least eight feet above the
surface of the sidewalk and the roof or covering is made of duck, canvas or
other suitable material supported by iron frames or brackets securely fastened
to the building, without any posts or other device that will obstruct the
sidewalk or hinder or interfere with the free passage of pedestrians.
136.12   ENCROACHING STEPS.
It is unlawful for a person to erect or maintain any stairs or steps to any
building upon any part of any sidewalk without permission by resolution of the
Council.
136.13   OPENINGS AND ENCLOSURES.
It is unlawful for a person to:
1.   Stairs and Railings. Construct or build a stairway or passageway to any
cellar or basement by occupying any part of the sidewalk, or to enclose any
portion of a sidewalk with a railing without permission by resolution of the
Council.
2.   Openings. Keep open any cellar door, grating, or cover to any vault on any
sidewalk except while in actual use with adequate guards to protect the public.
3.   Protect Openings. Neglect to properly protect or barricade all openings on
or within six feet of any sidewalk.
136.14   FIRES OR FUEL ON SIDEWALKS.
It is unlawful for a person to make a fire of any kind on any sidewalk or to
place or allow any fuel to remain upon any sidewalk.
136.15   DEFACING.
It is unlawful for a person to scatter or place any paste, paint, or writing on
any sidewalk.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 716.1)
136.16   DEBRIS ON SIDEWALKS.
It is unlawful for a person to throw or deposit on any sidewalk any glass,
nails, glass bottle, tacks, wire, cans, trash, garbage, rubbish, litter, offal,
or any other debris, or any substance likely to injure any person, animal, or
vehicle.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[2])
136.17   MERCHANDISE DISPLAY.
It is unlawful for a person to place upon or above any sidewalk, any goods or
merchandise for sale or for display in such a manner as to interfere with the
free and uninterrupted passage of pedestrians on the sidewalk; in no case shall
more than three feet of the sidewalk next to the building be occupied for such
purposes.
136.18   SALES STANDS.
It is unlawful for a person to erect or keep any vending machine or stand for
the sale of fruit, vegetables or other substances or commodities on any
sidewalk without first obtaining a written permit from the Council.
136.19   OBJECTS OBSTRUCTING PEDESTRIAN USE OF SIDEWALKS PROHIBITED.
Except for objects placed by the City or as otherwise allowed by this chapter,
it is unlawful for any person, persons, firm, company, or corporation to place
any stick, pole, post, stone, box, or any other article of whatsoever kind of
character, upon or across any of the sidewalks of the City in such a manner as
to obstruct the free and unobstructed use of the sidewalks for pedestrians
traveling or desiring to travel the same.
CHAPTER 137
VACATION AND DISPOSAL OF PUBLIC RIGHT-OF-WAYS
 
137.01 Power to Vacate                137.04 Findings Required
137.02 Planning and Zoning Commission 137.05 Disposal of Streets or Alleys
137.03 Notice of Vacation Hearing     137.06 Disposal by Gift Limited
 
137.01   POWER TO VACATE.
When, in the judgment of the Council, it would be in the best interest of the
City to vacate a street, alley, portion thereof, or any public grounds, the
Council may do so by ordinance in accordance with the provisions of this
chapter.
137.02   PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION.
Any request to vacate a street or alley shall be in writing and submitted to
the office of the City Administrator who shall refer the matter to the Planning
and Zoning Commission for study and a recommendation prior to further
consideration by the City Council. The Planning and Zoning Commission shall,
after due notification and hearing thereon, submit a written report, including
recommendations in general and specific recommendations pertaining to easements
over that right-of-way when it deems it necessary to accommodate the needs of
any and all adjoining private properties so that those adjoining private
properties will have free and unencumbered access to and/or across the vacated
right-of-way for any and all purposes, to the City Council within 30 days of
the request for vacation was referred to it.
137.03   NOTICE OF VACATION HEARING.
The Planning and Zoning Commission and the City Council shall each cause to be
published a notice of public hearing at which time said request for vacation is
to be considered. In addition to the above, written notice shall be delivered
by certified mail to each property owner of record who owns property within 200
feet of any boundary of the proposed vacation area. Said notice shall be
delivered no less than seven clear days prior to the date set for the public
hearing.
137.04   FINDINGS REQUIRED.
No street or alley, or portion thereof, shall be vacated unless the City
Council finds that:
1.   Public Use. The street or alley proposed to be vacated is not needed for
the use of the public and, therefore, its maintenance at public expense is no
longer justified.
2.   Abutting Property. The proposed vacation will not deny owners of property
abutting on the street or alley reasonable access to their property.
137.05   DISPOSAL OF STREETS OR ALLEYS.
When, in the judgment of the City Council, it would be in the best interest of
the City to dispose of a vacated street or alley, or portion thereof, they may
do so by resolution following notice and hearing as set out above in Section
137.03 and only after or in conjunction with the recording of the associated
vacation instrument. When disposing of any vacated public right-of-way, the
City Council shall consider easements over that right-of-way when it deems it
necessary to accommodate the needs of any and all adjoining private properties
so that those adjoining private properties will have free and unencumbered
access to and/or across the vacated right-of-way for any and all purposes.
137.06   DISPOSAL BY GIFT LIMITED.
The City may not dispose of a vacated street or alley right-of-way, or portion
thereof, by gift, except to a governmental body for a public purpose or to a
fair. When the City Council, at their sole discretion, determines that a
vacated street or alley is to be disposed of pursuant to Section
137.05 above, the vacated property may be disposed of through either one of the
following two methods:
1.   Pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 354.23, of the Code of Iowa, (as
amended) where the vacated parcel shall first be divided into equal portions*
and disposed of and conveyed to the immediately adjoining proprietors through
the vacation instrument (ordinance or plat acceptance resolution) after payment
of an application and processing fee as set by Council resolution.
*(In lieu of dividing the parcel into equal portions, the City may dispose of
the vacated parcel in whatever portions are agreed upon in advance, in writing,
between the immediately adjoining proprietors).
2.   Through a publicly noticed, sealed-bid process wherein the minimum,
acceptable bids will be determined as follows:
   A.   Where the vacated property is of such a size or configuration to render
it “unbuildable” per those requirements as established in the Zoning
Regulations Chapter, and/or the property is 600 square feet or less in total
area, the minimum acceptable bid will be established on a square foot basis
where the square foot value shall be determined by the Council.
   B.   Where the vacated property is of such a size or configuration so that
it could be rendered “buildable” per those requirements as established in the
Zoning Regulations Chapter, and/or the property is more than 600 square feet in
total area, the property will be appraised and the minimum acceptable bid will
be established on a square foot basis by dividing the appraised value by the
square footage, and then adding the City’s costs to determine the total cost.
EDITOR’S NOTE
The following ordinances, not codified herein and specifically saved from
repeal, have been adopted vacating certain streets, alleys and/or public
grounds and remain in full force and effect.
