Whenever any work is being done in violation of the provisions of this Code of
Ordinances, or in variance with the terms of any permit issued for such work,
the Building Inspector or the Building and Zoning Enforcement Officer may order
all work on the job stopped until such violation or variance is eliminated, and
any work or installation made in violation of this Code corrected. Such stop
order, if oral, shall be followed by a written stop order within 24 hours
(excluding Saturday, Sunday, or holidays). It shall be unlawful to do or
perform any work in violation of such stop order, except as may be necessary to
prevent injury or damage to persons or property. Such stop order may be revoked
by the Building Inspector, Building and Zoning Enforcement Officer, the Mayor,
Council, or City Administrator.
156.06   INTERPRETATION.
Wherever in the building regulations it is provided that anything must be done
to the approval of or subject to the direction of the Building Inspector,
Building and Zoning Enforcement Officer, or any other officer of the City, this
shall be construed to give such officer only the discretion of determining
whether the rules and standards established by ordinance have been complied
with; and no provision shall be construed as giving any officer discretionary
powers as to what such regulations or standards shall be, or power to require
conditions not prescribed by ordinance, or to enforce ordinance provisions in
an arbitrary or discriminatory manner.
156.07   CERTIFICATE OF OCCUPANCY.
No Certificate of Occupancy for any building or structure erected, altered, or
repaired after the adoption of the Building Code shall be issued unless such
building or structure was erected, altered, or repaired in compliance with the
provisions thereof.
CHAPTER 157
SWIMMING POOLS
 
157.01 Compliance Required 157.06 Fences
157.02 Private Pool        157.07 Water Supply
157.03 Location            157.08 Electrical Requirements
157.04 Permit Required     157.09 Inspection
157.05 Recirculation Pools
 
157.01   COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.
It is unlawful to construct, maintain, install, or enlarge any swimming pool in
the City except in compliance with all provisions of this chapter.
157.02   PRIVATE POOL.
The term “swimming pool” is hereby defined to mean any outdoor, man-made
receptacle, not a part of a natural water course, which has a water depth of 18
inches or more in any portion thereof, intended for swimming, bathing,
immersion, or partial immersion, or other recreational activities by human
beings, and including all appurtenant equipment a part thereof. This definition
includes “in-ground,” “above-ground,” and “on-ground” swimming pools, along
with hot tubs, spas, and “temporary, inflatable, or otherwise constructed”
swimming pools.
157.03   LOCATION.
No portion of a swimming pool outside a building shall be located at a distance
less than eight feet from any side or rear property line, or building line.
Pumps, filters, and pool water disinfection equipment installations shall be
located at a distance not less than eight feet from any side property line. No
swimming pool shall be closer than eight feet to the principal building or
accessory structure having a basement, nor closer than five feet to any
principal building or accessory structure without a basement.
157.04   PERMIT REQUIRED.
It is unlawful to proceed with the construction, installation, enlargement, or
alterations of any private residential swimming pool and appurtenances within
the City unless permits therefore have been obtained from the Building
Inspector. “Temporary, inflatable, or otherwise constructed” swimming pools and
covered hot tubs and spas are exempt from the permit requirements of this
particular section only, providing all other conditions of their use as
enumerated in this chapter are complied with.
157.05   RECIRCULATION POOLS.
All swimming pools shall be of the recirculation type in which circulation of
the water is maintained through the pool by pumps; the water drawn from the
pool being clarified and disinfected before being returned to the pool.
157.06   FENCES.
1.   Every person who owns or is in possession of any premises on which there
is situated a swimming pool with a water depth of 18 inches or more in any
portion thereof shall maintain on the lot or premises upon which such swimming
pool is situated a fence, wall, or other adequate structure completely
surrounding such pool to make the same reasonably inaccessible to all persons,
including small children. Such fence, wall, or other structure must not be less
than four feet in height above the grade with no openings large enough to admit
a child except through doors or gates as hereinafter provided. Any above-ground
pool with a solid, non-collapsible, sidewall height, including access point(s)
of not less than four feet above grade, does not require fencing pursuant to
the requirements of this section providing that any access ladders, stairs, or
other such devices are removed or gated off and locked when the pool is not in
use.
Temporary, inflatable, or otherwise constructed swimming pools and hot tubs and
spas also do not require fencing pursuant to the requirements of this section
providing that the swimming pools are drained, dismantled, and placed in
storage and the hot tubs and spas are covered immediately following each use.
For any hot tub or spa “cover” to meet the requirements and intent of this
chapter, it shall be solid in nature and shall be capable of supporting not
less than 50 pounds of weight. When such pools, hot tubs, or spas are in use,
they shall be monitored at all times by at least one adult who shall be
immediately adjacent to and physically present within not more than 25 feet of
the pool’s location. Any fence, wall, or other adequate structure required
pursuant to the requirements of this section must be constructed and completed
prior to placing any water in any swimming pool.
2.   All doors or gates in fences surrounding swimming pools shall be of such a
size as to completely fill any opening in the fence, wall, or other structure,
and shall be equipped with self-latching devices capable of keeping such gate
or door securely closed. The closing or latching devices shall be located not
less than four feet above grade or be otherwise inaccessible from the outside
to small children. In lieu of such self-closing and self-latching devices, said
doors and gates may be equipped with locks which shall be kept locked at all
times when said pool is not in actual use.
3.   The Building Inspector and/or Building and Zoning Enforcement Officer may
allow slight modifications for good cause shown in individual cases with
respect to height of the fence, wall, or other enclosing structure or the
nature or position of the latch or other locking device. The Building Inspector
may permit other protective devices or structures to be used as the degree of
protection afforded by the substitute devices or structures is not less than
the protection afforded by the fence, wall, or other enclosing structure and
the gate, door, latch, or other locking devices described herein. Upon the
application of a property owner, the Council, only, may grant extensions of
time for compliance for good cause shown in individual cases. Such extensions
of time shall not exceed 30 days at a time.
157.07   WATER SUPPLY.
No source of water other than that secured from the City waterworks
distribution system shall be used in swimming pools.
157.08   ELECTRICAL REQUIREMENTS.
All electrical installations provided for, installed, and used in conjunction
with private residential swimming pools shall be in conformance with the
ordinances regulating electrical installations. No current-carrying electrical
conductors shall cross private residential swimming pools, either overhead or
underground, or within 15 feet of such pools. All metal fences, enclosures, or
railings near or adjacent to swimming pools, which might become electrically
alive as a result of contact with broken overhead conductors or from any other
cause, shall be effectively grounded.
157.09   INSPECTION.
The Building Inspector and/or Building and Zoning Enforcement Officer shall
periodically inspect all swimming pools to determine whether or not the
provisions of the ordinances regarding health, sanitation, and safety
applicable thereto are being complied with.
CHAPTER 158
SOLAR ENERGY USES
 
158.01 Permit Required                              158.03 Right to Light
158.02 Provisions Relating to All Solar Energy Uses
 
158.01   PERMIT REQUIRED.
No person, firm, or corporation shall install, construct, or alter any device
or equipment for solar energy use without first obtaining a permit, therefore.
The application shall be on forms provided by the Building Inspector and shall
contain all information needed to show that the proposed construction or
alteration complies with all applicable provisions of this chapter.
158.02   PROVISIONS RELATING TO ALL SOLAR ENERGY USES.
All solar energy uses shall conform to the requirements of this section:
1.   No solar hot water heating system shall be placed in such a location as to
provide more shadow or less sunlight on neighboring properties than the amounts
allowed by the provisions of Section
158.03 of this chapter.
2.   Applicable requirements of the zoning ordinance shall be followed in
locating collectors.
3.   No collector shall be placed in any side yard closer, to the street line
or sidewalk, than 15 feet.
158.03   RIGHT TO LIGHT.
1.   Requirements. No person shall build any structure or plant or maintain any
tree or shrub in any residential area in the City without complying with each
of the terms of this chapter.
2.   Restriction. No person shall build any structure or plant or maintain any
tree or shrub taller than 25 feet or seven point six meters, unless the
structure, tree, or shrub comes within the exceptions set out in Subsection 4
of this section.
3.   Building Permits. No building permit shall be issued for any structure
that does not comply with the provisions of this section.
4.   Exemptions. An applicant for a building permit may obtain a permit for a
building higher than the restrictions set out in Subsection 2 of this section,
and a tree or shrub may be maintained higher than such restriction, if the
applicant can show any of the following conditions:
   A.   There is an existing principal residence building and the building’s
roof will not be shaded by the tree, shrub, or building more than one hour in
any day at any time of the year, except one hour after sunrise and one hour
before sunset.
   B.   There is a public street.
   C.   There is a lot with no principal residence building and the proposed
building, or the tree or shrub, will not shade any part of the lot on which
building is permitted by law and by applicable restrictions on the real estate,
at a height of 18 feet or five point five meters, for more than one hour in any
day at any time of the year, except one hour after sunrise and one hour before
sunset.
   D.   The adjacent lot is zoned for commercial purposes and is not in use as
a residence.
5.   New Subdivisions. New subdivisions may be designed with innovative ways of
preventing shading of residential buildings. Any design will be deemed to
comply with the requirements of this section if that design results in no roof
of any residence building being shaded for more than one hour in any day at any
time of the year, except one hour after sunrise and one hour before sunset.
6.   Existing Buildings. Nothing in this section shall be deemed to require the
demolition or alteration of any existing building.
CHAPTER 159
FIRE SUPPRESSION APPLIANCES
 
159.01 Sprinkler and Standpipe Systems 159.02 Fire Hydrants
 
159.01   SPRINKLER AND STANDPIPE SYSTEMS.
Sprinkler and standpipe systems will be installed in accordance with the
provisions of the various building and fire codes covering these appliances.
The Building Inspector and the Fire Chief will determine the need for and
monitor and approve the installation of these appliances.
159.02   FIRE HYDRANTS.
1.   All fire hydrants erected within the public right-of-way or on immediately
adjacent easements, for the purpose of extinguishing fires, are hereby declared
to be public fire hydrants. No person or persons, except members of the Fire
Department acting in an official capacity or water department personnel, or
other persons that have been specifically authorized by the City and/or
Company, and then only in the exercise of authority delegated by the City and/
or Company, shall open any of said fire hydrants, or attempt to uncover or
remove any protection from, or in any manner tamper with any of said fire
hydrants.
2.   Public fire hydrants shall be installed at such time as any public water
main is extended for a distance of 400 feet or more, or a water main is
replaced and there is no hydrant within 400 feet in either direction. There
shall be no more than 400 feet in travel distance between each public fire
hydrant.
3.   All fire hydrants erected outside of the public right-of-way or outside of
immediately adjacent easements, for the purpose of extinguishing fires, are
hereby declared to be private, on-site fire hydrants. No person or persons,
except members of the Fire Department acting in an official capacity or
designated representatives of the property owner of the property upon which the
private, on-site fire hydrants are located, shall open, or operate any of said
fire hydrants or attempt to uncover, or remove any protection from or in any
manner tamper with any fire hydrant. Private, on-site fire hydrants will not be
opened or operated for any reason by any person except for the purposes of
testing or extinguishing fires and then only at the direction of the Fire Chief
or a representative of the Company.
4.   The City may require private, on-site, fire hydrants and water mains
capable of supplying adequate/required fire flows when any portion of any
structure is more than 150 feet from a public fire hydrant on a public street
or when such conditions exist as are outlined in item Subsection 5 below. The
need for, location, material specifications, and number of private, on-site
fire hydrants will be determined by the City. In making these determinations,
such factors as the following will be considered by the City: (i) the Fire
Chief’s recommendations relative to the Fire Department’s abilities and
equipment status, (ii) the relative severity of a probable fire and the
rapidity with which it may spread, (iii) especially hazardous occupancies, or
special hazards that may exist in addition to the normal hazard of the
occupancy, (iv) the suitability for use and ease of access to public fire
hydrants, and (v) changes in use, occupancy, or configuration of a structure
where such changes cause an increase in the hazards associated with said
structure.
5.   All public fire hydrant material specifications, positioning,
construction, and maintenance will be the responsibility of the Company.
6.   The construction, maintenance, and testing of private, on-site fire
hydrants will be the responsibility of the property owner upon whose property
the fire hydrants are located.
7.   Fire hydrants shall be installed at a minimum of 18 inches from the
nominal ground level to the center of the lowest water outlet.
8.   Fire hydrants shall be positioned so the four- and one-half inch
connection is facing the street or driveway accessible to the Fire Department.
9.   No fire hydrant shall be installed on a water main less than six inches in
diameter. Water mains shall be appropriately sized and installed to provide the
required water flow for hydrant supplied by it.
10.   A four-foot clear space around the circumference of a hydrant and a clear
path of visibility from the hydrant to the road shall be maintained, except as
otherwise required or approved.
CHAPTER 160
SATELLITE OR DISH ANTENNA
 
160.01 Definition           160.04 Size and Height Limitations
160.02 General Requirements 160.05 Location on Lot
160.03 Number Allowed       160.06 Retroactivity
 
160.01   DEFINITION.
“Satellite or dish antennae” means a satellite receiver which is a concave
“dish” or antenna anchored to a foundation or structure, or which is portable,
and which is a device designed and intended to transmit or receive or intercept
microwave, television, radio, and other such signals or transmissions.
160.02   GENERAL REQUIREMENTS.
No satellite receiver exceeding three feet in diameter shall be erected or
placed on any lot within the corporate limits until a permit has been obtained
from the Building Department. Satellite antennas must be of a non-combustible
and corrosive resistant material, must be one solid color that is reasonable
and consistent with the surrounding environment, and comply with the
manufacturer’s specifications, unless they are in conflict with this Code of
Ordinances, in which case this Code will control.
160.03   NUMBER ALLOWED.
No more than one satellite antenna shall be allowed on any residentially zoned
lot. More than one antenna may be allowed for commercially or industrial-zoned
lots if zoned for that use or purpose.
160.04   SIZE AND HEIGHT LIMITATIONS.
A satellite antenna may not exceed 15 feet in diameter in any residentially
zoned area. Satellite antennas may exceed 15 feet in diameter in commercial or
industrial-zoned areas where the uses are permitted by the zoning regulations.
Ground-mounted satellite antennas may not exceed the height of the peak of the
principal structure. Roof mounted satellite antennas may not exceed 10 feet
above the roof peak and in no instance shall exceed the maximum allowable
height for the particular zoning classification.
160.05   LOCATION ON LOT.
Satellite antennas greater than 24 inches in diameter may be located only in
the rear yard of any residentially zoned lot as said yard is defined in the
zoning regulations. Satellite antennas located in any zoning district must
conform with the applicable zoning regulations in effect for that district with
regards to setbacks, etc., except as otherwise modified herein.
160.06   RETROACTIVITY.
All satellite antennas existing prior to July 7, 1986, are exempt from the
provision herein stated. Any existing satellite antennas not in conformance
with this chapter are considered “nonconforming” structures, and, as such, may
be governed by the applicable zoning regulations.
CHAPTER 161
SIGNS
161.01 Scope, Purpose, and Intent of 161.09 Signs Permitted in Residential
Control                              Districts
161.02 Conformance with Other Codes  161.10 Signs Permitted in Commercial
                                     Districts
161.03 Definitions                   161.11 Signs Permitted in Industrial
                                     Districts
161.04 General Conditions            161.12 Sign Maintenance
161.05 Prohibited Items              161.13 Nonconforming Signs
161.06 General Requirements and      161.14 Public Hearing Required
Procedures
161.07 Construction Requirements     161.15 Penalties
161.08 Specific Sign Types and
Regulations
 
161.01   SCOPE, PURPOSE, AND INTENT OF CONTROL.
There is a significant relationship between the manner in which signs are
displayed, the public health, safety, and welfare, and the value,
compatibility, and economic stability of adjoining property, its land use, and
the City. The reasonable display of signs is necessary as a service to the
people in the conduct of competitive commercial and industrial activity and to
promote freedom of expression. The regulations in this chapter establish
standards for the display of signs in direct relationship to the above-stated
purposes and directives. This chapter also covers construction and erection of
all outdoor signs of any type or nature with respect to size and safety. These
provisions shall apply to any structure arranged, intended, designed, or used
as an advertisement, announcement, or direction.
161.02   CONFORMANCE WITH OTHER CODES.
Any structure erected under the provisions of this chapter shall conform to all
other federal, State and local codes governing such items. These codes include,
but are not limited to, the following:
1.   Chapter 306B and 306C of the Code of Iowa (as amended and updated).
2.   Iowa Administrative Code Chapter 761.117 - 761.131 (as amended and
updated).
3.   Iowa Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways
(as amended and updated).
Any advertising sign falling under the jurisdiction of one or more of the
above-named codes or any others shall first comply with the applicable
provisions of said codes and secure any and all required permits and clearances
prior to application to the City for its required sign permit.
161.03   DEFINITIONS.
For purposes of this chapter, the following words and their derivations have
the meaning given herein:
1.   “Accessory sign” means any sign identifying or advertising a business,
person, activity, goods, products, or services located on the premises where
the sign is.
2.   “Adjacent area” means an area which is contiguous to and within 660 feet
of the nearest edge of the right-of-way of any interstate, freeway, or primary
highway.
3.   “Advertising sign” means any outdoor sign, display, device, figure,
painting, drawing, message, placard, poster, billboard, or any other device
designed, intended, or used to advertise or to give information in the nature
of advertising and having the capacity of being visible from the traveled
portion of any highway or street of the interstate system of the State or the
street network system of the City.
4.   “Approved combustible plastics” are those which, when tested in accordance
with ASTM Standard Method Test for Flammability of Plastics over 0.050-inch in
thickness (D635-44), burn no faster than two- and one-half inches per minute in
.060-inch thickness.
5.   “Banner” means any sign printed or displayed upon cloth or other flexible
material, with or without frames.
6.   “Beacon” means a stationary or revolving light which flashes or projects
illumination, single color or multicolored, in any manner, which is intended to
attract or divert attention, except, however, this term is not intended to
include any kind of lighting device which is required or necessary under the
safety regulations described by the Federal Aviation Agency or similar
agencies.
7.   “Billboard” means a type of sign having 72 square feet or more of display
surface which is either erected on the ground or attached to or supported by a
building or structure.
8.   “Building line” means the average distance from the street line of
existing buildings in any block where more than half the frontage has been
built upon in the past.
9.   “Bulletin board” means any sign erected by a charitable, educational, or
religious institution or public body which is erected upon the same property as
said institution for purposes of announcing events which are held on the
premises.
10.   “Church bulletin board sign" means a sign attached to the exterior of a
church, or located elsewhere on the church premises, used to indicate the
services or activities of the church, and including its name, if desired.
11.   “Commercial sign” means any flat or embossed painted and printed or
enameled display used as an advertising medium.
12.   “Controlled access highway” means any State or federal numbered highway
designated by ordinance as a controlled access highway by the Council.
13.   “Display surface area” means the net geometric area enclosed by the
display surface of the sign, including the outer extremities of all letters,
characters, delineation, trim, and border; provided, however, “display surface
area” does not include the structural supports for free-standing signs,
provided further that only one face of a double-faced sign, as defined, shall
be considered in determining the display surface area.
14.   “District” or “zoning district” means a section or sections of the City
for which the then effective Zoning Ordinance governing the use of buildings
and land are uniform for each class of use permitted therein.
15.   “Electrical sign” means a sign of any type incorporating electric
illumination of any type from within or without. A sign illuminated only by
projecting electric lighting reflectors shall not be construed as an electric
sign.
16.   “Erect” means to construct, reconstruct, build, raise, assemble, place,
affix, attach, create, paint, draw, or, in any other way, bring into being or
establish; however, it does not include any of the foregoing activities when
performed incidental to the customary maintenance of an advertising device.
17.   “Flashing sign” means an illuminated sign on which artificial or
reflected light is not maintained stationary, and constant in intensity and
color at all times when in use.
18.   “Free-standing ground sign” means a sign which is attached to or a part
of a completely self-supporting structure. The supporting structure shall be
firmly in or below the ground surface and not attached to any building or any
other structure whether portable or stationary.
19.   “Identification and informational signs” means signs used for
identification or of informational nature bearing no advertising.
20.   “Illuminated signs” means any sign which has characters, letters,
figures, designs, or outlines illuminated by electric lights or luminous tubes
as a part of the sign proper.
21.   “Joint identification sign” means a sign which serves as common or
collective identification for a group of persons or businesses operating on the
same zoning lot (e.g., shopping center, office complex, etc.). Such a sign may
name the persons or businesses included but carry no other advertising matter.
22.   “Letter sign” means letters not self-illuminated and applied individually
and directly to a building wall, a cornice, canopy, or other similar element of
a building.
23.   “Letters and decorations” means the letters, illustrations, symbols,
figures, insignia, and other devices employed to express and illustrate the
message of the sign.
24.   “Maintain” means to cause to remain in a state of good repair, but does
not include reconstruction.
25.   “Nameplate” means a plate or sign, typically made of metal, displaying
the name of someone, such as the person working in a building or the builder of
a ship.
26.   “Nonconforming sign” means a sign existing at the effective date of the
adoption of the ordinance codified in this chapter which could not be built
under the terms of this chapter.
27.   “Off-site sign” means a sign other than an on-site sign.
28.   “On-site sign” means a sign relating in its subject matter to the
premises on which it is located, or to products, accommodations, services, or
activities on the premises.
29.   “Political sign” means an outdoor sign of a temporary nature, not larger
than 32 square feet in surface area, erected for the purpose of soliciting
votes or support for or in opposition to any candidate or any political party
under whose designation any candidate is seeking nomination or election of any
public question on the ballot in an election held under the laws of this State.
30.   “Portable swinger sign and ‘A’ frame or sandwich sign” means an
advertising device in the shape of an ‘A’ or some variation thereof, which is
temporary in nature, located on the ground, easily movable, not permanently
attached thereto and which is usually two-sided.
31.   “Portable temporary attraction sign board” means a single or double
surface painted or poster panel type sign or some variation thereof, which is
temporary in nature, usually mounted on wheels, easily movable, and not
permanently attached.
32.   “Public property” includes all property owned by any governing or tax
levying body, whether or not devoted to use as streets, alleys, sidewalks,
parking lots, etc.
33.   “Real estate sign” means a temporary sign placed upon property for the
purpose of advertising to the public the sale or lease of said property.
34.   “Reconstruction” means any repair to the extent of 65 percent or more of
the fair market value of the structure, excluding buildings.
35.   “Right-of-way” means land area dedicated to public use for highways or
streets and their maintenance, and includes land acquired in fee simple or by
permanent easement for highway or street purposes, but does not include
temporary easements or rights for supplementary highway or street
appurtenances.
36.   “Roof sign” means any sign wholly erected, constructed, or maintained on
the roof structure or parapet wall of any building.
37.   “Sign” means and includes every device, frame, letter, figure, character,
mark, plane, point, design, picture, stroke, stripe, trademark, or reading
matter which is used or intended to be used to attract attention or convey
information when the same is placed out-of-doors in view of the general public.
For the purpose of determining the number of signs, a sign shall be considered
to be a single display surface or display device containing elements organized,
related, and composed to form a unit. Where matter is displayed in a random
manner without organized relationship to elements or where there is reasonable
doubt as to the relationship of elements, each element shall be considered to
be a single sign.
38.   “Sign facing” means the opaque or transparent surface or surfaces of the
sign, upon, against, or through which the message of the sign is exhibited.
39.   “Special event sign” means a temporary advertising device, not larger
than 32 square feet in area, erected for the purpose of notifying the public of
noncommercial community events including, but not limited to, fairs,
centennials, festivals, and celebrations open to the general public and
sponsored or approved by a city, county, or school district.
40.   “Structural trim” includes the molding, battens, cappings, nailing
strips, latticing, and platforms which are attached to the sign structure.
41.   “Structure” means any sign supporting devices including, but not limited
to, buildings.
42.   “Table or plaque” means a solid wall panel or ornament of nonferrous
metal with inscription integral or applied, not more than eight square feet in
area, not more than three inches thick attached directly to a building wall
(not a “commercial sign”).
43.   “Temporary sign” means a banner or other advertising device constructed
of cloth, canvas, fabric, or other light temporary material, with or without a
structural frame, intended for a limited period of display, including
decorative displays for holidays or public demonstrations.
44.   “Visible” means capable of being read or comprehended without visual aid
by a person of normal visual acuity.
161.04   GENERAL CONDITIONS.
1.   Vision clearance at street intersections and driveway intersections shall
be maintained.
2.   All advertising signs of any nature, in excess of 20 square feet, shall
display the name of the owner.
3.   Highway directional signs and markers shall be made and installed in
accordance with the specifications of the City or the State. Included shall be
signs announcing the location of or direct traffic to given locations which
include, but are not limited to, the following:
   A.   Service areas – automobile, food, lodging.
   B.   Public and quasi-public information signs.
   C.   Business and business districts.
4.   Permitted Locations:
   A.   Advertising Signs. When allowed as a permitted or special use in a
specific district.
   B.   On-Site. When necessary to a lawfully established use and permitted
within the district as an accessory use.
   C.   Special Event Signs and Devices. When allowed as a special or temporary
use.
   D.   General. The sign is erected, constructed, and displayed in conformance
with the provisions of this section and other applicable provisions of this
chapter.
161.05   PROHIBITED ITEMS.
The following are prohibited:
1.   Pendant swinging signs, where parts of such signs are free to move in the
wind. This shall not be construed to prohibit mechanically operated moving
parts or properly supported parts designed to rotate due to wind pressure.
2.   Tacking or posting signs on trees, utility-owned poles, traffic signs, or
traffic control devices.
3.   Tacking or posting printed or similar signs on fences, walls, buildings,
railings, or other structures.
4.   Attachment to fire escapes.
5.   Placement so as to obstruct or interfere with any openings legally
required for either exits or ventilation.
6.   Portable, temporary signs on public property, unless used for a “civic
purpose” as determined and authorized by the City.
7.   Flashing or revolving beacons or moving concentrated beam lighting devices
aimed below 45 degrees from the vertical.
8.   Obsolete signs that advertise an activity, business product or service
that is no longer conducted on the premises on which the sign is located.
9.   No sign shall be permitted to block any required accessway or window.
10.   No sign shall be placed onto or project over public property unless
otherwise authorized by this Code.
11.   No signs, structures, or portions thereof shall be so located as to
obstruct or prevent the operation of the Fire Department or to prevent free
passage from one part of a roof to any other part thereof.
12.   No advertising sign shall be placed closer than 100 feet from any
residential district boundary.
13.   Signs that are located so as to interfere with visibility for the safe
movement of pedestrians, bicycles, and vehicles.
14.   Highly reflective frame materials such as mirrored glass or chrome metal.
161.06   GENERAL REQUIREMENTS AND PROCEDURES.
1.   Permit Required. No person shall erect, alter, or relocate within the City
any sign or other advertising structures without first obtaining a permit and
making payment of the required fee, unless otherwise exempted herein.
2.   Plans Required. Permit applications shall be accompanied by plans and
specifications of the sign, its supporting structure, details of anchorage, and
such other detailed information as may be required by the Building and Zoning
Enforcement Officer, including a plot or site plan where necessary, in order
that such officer may determine that the installation complies fully with the
provisions of this chapter and such other ordinances and codes of the City as
are applicable.
3.   Fees Required.
   A.   The Council shall establish, by resolution, the permit fees and other
costs associated with any provision of this chapter as referenced herein.
   B.   Exception: Where the owner of the improvement is a tax-levying body, a
permit shall be obtained in the normal manner, but no fee shall be required.
4.   Permit Exemption. Exemptions shall not be construed as relieving the owner
of such signs from the responsibility of complying with applicable provisions
of this chapter. The exemptions shall apply to the requirements for a sign
permit only and no sign permit shall be required for the erection of the
following signs:
   A.   Professional Name Plates. Professional name plates erected flat on
walls of buildings and not exceeding four square feet of display surface area.
   B.   Building Construction Signs. One on-site building construction sign on
each construction site in any zoning district provided that the maximum display
surface area shall not exceed eight square feet.
   C.   Real Estate Signs. On a zoning lot in any district there may be erected
on each street frontage one unanimated, non-illuminated real estate sign not
more than 10 square feet in area.
   D.   Signs Painted on Building. Signs, including murals, painted on the
exterior surface of a building or structure.
   E.   Home Occupation Signs. Home occupation signs erected flat against the
wall of the building and not exceeding two square feet in area.
   F.   Memorial Signs. Memorial signs or tablets, names of buildings, and
dates of erection, when cut into any masonry surface or when constructed of
bronze or other noncombustible materials.
   G.   Municipal Signs. Traffic or other municipal signs, legal notices,
railroad crossing signs, and danger and such temporary emergency or non-
advertising signs.
   H.   Changeable Signs. Posting of bills on signs, repainting of signs, or
the changing of letters or numbers on signs designed for changeable lettering
or numbering which were legally erected and maintained for such purposes.
   I.   Election Campaign Signs. Political signs are permitted to be placed on
private property in any district. The owner of the property on which said sign
is placed shall be responsible for its removal. Any such sign shall not exceed
32 square feet per face.
   J.   Time and Temperature Signs. Time and temperature displays without
advertising matter, providing all clearances prescribed herein for signs
similarly located are maintained.
   K.   Banners. Banners shall be exempted when used in conjunction with public
and private events as follows:
      (1)   Election Campaigns. Election campaign banners.
      (2)   Public Events. Public event banners shall be placed no more than
two weeks before the event and removed within 48 hours following the event to
which the banner applies.
      (3)   Private Sales Events. Banners placed on private property for
advertising a special sales event. (Note: Banners bearing advertising matter
shall be considered wall or free-standing signs depending upon mounting and
shall meet all regulations pertaining thereto.)
   L.   Signs Within Buildings. All signs located within a building that are
not visible to the public outside of said building.
   M.   Signs on Glass Surfaces. Signs painted on or affixed to glass surfaces
of windows or doors on the outside surface, and pertaining to the lawful
business conducted therein, and not having any illumination.
   N.   Informational Signs. Directional, identification, and informational
signs provided that such signs are limited to wall and free-standing signs with
a maximum of four-square feet of display surface area.
   O.   Collection Boxes. Collection boxes for charitable or nonprofit
organizations containing no commercial advertising and located on private
property.
   P.   Garage Sale Signs. See Section
170.60 of the City Zoning Regulations.
   Q.   Holiday Decorations. Holiday decorations erected by and for the
promotion of any commercial enterprise. These permits will be issued by the
Building and Zoning Enforcement Officer and are to be for a period not to
exceed 60 days. No fee is required for non-illuminated decorations. The permit
fee for illuminated decorations shall be the same as electric signs each time
decorations are erected. All clearance requirements must be observed.
   R.   Temporary Signs. Portable, temporary signs used for “civic purposes.”
   S.   Historic site markers or plaques, gravestones, and address numbers.
   T.   Flags. State or federal flags; the flag of a commercial institution;
provided, no more than one flag is permitted per business premises, or one per
tenant in a multi-tenant building; and further provided, the flag does not
exceed 20 square feet in surface area and does not advertise a product.
5.   Special Permits. Special permits are required for the following (no fees
required):
   A.   Cloth signs on wood frames for advertising business sales, etc., when
securely attached to a building wall. Such signs may be displayed for a two-
week period only and shall not be rehung or repeated within three months. These
permits will be issued by the Building and Zoning Enforcement Officer.
   B.   Cloth banners over streets are required to have a permit issued by the
Building and Zoning Enforcement Officer. Available only to noncommercial
organizations, civic organizations, or for advertising a convention (civic,
political, or commercial), but not for personal advertising of political
candidates. Such banners shall be provided with holes to relieve wind pressure,
shall be securely erected in a manner that will not impose undue strain or load
on the buildings and structures to which they are attached, must not be located
on or adjacent to any overhead power or communication wire lines, and must
provide 14-foot clearance above streets. All such banners shall be removed at
the appropriate time. Such permit, when issued, shall include regulations
contained in the permit as to location of banners, length, time they are to
remain in place, and other relevant regulations.
6.   Alterations and Repairs.
   A.   Moving Signs. A sign shall not be moved from one location to another
without first securing a new permit and such sign shall be made to comply with
all provisions of this chapter.
   B.   Alterations. Alterations to existing signs shall not be made without
first securing a new permit and when such work is undertaken the entire unit
shall be made to comply with all provisions of this chapter. Nothing in this
section shall be construed as applying to the following:
      (1)   Changing the advertising copy on a sign designed with changeable
copy panels.
      (2)   Painting the sign and/or the sign structure when no change of
ownership is involved.
      (3)   Re-posting or repairing a poster panel.
161.07   CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS.
1.   Small Signs. Small commercial signs and wall signs, maximum area eight
square feet for either, may be constructed entirely of wood.
2.   Combustible Plastics. Any signs may incorporate areas and/or parts of
approved combustible plastics.
3.   Plywood on Wood Battens. Auxiliary panels (cutouts) supported from poster
panels may be of plywood or wood battens, with noncombustible supports and
attachments from the poster panel face or structure.
4.   Noncombustible Construction. Except as noted above, all parts of signs,
sign structures, and poster panels shall be of noncombustible construction.
5.   Glass. No sign over or within its height distance of public property shall
contain any glass other than that of the electric lighting units. “Lighting
units” shall not be construed as including any part of a lighting unit
enclosure such as glass letters or glass facing illuminated from within.
6.   Stresses. The working stresses of chains, wire ropes, guy rods, and all
fastenings, connections, and anchorage details for all these items shall not
exceed one-quarter of their ultimate strength.
7.   Electrical Signs.
   A.   Public Property. Where over public property, not less than 85 percent
of the lettered area of an electric sign shall be illuminated. Letters shall
include figures, illustrations, etc., as described herein. Areas shall be
calculated on the basis of rectangles enclosing each inscription line and
touching the outer points of the respective words and figures in the
inscription line. In the case of irregular insignia, illustrations, etc., the
area shall be that of the smallest straight line geometric figure without re-
entrant angles which will enclose the illuminated device.
   B.   Illumination Source. Illumination source may be either filament lamps
or electric discharge lamps. Sign lighting and illuminated signs shall be of
such intensity and positioning so as not to cause any glare falling into the
sight path of any passing motor vehicle.
   C.   Enclosed or Exposed Source. The illuminative source may be enclosed
with translucent panels or may be exposed on the sign face.
   D.   Flashing and Switching. Flashing and switching devices may not be
incorporated in the design.
   E.   Requirements. An electric sign may be composed of individual
illuminated letters, attached to a building face, mounted on a marquee or
canopy or belt course of a building, on top of a parapet wall, or along the
margin of a cornice or open edge of a roof. Clearances and projections shall
comply with applicable sections of this chapter. Such letter signs may be
silhouette or backlighted. Arrangement on parapets and roof margins must be
such as not to interfere with Fire Department access.
   F.   Placement Near Traffic Signs. No electric sign is to be so placed as to
obscure any traffic light or provide a confusing background for a traffic
light.
8.   All Other Elements. All other elements of signs and sign structures shall
comply with the structural design requirements of other applicable chapters of
this Code and good engineering practice.
161.08   SPECIFIC SIGN TYPES AND REGULATIONS.
1.   Billboards.
   A.   Ground Mounted. Ground mounted billboards shall not exceed 30 feet in
height measured from the highest adjoining sidewalk level. In case no sidewalk
exists, the measurement shall be taken from the established street grade
adjacent, and in case no such established street grade exists, then the
measurement shall be taken from the average grade at the sign location. Signs,
clocks, or other advertising devices erected upon standards or separate
supports shall be placed so as to be entirely within the property lines of the
premises upon which it is located, and no part of the sign or standard shall
have a total height greater than 30 feet above the level of the street upon
which the sign faces or above the adjoining ground level, if such ground level
is above the street level, nor shall the surface of any such sign exceed in
area of 250 square feet.
   B.   Face of Billboards. The face of all ground-mounted billboards shall be
set back from the street property line a distance of one foot, but in no case
shall any part be set forward of an established building line or the property
line. The one-foot restriction applies to the face of the sign panels. Electric
lighting reflectors may project forward from the sign face. Clearance
regulations for projecting signs apply to such lighting units.
   C.   Base of Billboards. The base of a billboard shall be at least three
feet above grade at the sign location. The space below may be filled with a
decorative lattice or of similar light, noncombustible construction having at
least 50 percent open area.
   D.   Duties and Responsibilities. The owners, and lessees, of any billboards
on otherwise vacant lots shall be subject to the same duties and
responsibilities as the owner of the lot with respect to keeping the premises
clean and inoffensive.
   E.   Property Line. Billboards shall not be set closer to an inside property
line than the allowable distance for buildings provided by the Zoning
Ordinance.
   F.   Overhanging Public Property. Neither the face or structural trim of a
wall-mounted billboard may overhang public property unless it meets clearance
specifications for wall signs as set forth in Paragraphs 3(A) and (B) of this
section.
2.   Roof Signs.
   A.    Roof signs shall not exceed eight feet in height except upon written
approval by the Council, measured from the highest point of the roof
immediately below the sign. Roof signs shall not extend above the height
limitations of the building on which it is mounted, either as established by
this Code or by the Zoning Regulations.
   B.   Overhanging Public Property. No roof sign shall overhang public
property, except that lighting reflectors may project not to exceed eight feet
from the sign face.
   C.   Access By Fire Department. Roof signs and their supports shall not be
placed so as to interfere with or obstruct access to or traversing of roofs by
the Fire Department.
   D.   Space Between Sign and Roof. The bottom on the face of a roof sign
shall have a clear space between the sign and the roof, unobstructed except for
the necessary vertical supports and bracing. Such space to be as follows:
      (1)   All parts of signs within five feet of exterior walls of the
building, not less than six feet.
      (2)   All parts of signs five feet or more back of exterior walls of the
building, not less than four feet.
3.   Wall Signs.
   A.   Projection. No part of a wall sign shall project more than six inches
forward of the wall to which it is attached, except that lighting reflectors
may project eight feet from such wall. The provision applies whether the sign
is over private or public property. Signs projecting a greater distance shall
be classed as projecting signs.
   B.   Height. Wall signs may be mounted above public property in which case
the clear distance from the highest point of the sidewalk (or grade if no walk
exists) to the lowest part of the sign shall be nine feet, except as noted in
the following:
      (1)   There shall be no restriction in the mounting height of a plaque or
tablet provided its maximum projection from the wall face is two inches.
      (2)   Individual letter signs with a maximum projection of one inch may
be mounted up a clear distance of not less than seven feet.
         i.   Private Commercial Property. The same restrictions in Paragraph 3
(B) shall apply for wall signs mounted over publicly used walkways or roadways
on private commercial property.
         ii.   Public Alley. A wall sign may be erected over a public alley,
with a maximum projection of two inches, a minimum clearance above the alley
surface at the lot line shall be nine feet, and the maximum area 16 square
feet.
4.   Marquee Signs.
   A.   Requirements. Signs may be erected over a marquee, attached to the
front or sides of a marquee; or attached to or hung from a marquee. Such signs
may extend the full length and/or width of the marquee. Such signs shall not
exceed five feet in height.
   B.   Permanent Fixed Awning or Marquee. When signs are hung from or attached
to a permanent fixed awning or a marquee, the projections and clearances shall
be as set forth for projecting signs.
   C.   Front Attachment. When signs are attached to the front of the marquee
the extreme projection of the sign shall be considered the front of the marquee
and shall comply with all clearance distances for projecting signs.
5.   Projecting Signs.
   A.   Requirements. No projecting sign shall exceed 30 feet in height or have
a total gross area of any one face exceeding 250 square feet, except with
written approval by the Council.
   B.   Public Property. Any projecting sign overhanging public property shall
be an electrical sign or illuminated by wall-mounted or spot lighting.
   C.   Projection. No projecting sign shall overhang public property more than
nine feet six inches or project beyond a point within one foot of a line drawn
perpendicularly upward from the face of the street curb.
   D.   Widened Streets and Curbs. Where streets are widened and curbs are set
back, all projecting signs shall be altered to conform to the above within 30
days after widening work contract is finished or order date. No notice is
required by the City to the sign owner. No liability shall accrue against the
City.
   E.   Minimum Clear Height. The minimum clear height of a projecting sign
above a public sidewalk shall be as follows:
      (1)   In Zones “C-3,” “I-1,” and “I-2” signs projecting more than six
feet over public property - 12 feet;
      (2)   All other zones - 10 feet, six inches.
   F.   Innermost Point of Projection. The innermost point of a projecting sign
shall not be more than two feet from the building wall.
   G.   Private Commercial Property. All of the above clearance and dimension
restrictions shall also apply to projecting signs when erected over publicly
used walkways on private commercial property, or over publicly used drives and
parking lots on such property.
   H.   Public Alley. No projecting sign may overhang a public alley.
6.   Ground Signs.
   A.   Requirements. No ground signs shall exceed 30 feet in height, except
upon written approval by the Council, measured from the highest adjoining
sidewalk level or other grade as established herein.
   B.   Total Gross Area. No ground sign shall have a total gross area of any
one face exceeding 250 square feet, except upon written approval by the
Council. This shall be computed for the actual sign area and does not include
the supporting structure below the sign.
   C.   Supporting Structure. All parts of the supporting structure of a ground
sign shall be on private property. No part of the supporting structure shall
extend beyond a line one foot inside the public right-of-way line. No part of
the supporting structure shall be set closer to the property line than the
allowable distance for buildings provided by the Zoning Regulations.
   D.   Projections. A ground sign may have portions (or all) of the actual
sign projected from the supporting structure and such projections may extend
over public property in which case all of the provisions of Subsection 5 shall
apply, and the two-foot dimension of Paragraph 5(F) shall be measured from the
property line.
   E.   Special Permits. The Council, at its discretion and on receipt of
proper application, may authorize special permits for heights and areas
exceeding the limitations above. Each unit shall require separate action.
   F.   Church Bulletins. Church bulletins must be located on private property.
Such bulletins may have portions constructed of combustible materials. Fronts
may be of glass. Maximum dimension of church bulletins shall be eight feet,
with a maximum area of 32 square feet; both limitations to include the
enclosing structure, but not the height of open column or post supports below.
161.09   SIGNS PERMITTED IN RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS.
In all residential districts, the following classes of signs are permitted in
accordance with the regulations set forth herein:
1.   Non-Flashing and Non-Illuminated Accessory Signs.
   A.   Name Plates. Subject to the following:
      (1)   For one- and two-family dwellings, there shall be not more than one
nameplate, not exceeding one square foot in area for each dwelling unit,
indicating the name or address of the occupant or a permitted home occupation.
      (2)   For multiple-family dwellings up to 10 dwelling units, apartment
hotels, and for buildings other than dwellings, a single identification sign
not exceeding 32 square feet in area may be displayed. Any larger sign must be
approved, in writing, by the Council prior to issuance of a permit. Only the
name and address of the building and the name of the management thereof may be
contained on this sign.
      (3)   In connection with the construction or remodeling of a building,
there shall be permitted one sign not exceeding 32 square feet in area. On
corner lots two such signs, one facing each street, shall be permitted. Said
signs shall be removed within two weeks after completion of the structure
indicated.
      (4)   No sign shall project higher than eight feet above the established
average grade, whichever is lower.
      (5)   No sign shall project beyond the property line into the public
right-of-way.
   B.   Temporary “For Sale” and “To Rent” Signs. Subject to the following:
      (1)   There shall be not more than one such sign per zoning lot, except
that on a corner lot two signs, one facing each street, shall be permitted. No
sign shall exceed 10 square feet in area or be closer than eight feet to any
other zoning lot.
      (2)   No sign shall project beyond the property line into the public way.
      (3)   No sign shall project higher than eight feet above the established
average grade, whichever is lower.
   C.   Accessory Signs to Parking Areas. Subject to the following:
      (1)   Signs designating parking area entrances or exits are limited to
one sign for each exit or entrance and to a maximum size of two square feet
each. One sign per parking area and designating the conditions of use, or
identity of such parking area, and limited to a maximum size of nine square
feet shall be permitted.
      (2)   No sign shall project beyond the property line into the public way.
      (3)   No sign shall project higher than seven feet above the established
average grade of the parking area.
   D.   Church bulletins. Subject to the following:
      (1)   There shall be not more than one sign per zoning lot, except that
on a corner lot, two signs, one facing each street, shall be permitted.
      (2)   No sign shall project beyond the property line into the public
right-of-way.
      (3)   No sign shall project higher than eight feet above the established
average grade.
      (4)   May be illuminated, but not flashing.
161.10   SIGNS PERMITTED IN COMMERCIAL DISTRICTS.
In all commercial districts, the following signs are permitted subject to the
requirements set forth herein:
1.   All signs and nameplates permitted in the residential districts and
subject to the following:
   A.   Illumination. No illuminated sign shall be of the flashing or
intermittent type, except that advertising devices denoting the time,
temperature, and other similar information shall not be considered a flashing
sign for the purpose of this chapter. Signs which may be in conflict with
public traffic signals shall not be permitted. Illuminated signs shall be
shaded so as not to shine on adjacent residential properties, thereby
constituting a nuisance.
   B.   Height. No sign shall project higher than 30 feet above the established
average grade of the street upon which the sign faces or above the adjoining
ground level, if such ground level is above the street level. If a sign is
connected to a building, it shall not project more than eight feet above the
roof line.
2.   On-site Signs. On-site signs are permitted subject to the following:
   A.   Nameplates. Signs relating only to the name and use of buildings or
premises upon which they are placed.
   B.   Wall Signs. No sign, excluding murals, shall be painted, pasted, or
similarly posted directly on the surface of any wall, nor shall any sign be
permitted to be placed on any wall, fence, or standard facing the side of any
adjoining lot located in a residence district. The sign or signs may front on
the front side, or rear walls or all of the principal building.
   C.   Marquees. Restrictions imposed hereinafter on the projection of signs
across property lines into the public right-of-way shall not apply to signs
located on marquees or canopies, provided that any sign located on a marquee or
canopy shall be affixed flat to the surface thereof, and further, no sign shall
extend vertically or horizontally beyond the limits of said marquee or canopy,
except that individual free-standing letters may project to a height not to
exceed 60 inches above same. Restrictions imposed herein on the projection of
signs across property lines into the public right-of-way shall not apply to
signs located on an awning provided that any sign located on an awning shall be
affixed flat to the surface thereof, shall be non-illuminated and non-flashing,
and shall indicate only the name and address of the establishment on the
premises. Further, no such sign shall extend vertically or horizontally beyond
the limits of said awning.
   D.   Ground Signs. No ground sign shall be erected or placed between the
street line and the building line.
      (1)   Joint Identification. For an integrated planned business
development in single ownership and management, or under unified control, one
additional sign may be erected not exceeding 250 square feet in area
advertising only the name and location of the integrated shopping center. Such
sign shall be placed so as to be entirely within the property lines of the
premises upon which it is located, and the bottom edge of such sign shall be at
least five feet above the level of the ground, and the overall height shall not
exceed 30 feet above curb level or above the adjoining ground level if such
ground level is above the street level.
   E.   Projecting Signs. Signs suspended from any building shall not project
more than four feet beyond the front of the building. The sign location and
arrangement shall be subject to approval by the Building and Zoning Enforcement
Officer.
3.   Off-site Signs. Off-site signs are permitted subject to the following:
   A.   Billboards. Signs which advertise products, businesses, or public
service activities not related to the occupancy and use of the premises are
prohibited in the C-1 zoning district and are subject to the following:
      (1)   In any C-3 zone the minimum area for any billboard, except “service
club or religious notice signs” as defined by the I.D.O.T., will be not less
than 32 square feet.
      (2)   Location. No advertising sign shall be erected on the front of any
building and no more than one advertising sign structure shall be permitted to
be erected on a business lot having 50 feet of frontage or less, and no more
than one additional structure shall be permitted for an additional 100 linear
feet of lot frontage, or major fraction thereof.
         a.   In any C-3 zone, where platted lots do not currently exist, and
where platted lots will probably not exist in the future (e.g., in the railroad
right-of-way), the maximum distance between signs within these unplatted areas
shall be not less than 700 feet.
         b.   This provision does not apply to the distance between two or more
“service club or religious notice signs” as defined by the I.D.O.T., or the
distance between these types of signs as referenced above and all other types
of signs.
      (3)   Number. No advertising sign structure shall contain over two signs
per facing.
      (4)   Setback. All advertising signs shall be required to be set back
from the property line a distance of the minimum setback requirement of the
district or to the established building line, whichever is the greater.
      (5)   Maximum Clear Height. The maximum clear height for any billboards
(that clear space between the lowest part of the sign face and the surrounding
natural grade) will be not more than four feet six inches for signs from 32
square feet up to 71 square feet; not more than six feet for signs from 72
square feet up to 143 square feet up to 195 square feet; and not more than 20
feet for signs from 196 square feet up to 250 square feet.
      (6)   Double-Faced. Any billboard, except “service club or religious
notice signs,” as defined by the I.D.O.T., will have not less than two faces.
(Each such sign will be “double-faced” only).
   B.   Automobile Service Stations. The following signs accessory to
automobile service stations are permitted:
      (1)   Racks for the orderly display of cans of engine oil for convenience
in dispensing said oil may be located on or at the ends of pump islands (limit
of two to each island).
      (2)   Two open portable tire racks (not more than seven feet in height,
including signs, and six feet in length), for the purpose of displaying new
tire casings, shall be permitted for each gasoline or tire service station.
      (3)   Items for sale on the premises may be openly displayed within 10
feet of the principal building. Products may be displayed under group island
canopies or between pumps within the area of the pump island base.
      (4)   Any sign may be painted on the inside and outside front door face
of a closed tire rack, but shall not be painted on the sides or rear.
161.11   SIGNS PERMITTED IN INDUSTRIAL DISTRICTS.
In all industrial districts the following signs are permitted, subject to the
requirements set forth herein:
1.   All identification, business, and advertising signs permitted in the
commercial districts.
2.   All signs shall adhere to the requirements for signs in the commercial
districts unless otherwise specified below.
3.   Billboards and Ground Signs. Signs shall not have a sign area in excess of
250 square feet, except that where only one advertising sign is erected per
facing on a sign structure, such sign area may be doubled in size but shall not
exceed 500 square feet.
   A.   The minimum distance between any two located on the same side of a
street or highway, and on the same zoning lot, shall be not less than four feet
for every one square foot of the total area of the two signs.
   B.   No advertising sign shall be permitted to be erected closer than 100
feet to any other structure on the same side of a street or highway, unless
separated by a building, roadway, or structure for signs or billboards which
face the same direction.
   C.   The gross area in square feet of all signs on a zoning lot shall not
exceed six times the lineal feet of frontage of such zoning lot, except in the
case where there is just one sign and said sign shall not exceed 250 square
feet.
   D.   No advertising sign, the informative contents of which are to be
visible from a park, shall be permitted to be erected within 500 feet of any
public park of more than five acres in area.
161.12   SIGN MAINTENANCE.
1.   Sign Identification. Every sign hereafter registered shall show in a
conspicuous place thereon, which is visible to the Inspector and is readable by
the Inspector from the ground, the permit number.
2.   Premises Maintenance. All free-standing signs and the premises surrounding
the same shall be maintained by the owner thereof in a clean, sanitary, and
inoffensive condition, and free and clear of all obnoxious substances, rubbish,
and weeds as defined and as otherwise required elsewhere in this Code.
3.   Sign/Structure Maintenance. Every sign shall be kept well painted and or
maintained at all times. Any deterioration, loose, or torn paper or paint shall
be removed and replaced immediately.
4.   Unsafe or Illegal Signs.
   A.   Nuisance. Any sign becoming insecure, in danger of falling, or
otherwise unsafe, or any sign installed, erected, or maintained in violation of
any of the provisions of this chapter is a public nuisance and may be removed
by the City upon not less than two (2) days’ written notice to the owner of the
sign and to the owner of the land on which the sign is located.
The notice shall require such owners to make the sign safe, remove the sign if
it is prohibited, or to cause it to conform to the provisions of this chapter
if it is not prohibited. Further, said notice shall also include a statement
that the City will exercise its right of removal, as specified below, if the
required actions are not completed within the allotted timeframe.
If the owner of the sign or the property owner fails to act within the
timeframe as required in the notice, the advertising device shall be deemed to
be forfeited and the City may enter upon the land and remove the advertising
device. Such entry, after notice, shall not be deemed a trespass, and the City
may be aided by injunction to abate the nuisance and to insure peaceful entry.
   B.   Privately Owned Signs in Public Places. Existing privately owned signs
currently located on or over a public place that are not in compliance with
this Code shall be eliminated and removed. If the sign owner fails to remove
the sign after so ordered by the City, the City may remove the sign.
   C.   Assessment of Costs. All costs, fees, and expenses arising out of an
action brought by the City to insure the peaceful entry and/or removal of any
signs will be assessed against the property owner and act as a lien on the
property and collected in the same manner as regular property taxes.
5.   Removal by Order of City Council. Any sign on or over public property may
be ordered removed by action of the Council when such sign is determined to
cause a nuisance as defined herein. No liability shall be incurred by the City
on account of any such removal order.
161.13   NONCONFORMING SIGNS.
1.   Definition. For the purpose of this section, a nonconforming sign is a
sign which does not conform with the provisions of this chapter, or which does
not conform with the City Zoning Regulations.
2.   On-site Nonconforming Sign. All nonconforming signs not otherwise
prohibited by the provisions of this chapter, relating to a place of business,
and located on the same premises as such place of business, may be continued
until:
   A.   The nature of the business conducted on the premises changes in such
manner as to occasion a change in the existing sign; or
   B.   The name of the business changes and the sign is changed or modified
either in shape, size, or legend.
3.   Off-site Nonconforming Signs. Where an off-site nonconforming sign is
located off the premises of the place of business to which the sign pertains,
and exists at the effective date of the ordinance codified herein, and could
not be built under the terms of such ordinance by reason of restrictions on
sign area, height, its location on the lot, or other requirements, the owner of
the sign shall:
   A.   Place on record, in the office of the Building and Zoning Enforcement
Officer within one year following the adopting of the ordinance codified by
this chapter, a sworn statement regarding the term of the lease agreement that
was in effect on the effective date of such ordinance, if any, and other
information describing the existing sign.
   B.   If a lease is not in effect, remove the sign within three years from
such effective date.
4.   No Alterations to Sign Permitted. No nonconforming sign may be enlarged or
altered in any way which would increase its nonconformity.
5.   Damaged Nonconforming Signs. Should any nonconforming sign be damaged by
any means to an extent of more than 65 percent of its replacement cost at time
of damage, it shall not be reconstructed except in conformity with the
provisions of this chapter.
161.14   PUBLIC HEARING REQUIRED.
A public hearing shall be required to be held to receive public input on any
petition to erect a sign that is not in conformance with the requirements of
this chapter. Notice of said meeting shall be published as prescribed by law
and written notice shall be delivered by certified mail to all property owners
of record who own property within 200 feet of any boundary of the property upon
which said sign is proposed to be located.
161.15   PENALTIES.
The owner or tenant of any building, structure, premises, or part thereof, and
any architect, builder, contractor, agent, or other person who commits,
participates in, or maintains such violation may be found guilty of a separate
offense and suffer the penalties herein provided.
CHAPTER 162
NATIONAL POLLUTANT DISCHARGE ELIMINATION SYSTEM (NPDES AND MS4) PERMIT PROGRAM

162.01   ILLICIT DISCHARGE TO STORMWATER SYSTEM.
1.   For purposes of this chapter, a “responsible party” is one or more persons
that control or are in possession of or own property. Responsible parties shall
be jointly and severally responsible for compliance with this chapter and
jointly and severally liable for any illicit discharge from the property
controlled, possessed, or owned. For purposes of this chapter, “property”
includes, but is not limited to, real estate, fixtures, facilities, and
premises of any kind located upon, under, or above the real estate.
2.   Nothing in this chapter shall be deemed to relieve a responsible party
subject to an IDNR-issued industrial discharge permit or any other federal,
State, or City permit, statute, chapter, or rule from any obligation imposed by
such permit, statute, ordinance, or rule, if any such obligation is greater
than any obligation imposed by this chapter.
3.   Any discharge into the City’s storm sewer system prohibited by the City’s
MS4 Permit, (all terms, conditions, and requirements of which are hereby
incorporated by reference), shall be deemed an “illicit discharge” in violation
of this chapter. An “illicit discharge” as defined by the EPA’s Phase II
Stormwater Regulations is “any discharge to a municipal separate storm sewer
system that is not composed entirely of stormwater, except discharges pursuant
to an NPDES permit and discharges resulting from fire-fighting activities”.
4.   Sediment pollution originating from excessive erosion rates on any site
not otherwise subject to this chapter and/or any other “pollutants of concern”
entering or allowed to enter a municipal storm sewer that causes a water
quality violation as determined by the DNR shall be deemed an illicit discharge
in violation of this chapter.† 13  In determining what constitutes a water
quality violation for purposes of enforcing this chapter, the City shall base
any decisions on definitive analysis utilizing those published water quality
standards as established by the IDNR. As defined in I.A.C. 567-64.13(2.c.1)
(455B) as amended; “Pollutants of concern” include biochemical oxygen demand
levels, sediment, or a parameter that addresses sediment (total suspended
solids, turbidity, or siltation), pathogens, oil and grease, and any pollutant
that has been identified as a cause of impairment of any water body that will
receive a discharge from the MS4.
 
Notes
   † EDITOR’S NOTE: It is acknowledged that this provision essentially subjects any
13 site to regulation which is more than State or federal law may mandate; however,
   the IDNR has indicated that any discharge that constitutes a water quality
   violation is subject to regulation.
162.02   ILLICIT CONNECTIONS PROHIBITED.
1.   For purposes of this chapter, an “illicit connection” to the City’s storm
sewer system is any physical connection or other topographical or other
condition, natural or artificial, which is not specifically authorized by
ordinance or written rule of the City, which causes or facilitates, directly or
indirectly, an illicit discharge.
2.   The construction, use, maintenance, or continued existence of any illicit
connection is hereby deemed to be a public nuisance and shall constitute a
violation of this chapter.
3.   This prohibition expressly includes, without limitation, illicit
connections made in the past, regardless of whether the connection was
permissible under law or practices applicable or prevailing at the time of
connection.
162.03   INDUSTRIAL DISCHARGES.
1.   Any responsible party subject to an industrial NPDES discharge permit
issued by the IDNR shall comply with all provisions of such permit.
2.   Proof of compliance with said permit may be required in a form acceptable
to the City prior to discharges to the storm sewer system authorized by said
permit.
162.04   ILLICIT DISCHARGE DETECTION, REPORTING, AND COST RECOVERY.
1.   All detection activities permitted under this chapter shall be conducted
by the City, or its designee, hereinbefore and after referred to as the “City.”
2.   The City shall not be responsible for the direct or indirect consequences
to persons or property of an illicit discharge, or circumstances which may
cause an illicit discharge, undetected by the City.
3.   Every responsible party has an absolute duty to monitor conditions on
property owned or controlled by them, to prevent all illicit discharges, and to
report to the City any illicit discharges which the responsible party knows or
should have known to have occurred. Failure to comply with any provision of
this chapter is a violation of this code.
   A.   Notwithstanding other requirements of law, as soon as any responsible
party has information of any known or suspected illicit discharge, the
responsible party shall immediately take all necessary steps to ensure the
discovery, containment, and cleanup of such discharge at the responsible
party’s sole cost.
   B.   If the illicit discharge consists of hazardous materials, the
responsible party shall also immediately notify emergency response agencies of
the occurrence via emergency dispatch services.
   C.   If the illicit discharge emanates from a commercial or industrial
establishment, the owner or operator of such establishment shall also retain an
on-site written record of the discharge and the actions taken to prevent its
recurrence. Such records shall be retained for at least three years.
   D.   A report of an illicit discharge shall be made in person or by phone or
facsimile or email to the City immediately but, in any event, within 24 hours
of the illicit discharge; notifications in person or by phone shall be
confirmed by written notice addressed and mailed or emailed to the City within
24 hours of the personal or phone notice.
4.   Any person or entity shall also report to the City any illicit discharge
or circumstances which such person or entity reasonably believes poses a risk
of an illicit discharge.
5.   Upon receiving a report pursuant to the previous subsections, or otherwise
coming into possession of information indicating an actual or imminent illicit
discharge, the City shall conduct an inspection of the site as soon as
reasonably possible, and thereafter shall provide to the responsible party, and
any third-party reporter, a written report of the conditions which may cause or
which have already caused an illicit discharge. The responsible party shall
immediately commence corrective action(s) or remediation and shall complete
such corrective action(s) or remediation within 24 hours.
6.   The City shall be permitted to enter and inspect property subject to
regulation under this chapter as often as is necessary to determine compliance
with this chapter. If a responsible party has security measures that require
identification and clearance before entry to its property or premises, the
responsible party shall make the necessary arrangements to allow access by the
City. By way of specification, but not limitation:
   A.   A responsible party shall allow the City ready access to all parts of
the property for purposes of inspection, sampling, examination, and copying of
records related to a suspected, actual, or imminent illicit discharge, and for
the performance of any additional duties as defined by State and federal law.
   B.   The City shall have the right to set up on any property such devices as
are necessary, in the opinion of the City, to conduct monitoring and/or
sampling related to a suspected, actual, or imminent illicit discharge.
   C.   The City shall have the right to require any responsible party, at
responsible party’s sole expense, to install monitoring equipment and deliver
monitoring data or reports to the City as the City directs. The sampling and
monitoring equipment shall be maintained at all times in a safe and proper
operating condition by the responsible party at responsible party’s sole
expense. All devices shall be calibrated to ensure their accuracy.
   D.   Any temporary or permanent obstruction to safe and easy access to
property to be inspected and/or sampled shall be promptly removed by the
responsible party at the written or oral order of the City and shall not be
replaced. The costs of clearing such access shall be borne by the responsible
party.
   E.   Any unreasonable delay in allowing the City access to a property is a
violation of this chapter.
7.   If the City has been refused access to any part of the property from where
an illicit connection and/or illicit discharge to a municipal storm sewer or
tributary to a water course is occurring, suspected or imminent, and the City
is able to demonstrate probable cause to believe that there may be a violation
of this chapter, or that there is a need to inspect and/or sample as part of a
routine inspection and sampling program designed to verify compliance with this
chapter or any order issued hereunder, or to protect the overall public health,
safety, and welfare of the community, then the City may seek issuance of a
search warrant from any court of competent jurisdiction.
8.   If it is determined that an illicit discharge is imminent or has occurred,
any and all costs incurred by the City in the enforcement of this chapter shall
be recovered from the responsible party. The City shall submit an invoice to
the responsible party reflecting the costs incurred by the City for any and all
enforcement activities undertaken under this Code. Failure to pay charges
properly invoiced under this Code within 30 days of billing shall constitute a
violation of this Code, and said charges not timely paid shall constitute a
lien against the property and may be assessed against the property from which
an illicit discharge emanates and collected in the same manner as other
