Contiguous Area.” It embraces all the lands and properties lying within said
City, and within the areas set forth and described as being contiguous or
adjacent to said City within a maximum of two miles from the said City limits,
but outside said City.
175.02   PURPOSE.
The purpose of this chapter is:
1.   To promote the adequacy and efficiency of the street and road system so as
to avoid congestion and promote safety;
2.   To secure the proper distribution of population and the necessary open
spaces for light and air;
3.   To improve the health, safety, and general welfare of the citizens;
4.   To establish minimum standards for the design and development of all new
subdivisions so that existing developments will be protected and so the new
subdivisions will conform to the City plans;
5.   To facilitate the adequate provision of water, sewerage, storm drainage,
schools, parks, and other public requirements;
6.   To insure sound, harmonious subdivision development and community growth;
7.   To provide permanent assets to the locality and to the City;
8.   To safeguard the interests of the homeowner, the subdivider, the investor,
and the City;
9.   To prevent scattered development beyond existing public utilities and
prevent excessive development costs, unless an agreement to extend such
utilities is executed by the developer;
10.   To assure the development of land for the highest possible use with all
the necessary protection against deterioration and obsolescence, and;
11.   To provide common grounds of understanding and a sound working
relationship between the City and the subdivider.
175.03   AUTHORITY.
This chapter is adopted pursuant to the authority granted by Chapters 354 and
355 of the Code of Iowa, as amended, and which are specifically adopted by
reference.
175.04   APPROVALS AND EXCEPTIONS.
No land shall be subdivided or filed for record, nor any street laid out, nor
any improvements made to the land, until the plat or plans of the subdivision
or street improvements shall have been referred to the Planning and Zoning
Commission for review and recommendation and approved by action of the Council.
(The use of eminent domain to establish or create said road, highway, street,
or alley shall not require the owner to submit a subdivision plat). This
approval must be in writing and placed on the original tracing of the final
plat according to the procedures outlined herein. No lot, tract, or parcel of
land within any such subdivision shall be offered for sale nor will any sale,
contract for sale, or option be made or given until subdivision plans have been
properly reviewed and formally approved by the Planning and Zoning Commission
and the Council. (The sale or exchange of small parcels of land to or between
immediately adjoining property owners, where such sale or exchange does not
create additional, buildable lots, shall not be considered as a subdivision of
land). No improvements, such as sidewalks, water supply, stormwater drainage,
sewer facilities, gas service, electric service or lighting, or grading, paving
or surfacing of streets, will hereafter be made within or abutting any such
subdivision by any owner or owners, or their agent, or by any public service
corporation at the request of such owner or owners, or their agent, until
preliminary plats for the subdivision and also the plans for improvements
thereto have been formally approved by the Planning and Zoning Commission and
Council, according to the procedures outlined herein.
175.05   DEFINITIONS.
For the purposes of this chapter and in order to carry out the provisions
contained herein, certain words, terms, and phrases are to be interpreted as
defined herein. Words used in the present tense will include the future tense;
the singular number includes the plural, and the plural number includes the
singular. The word “lot” includes the word “plot” or “parcel.” The word “will”
is mandatory, and the word “may” is permissive. The phrase “used for” will
include the phrases “arranged for,” “designed for,” “intended for,” “maintained
for,” and “occupied for.” The following words, terms, and phrases are hereby
defined as follows, and will be interpreted as such throughout these
regulations, unless otherwise modified herein. Terms not herein defined will
have the meaning customarily assigned to them:
1.   Words beginning with “A.”
   A.   “Alley” means a public right-of-way which affords only a secondary
means of vehicular access to the back or side of abutting properties.
   B.   “Auditor’s plat” means a subdivision plat required by either the County
Auditor or the County Assessor, prepared by a surveyor under the direction of
the Auditor or the Assessor. Such plats are intended to clarify property tax
descriptions for the purposes of assessment and taxation.
2.   Words beginning with “B.”
   A.   “Base course” means the layer or layers of specified or selected
materials of designed thickness upon which the final traffic surface is
constructed.
   B.   “Block” means a tract of land bounded by streets or by a combination of
streets, public parks, cemeteries, railroad right-of-way, shorelines of
waterways, and/or other physical barriers.
   C.   “Building” means any structure designed or built for the support,
enclosure, shelter, or protection of people, animals, chattels, or property of
any kind, including mobile homes. Any structure with an interior area not
normally accessible for human use will not be considered as a building. When
separated by party walls without openings through such walls, each portion of
such a building will be considered a separate structure.
   D.   “Building and Zoning Enforcement Officer” means the person appointed to
occupy the office created herein, in which office is vested the principal
administrative and enforcement duties associated with this chapter.
   E.   “Building setback line” means a line on a plat between which line and
the property line no building or structure of any kind may be erected.
3.   Words beginning with “C.”
   A.   “Circle drive” means a residential street of a closed circular shape
which has one entrance open to traffic and intersects or intercepts no street
other than the entrance.
   B.   “City Engineer” means the person or firm designated to act in that
capacity in the review of engineering data as outlined herein where the service
of a City Engineer is specifically mentioned.
   C.   “Conveyance” means an instrument filed with a recorder as evidence of
the transfer of title to land, including any form of deed or contract.
   D.   “Communication service or communications” means communication services
provided to the public such as telephone, cable television, and other such
services as may require the use of easements for the delivery of services
within their operating permits.
   E.   “Crosswalk” means a strip of land dedicated to public use, which is
reserved across a block to provide pedestrian access to adjacent areas.
   F.   “Cul-de-sac” means a local street terminated at one end with a
permanent turn-around, and the open end being the only means of access to
another street.
4.   Words beginning with “D.”
   A.   “Dedication” means that action of the subdivider whereby title to land,
right-of-ways, and/or public improvements, as required by this chapter and
action of the Council, is conveyed to the City.
   B.   “Design standards” means the “LeClaire Standard Public Works
Improvements Specifications” and any construction or development standards that
may be referenced therein.
   C.   “Division” means dividing a tract or parcel of land into two parcels of
land by conveyance or for tax purposes. The conveyance of an easement, other
than a public highway easement, shall not be considered a division for the
purpose of this chapter.
5.   Words beginning with “E.”
   A.   “Easement” means a grant by a property owner for the use of a strip of
land by the general public, a corporation, or a certain person or persons for a
specific purpose or purposes.
   B.   “Excess stormwater passageway” (“major system,” see Section
175.32) means a drainage easement designed to carry that portion of stormwater
runoff from the 100-year frequency storm that exceeds the carrying capacity of
storm sewers and natural drainage channels serving a specific watershed.
6.   Words beginning with “F.”
   A.   “Five-year storm” means the equivalent of two inches of rain falling in
a one-hour period or less.
   B.   “Flag lot” means a lot with a long, unbuildable approach used to
provide access and meet frontage provisions for subdivision lots.
   C.   “Flood” means a general and temporary condition of partial or complete
inundation of normally dry land areas resulting from the overflow of streams or
rivers or from the unusual and rapid run-off of surface waters from any source.
   D.   “Floodproofing” means any combination of structural and nonstructural
additions, changes, or adjustments to structures, including utility and
sanitary facilities, which will reduce or eliminate flood damage to such
structures.
   E.   “Floodway” means the channel of a river or stream and those portions of
the floodplains adjoining the channel, which are reasonably required to carry
and discharge flood waters or flood flows so that confinement of flood flows to
the floodway area will not result in substantially higher flood levels and flow
velocities.
   F.   “Flood hazard area” means any area subject to flooding by a one percent
probability flood, otherwise referred to as a base flood as designated by the
Iowa Department of Natural Resources or the Federal Insurance Administration.
   G.   “Frontage road” means a collector street which is parallel to and
adjacent to arterial streets and expressways, and which provides access to
abutting properties and affords protection to local traffic from fast, through-
moving traffic on the arterial streets or expressways.
7.   Words beginning with “G.”
8.   Words beginning with “H.”
   A.   “Half street” means a street having width less than that required by
these and other appropriate regulations.
   B.   “Highway” means a right-of-way for vehicular traffic, which traverses a
non-urban area, usually a State or federally numbered route. (Interstate 80 and
U.S. Highway 67 are highways in this City).
9.   Words beginning with “I.”
   A.   “Improvements” means changes to land necessary to prepare it for
building sites including, but not limited to, grading, filling, street paving,
curb paving, sidewalks, walkways, watermains, sewers, drainageways, and other
public works and appurtenances.
   B.   “Individual subsurface sewage treatment facility” means a sewage
disposal system designed to function on an individual lot basis. (A septic tank
is a type of individual subsurface sewage treatment facility).
10.   Words beginning with “J.”
11.   Words beginning with “K.”
12.   Words beginning with “L.”
   A.   “Land remnant” or “outlot” means any portion of a tract of land which
cannot be developed after the tract has been subdivided.
   B.   “Loop street” means a residential street that begins and ends at two
spaced points on the same street, and which intersects or intercepts no other
street. (Glenwood Drive and Mississippi Terrace Drive are examples of loop
streets in this City).
   C.   “Lot” means a parcel of land which is, or may be, occupied by a
building and its accessory buildings or related use, together with such yards,
parking, or open spaces within the lot lines as may be required by these
regulations, and having its principal frontage on a street or upon an approved
private drive.
   D.   “Lot area” means the total horizontal plane area included within lot
lines.
   E.   “Lot, buildable” means any singular parcel of land meeting all of the
current, minimum lot requirements of the City’s Zoning Code for the particular
district within which the land is located.
   F.   “Lot, corner” means a lot which has at least two adjacent sides
abutting for their full length on a street, provided the interior angle at the
intersection of such two sides is less than 135 degrees.
   G.   “Lot, double frontage” means a lot having a frontage on two non-
intersecting streets as distinguished from a corner lot.
   H.   “Lot frontage” means that dimension of a lot, or portion of a lot,
abutting on a street excluding the side dimension of a corner lot.
   I.   “Lot, interior” means any lot other than a corner lot or through lot
with only one frontage street.
   J.   “Lot lines” means lines bounding a lot as defined herein.
   K.   “Lot line, front” means in the case of an interior lot, in the line
separating said lot from the street. In the case of a corner lot or double
frontage lot, the line(s) separating said lot from the street(s).
   L.   “Lot line, rear” means the lot boundary opposite and most distant from
the front lot line. In the case of a pointed or irregular lot, it will be an
imaginary line parallel to and farthest from the front lot line not less than
10 feet long and wholly within the lot.
   M.   “Lot, reverse frontage” means a double frontage lot which has a
vehicular access point limited to the back of the lot, rather than having
access on its front.
   N.   “Lot line, side” means any lot boundary line not a front or rear lot
line.
   O.   “Lot of record” means a lot which is part of a subdivision, recorded in
the County Recorder’s Office. For lots not part of a recorded subdivision, a
lot of record shall be a lot whose deed is recorded in the County Recorder’s
Office prior to August 16, 1961, the adoption date of the City’s first
subdivision regulation ordinance.
   P.   “Low water entry” means the elevation at which surface water would
enter a building or structure.
13.   Words beginning with “M.”
   A.   “Metes and bounds” means the method used to describe a tract of urban
land intended to be used for dwelling or other purposes, so that it can be
recorded in the County Recorder’s Office, as contrasted with the description of
a part of a properly approved and recorded subdivision plat by the lot and
block number.
14.   Words beginning with “N.”
15.   Words beginning with “O.”
   A.   “100-year storm” means the equivalent of eight and eight-tenths inches
of rain falling in a one-hour period, or less. (Reference June 16, 1990, storm
data). A 100-year storm will have an intensity of rainfall, eight and eight-
tenths, which on the average, will be equaled or exceeded only once in 100
years. This does not imply that it will occur once in 100 years, or having
occurred, will not happen again for 100 years.
   B.   “Outlot” means a lot which is too small, too irregular, or
inaccessible, to allow construction of a house or other structure; or the
remaining area of a large parcel from which one or more smaller lots have been
subdivided.
16.   Words beginning with “P.”
   A.   “Parkway” means a route intended for use by both passenger vehicles and
pedestrians in a park-like setting with adequate separation to protect both.
   B.   “Planning and Zoning Commission” or “Plan Commission,” “Zoning
Commission,” or “Commission” means the Planning and Zoning Commission of the
City.
   C.   “Plat” means a map, drawing, or chart on which the subdivider's plan of
the subdivision is presented and which he submits for approval and intends in
final form to record.
   D.   “Plat, final” means the plan of record of a sub-division, together with
accompanying material as required in Section
175.16.
   E.   “Plat, major” means any subdivision which has four or more lots, or any
size subdivision requiring any new road, extension of municipal facilities, or
common facilities.
   F.   “Plat, minor” means any plat, re-plat, subdivision, or re-subdivision
that contains three or fewer lots; does not involve the installation,
construction, and dedication of any public improvements; and does not designate
any new lot boundaries outside those that already exist.
   G.   “Plat, preliminary” means the plan or layout of a proposed subdivision,
together with the accompanying material as required in Section
175.09.
   H.   “Poles, overhead lines, and associated overhead structures” mean and
include, but are not limited to, poles, towers, supports, wires, conductors,
guys, stubs, platforms, crossarms, braces, transformers, insulators, cutouts,
switches, communication circuits, appliances, attachments, and appurtenances
located above the ground upon, along, across, or over the streets, alleys, and
ways of the City and used or are useful in supplying electric, communications,
or similar or associated services.
   I.   “Private drive” means a vehicular access that services two or more
lots, that has not been dedicated to or otherwise acquired by the City, and
that has not been maintained by the City for public use.
   J.   “Private sanitary sewer system” means a sewer system owned, controlled,
and maintained by property owners, a subdivider, or a duly constituted
homeowners association.
   K.   “Private sewage treatment and disposal system” means all equipment and
materials needed to properly treat and dispose of sewage from a single
residential, commercial, or industrial use.
   L.   “Private water well system” means any excavation that is drilled,
bored, driven, or dug in the earth to provide a source of water for a single
residential, commercial, or industrial use.
   M.   “Public sanitary sewer outlet” means a public sanitary sewerage system
which conveys sewage to a public wastewater treatment facility.
   N.   “Public sanitary sewer system” means a sewer owned, controlled,
maintained, and subject to the jurisdiction of the City Municipal Utilities
Department, its successors, and assigns.
   O.   “Public water supply” means that water system owned, controlled, and
maintained by the City Municipal Utilities Department, its successors, and
assigns.
   P.   “Public Works Director” means the Public Works Director for the City or
a person designated to act in that capacity.
17.   Words beginning with “Q.”
   A.   “Quasi-public sewage treatment and disposal system” means all equipment
and materials needed to properly treat and dispose of sewage from more than one
residential, commercial, or industrial user, and other than a public sanitary
sewer system.
   B.   “Quasi-public water supply system” means any excavation that is
drilled, bored, driven, or dug in the earth to provide a source of water for
more than one residential, commercial, or industrial user, and other than a
public water supply.
18.   Words beginning with “R.”
   A.   “Replat” means a subdivision or plat, the site of which has heretofore
been platted or subdivided with lots or parcels of land. It may include all or
any part of a previous subdivision or plat.
   B.   “Reserve strip” means a narrow parcel of land created by the platting
of property lines several feet inside the property line/street right-of-way
line, which parcel is retained in private ownership and which use is to prevent
access of neighboring property to an improved and dedicated street.
   C.   “Resubdivision” means any division of land which has previously been
included in a recorded plat, including auditor’s plats. In appropriate context,
it may be a verb referring to the act of preparing a plat of previously
subdivided land.
   D.   “Right-of-way” means a strip of land occupied, or intended to be
occupied, by a road, walkway, crosswalk, railroad, or other such use. Every
right-of-way established under this chapter and shown on a final plat is
separate and distinct from the lots and parcels adjoining such right-of-way and
not included within the dimension or areas of such lots or parcels.
   E.   “Roadway” means that portion of the street which has been, or is to be
improved and is or will be, available for vehicular traffic.
19.   Words beginning with “S.”
   A.   “Setback line” means that line denoting the distance required to obtain
the minimum front, side, and rear yards, measured from the property line, as
required by the appropriate zoning regulations.
   B.   “Sewerage system, central” means a type, which is approved by the State
Department of Natural Resources and the County Health Department as properly
designed to serve one or more subdivisions. (A septic tank is not a central
sewerage system.)
   C.   “Sidewalk” means that portion of the street, walkway, or crosswalk
which is paved and intended for pedestrian use only.
   D.   “Site plan” means an aerial view plan of the proposed site showing the
approximate location of the development. A site plan contains those features
listed in Section
175.10.
   E.   “Street” means a general term used to describe a public right-of-way
which provides a channel for vehicular and pedestrian movement, and which may
provide for the primary vehicular and pedestrian access to properties adjacent
to it, and which may also provide space for the location of utilities, (both
above- and below-ground).
   F.   “Street, arterial” means those streets designated and designed to carry
large volumes of traffic from one part of a community to another. They should
have considerable continuity. It will be the largest street size in the
hierarchy. It has a high Average Daily Traffic (ADT) count and is not intended
to be a residential street and will have limited access points as approved by
the Council only. An arterial street should provide connections with major
State and interstate road systems and has a high potential for the location of
significant community facilities as well as retail, commercial, and industrial
facilities.
   G.   “Street, collector” means streets that function to connect smaller
areas of the community and to conduct traffic between arterial streets and/or
various activity centers. It is a principal traffic artery within residential
areas and carries a relatively high traffic volume. A collector has potential
for sustaining minor retail or other commercial establishments along its route
which influence traffic flows.
   H.   “Street, expressway” means a limited access traffic-way connecting two
or more communities. (Interstate 80 is an expressway and an arterial traffic-
way in this City.)
   I.   “Street, local” means streets that are intended to provide access to
abutting properties, while carrying only minimal through traffic. These streets
may be cul-de-sacs, courts, lanes, places, or drives. Occasionally, these
streets will connect other local streets to each other.
   J.   “Street, marginal access” means a local street which is parallel to and
adjacent to primary streets and highways, and which provides access to abutting
properties, usually only on one side, and affords protection to local traffic
from fast through-moving traffic on the primary streets.
   K.   “Street, platted, non-developed” means any previously platted street
that at the time of consideration of any plat or re-plat has anything less than
a permanent, (A.C.C. or P.C.C.), type roadway surface.
   L.   “Street, sub-collector” means streets that provide access to places,
lanes, and drives and which conduct traffic to an activity center or a higher
classification street. It may be a loop street connecting one collector or
arterial street at two points, or a more or less straight street conducting
traffic between collector and/or arterial streets.
   M.   “Street pavement width” means the horizontal distance of the roadway
measured from back of curb to back of curb, or to the edge of the pavement in
those cases where curb and gutter may not be required. (See “Traffic Surface”)
   N.   “Structure” means anything constructed or erected on the ground,
attached to the ground, or attached to something having a location on the
ground, including, but not limited to, buildings, billboards, and other similar
advertising signs, factories, sheds, cabins, factory-built homes, storage
tanks, hot tubs, whirlpools, swimming pools, and other similar uses.
   O.   “Subbase” means the layer or layers of specified or selected material
of designed thickness upon which a base course or pavement is constructed.
   P.   “Subdivider” means an individual, partnership, corporation, or other
legal entity or agent thereof which undertakes the activities covered by these
regulations. Inasmuch as the subdivision plan drawings are merely a necessary
means to the end of assuring satisfactory development, the term “subdivider”
includes “developer,” “owner,” or “builder,” even though the persons and their
precise interest may vary at different project stages.
   Q.   “Subdivision” means either:
      (1)   The division of land into three or more lots, sites, or parcels;
      (2)   The establishment or dedication of a road, highway, or street
through a tract of land regardless of area; or
      (3)   The re-plat or re-subdivision of land heretofore divided or platted
into lots, sites, or parcels, provided however, that the sale or exchange of
small parcels of land to or between adjoining property owners, where such sale
or exchange does not create additional lots, nor place said lots in
nonconformance with the provisions of the zoning ordinance or this chapter,
will not be considered as a subdivision of land; or
      (4)   The improvement of one or more parcels of land for residential,
commercial, or industrial structures or groups of structures, involving the
allocation of land for common use by owners, occupants, or lease holders.
   R.   “Subgrade” means the top surface of a roadbed upon which the pavement
structure and shoulders are constructed.
20.   Words beginning with “T.”
   A.   “Traffic surface” means the wearing or exposed surface of a roadway
used by vehicular traffic. Traffic surface may include prepared shoulders, but
the width is measured between the edge of the surfaced area intended for
vehicular traffic.
   B.   “25-year storm” means the equivalent of five and three-tenths inches of
rain falling in a one-hour period, or less.
21.   Words beginning with “U.”
   A.   “Utility or utilities” means and includes any gas, water, sewer,
electrical, or communication service and all persons providing the same.
22.   Words beginning with “V.”
23.   Words beginning with “W.”
24.   Words beginning with “X.”
25.   Words beginning with “Y.”
26.   Words beginning with “Z.”
175.06   PROCEDURES FOR THE REVIEW OF SUBDIVISIONS.
Pursuant to the authority granted in Section 354 of the Code of Iowa, as
amended, the City desires to review subdivisions within and outside of its
corporate limits as set forth herein. It is hereby required that no subdivision
of land within the City or land located outside of the corporate limits, but
within the following described area:
Beginning at the Northeasterly corporate limits where they intersect with the
State boundary line; thence continuing North along the State boundary line to a
point 1,000 feet North of the Northerly line extended of Section 23 of Township
79 North, Range 5 East, of the Fifth Principal Meridian; thence due West to a
point on the Westerly right-of-way line of U.S. Highway 67; thence Southerly
along said Westerly right-of-way line to the North line of Section 23 of said
Township; thence Westerly along said Northerly line of Section 23 and Section
22 to a point on the Westerly right-of-way line of 277th Avenue; thence
Southerly on said right-of-way line to a point of intersection with the center
section line of Section 22; thence Westerly on said center section line to a
point of intersection with the Westerly line of Section 21 of said Township;
thence South along the Westerly line of said Section 21 to its intersection
with the Northwest corner of Section 28 and the Northeast corner of Section 29
of said Township; thence West along the Northerly line of said Section 29 to
the centerline of 257th Avenue; thence South along said centerline to the
centerline of Territorial Road; thence West along said centerline to the
Westerly border of Section 29 of Township 78N R5E; thence South along the
Westerly borders of Sections 29 and 32 of said township to the centerline of
Indiana Avenue; thence East along said centerline; thence South along the
Easterly border of the Northeast quarter of the Southwest quarter of said
Section 32; thence West along the Southerly border of the Northeast quarter of
the Southwest quarter of said Section 32; thence South along the Westerly
border of the Southeast quarter of the Southwest quarter of said Section 32;
thence East along the Southerly border of the Southeast quarter of the
Southwest quarter of said Section 32; thence South along the Westerly border of
the Northeast quarter of Section 5 of said Township to the centerline of Forest
Grove Road; thence West along said centerline to the Westerly property line of
the Davenport Country Club; thence South along said property line to the
centerline of Wellsferry Road; thence South along said centerline to the
centerline of US Highway 67; thence East along said centerline to the
centerline of 181st Street; thence South along said centerline and extension
thereof to the Mississippi River; thence East following said river and the
meanders thereof to the Western corporate limits of the City; thence following
the City limits to the point of beginning,
shall be recorded in the County or have any validity until it has been approved
by the Council. Each person, firm, or corporation seeking the Council’s
approval of a map, plat, or subdivision will follow the procedures outlined
herein.
1.   In order to make the most of the opportunities related to the subdivision
and to conserve time, effort, and expense, the owner or subdivider should
consult with the Building and Zoning Enforcement Officer prior to the
preparation of the tentative plan of the subdivision. The plan and its
component features shall be consistent with the City’s comprehensive land-use
and other long-range plans.
2.   Requirements of the master street development plan; school and
recreational sites; shopping centers, community facilities; sanitation; water
supply, drainage, and erosion; and relationship to other developments, existing
and proposed in the vicinity, should be determined in advance of the
preparation of the subdivision plan. Consultation should also be held with
those familiar with the economic factors affecting the subdivision. A thorough
estimate of the situation will result in sound decisions with respect to the
form, character, and extent of the proposed subdivision.
3.   Land, which the Planning and Zoning Commission finds to be unsuitable for
subdividing due to flooding or poor drainage characteristics, or topographic
features likely to be harmful to the safety, welfare, and general health of
future residents, will not be subdivided until the objectionable features have
been eliminated, or until adequate safeguards against such hazards are
provided.
In applicable cases, plats will be reviewed by the State Department of Natural
Resources (IDNR) and their findings and recommendations incorporated in the
approval of such plats.
175.07   SKETCH PLAN DISCUSSION AND PRELIMINARY REVIEW REQUIREMENTS.
1.   Pre-submission of Plans Required. Prior to the filing of an application
for a minor plat or a preliminary plat, the Building and Zoning Enforcement
Officer may require that the subdivider submit certain materials relating to
the proposed subdivision. These materials will include information relative to
the site, conditions of the site, existing community facilities and utilities
on and adjacent to the site, number, and size of lots proposed, etc. These
materials will include as a minimum:
   A.   Location Map. This is a plan showing the location and relationship of
the proposed subdivision to the City in general, streets, and other community
facilities serving it. This map will include:
      (1)   Subdivision name in bold letters, centered at the top of the plan.
      (2)   Bold, heavy outline of area to be subdivided.
      (3)   Existing streets and City utilities on/or adjoining the property.
      (4)   North point, graphic bar scale, and date.
      (5)   Outline of the Overlay Flood District area and elevation(s) as
described in Section
170.35 if the proposed subdivision lies within said district and contains three
acres or two lots, whichever is less.
   B.   Sketch Plan. This a plan showing the proposed layout of streets, lots,
and other features in relation to existing conditions, as well as existing
topographic data and schematic diagrams for proposed utilities.
The sketch plan discussion and review does not require formal application, fee,
or filing of the lat. The Building and Zoning Enforcement Officer will submit
the sketch plan material to the Planning and Zoning Commission which will,
within 30 days from the date of submittal, make known its comments regarding
the proposed subdivision to the subdivider and the Building and Zoning
Enforcement Officer
175.08   PLATTING PROCEDURES FOR MINOR AND/OR URBAN RENEWAL DEVELOPMENT PLATS.
The Planning and Zoning Commission and\or Council, may waive any or all of the
requirements relating to the preliminary platting process for proposed
subdivisions containing three or fewer lots, (or any proposed subdivision),
provided that:
1.   All of the lots within the proposed subdivision front on an existing
street;
2.   No public improvement construction is required;
3.   No variation of the requirements of this section are requested, and
4.   No site for a public facility is covered by any part of the plat, or, if
the plat and improvements are being considered under a T.I.F. Development
Agreement and/or Minimum Assessment Agreement within a designated Urban Renewal
Area.
175.09   PRELIMINARY PLAT - PREPARATION AND FILING REQUIREMENTS.
The subdivider will cause to be prepared a preliminary plat and will file
copies of said plat along with the Preliminary Plat Application, (See Appendix
Form A), for plats consisting of four or more lots, a computer generated and
reproduced copy of the proposed plat using “autocad” or some other compatible,
approved drafting software saved to an appropriate storage medium, (flash
drive, compact disk (CD), E-Mail, etc.), and other required materials with the
Building and Zoning Enforcement Officer at least 15 calendar days prior to the
scheduled meeting of the Planning And Zoning Commission at which the plat is to
be considered.
1.   The preliminary plat, (and accompanying plans), of the proposed
subdivision will be drawn to the scale of one inch to 100 feet or larger, but
will not exceed 30 inches by 42 inches in size, and one copy of the plat will
be reduced to fit on an 8-1/2 X 14 inch page and will include:
   A.   Name of the proposed subdivision in bold letters centered at the top of
the plat, (which said name will not duplicate that of any previously recorded
plat).
   B.   The exact length and bearing of the exterior boundary will be shown and
indicated by a solid heavy line.
   C.   Name and address of owner(s).
   D.   Name of person(s) who prepared the plat and owner's attorney.
   E.   North point, graphic bar scale, and date.
   F.   Location of the proposed subdivision by township, section, and range,
and detailed metes and bound legal description, including accurate distances
and bearings from the subdivision to some corner of the congressional division
of which the addition is a part. Reference corners shall be accurately
described on the plat.
   G.   Location, widths, and names of all existing or prior platted streets or
other public ways, lot lines, railroad and utility right-of-ways, parks and
other public open spaces, permanent buildings and structures, houses, permanent
easements, and section and corporation lines within or adjacent to the tract
and/or other relevant information required by the Planning and Zoning
Commission.
   H.   Existing sewers, water mains, culverts, or other underground facilities
within the tract or adjacent to the tract, indicating pipe sizes, grades,
elevations above MSL, manholes, and approximate locations.
   I.   Boundary lines of adjacent tracts of land, showing ownership and zoning
classifications.
   J.   Layout of proposed blocks, (if used), and lots, including the
dimensions of each, and the lot and block number in alphabetical or numerical
order, and street addresses as provided by the City.
   K.   All zoning setback lines shall be indicated by dashed lines with the
appropriate labeling and all existing structures shall be shown as well.
   L.   Location, widths, other dimensions, and names of proposed streets,
alleys, and roads (with radii of all curves and length of tangents shown),
utility easements, parks, and other open spaces or reserved areas.
   M.   Zoning classification(s) of the subdivision.
   N.   Approximate grades of all proposed streets and alleys.
   O.   Typical cross sections of the proposed streets and alleys showing
roadway locations, type of curb and gutter, sub-base materials, surfacing
material to be used, and sidewalks to be installed, (preferably on another
sheet).
   P.   The layout of proposed water mains, sanitary sewer mains, and
appropriate service lines, (preferably on another sheet).
   Q.   The proposed drainage system of the subdivision, including storm
sewers, ditches, culverts, bridges, detention basins, and other structures,
(preferably on another sheet).
   R.   Boundaries of the highest known flood of record affecting the
subdivision and the source of information, if applicable.
   S.   If the proposed subdivision borders on a lake, stream, or the river,
the distances and bearings of a meander line established not less than 20 feet
back from the mean high water mark of the lake, stream, or river.
   T.   Location of any and all “Greenway District” boundaries, if applicable.
   U.   A statement, near the owner’s name, to read: preliminary plat, not to
be recorded.
   V.   A table of the following information:
      (1)   Total acreage of subdivision.
      (2)   Total number of lots, and each lot area.
      (3)   Acreage of public lands to be dedicated other than streets.
   W.   A complete listing, (preferably in a separate document), of all
existing covenants which apply to the land to be subdivided, and a complete
listing of all covenants which are proposed by the subdivider to apply to the
subdivided land and information as to any agreements which have been entered
into with the owners of other property within the neighborhood in which the
proposed subdivision is located, as to general plans for the entire
neighborhood. Reference should be made to the City’s Comprehensive Plan for
suggestions as to the general street pattern and design of the neighborhood.
Wherever possible, all of the property owners within the neighborhood should
endeavor to agree upon a general plan for its development, in order that such
subdivision may be designed as an integral part of a well-considered overall
plan.
   X.   The layout, (preferably on another sheet), of the proposed streets
showing approximate grades as being elevated to or above a 100-year flood level
if the proposed subdivision lies within the Overlay Flood District.
   Y.   The layout of drainage facilities designed to store and convey the flow
of surface waters and flood flows without unduly increasing flood heights and
without causing danger of life loss to persons and/or severe damage to
properties and drainage openings will be sufficient to discharge flood flows
without unduly increasing flood heights. if the proposed subdivision lies
within the Overlay Flood District, (preferably on another sheet).
   Z.   The layout of all proposed water systems and/or sanitary sewerage
systems designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of flood waters into the
systems and discharges from systems into flood waters, and waste disposal
systems to be located so as to avoid impairment of them or contamination from
them during flooding, (preferably on another sheet).
175.10   SITE PLAN.
A site plan, of the proposed subdivision, (based on the preliminary plat), will
be submitted on a separate sheet, and will be drawn to the scale of one inch to
100 feet or larger, but will not exceed 30 x 42 inches in size, and one copy of
the plat will be reduced to fit on an 8-1/2 x 14-inch page and will include at
least the following information:
1.   Existing and proposed contours at two-foot intervals where ground slope is
less than 10 percent, contours at five-foot intervals when ground slope is
greater than 10 percent.
2.   Areas having a slope greater than 10 percent will be highlighted or
specifically delineated in some fashion.
3.   Individual trees having a diameter of four inches or more and general
wooded areas will be indicated.
4.   Rivers, streams, ponds, marshes, other drainage courses, and rock
outcroppings.
5.   Floodplain limits existing and proposed.
6.   Analysis of site run-off characteristics, (including plan(s) and
calculations). Drainage areas shall be drawn showing the direction of flow of
all surface water.
7.   Provisions for control of erosion and sedimentation during construction
including, but not limited to, sedimentation basins, temporary diversions,
contour furrows, and such other provisions as may be required to reduce erosion
and excessive water drainage to downstream adjacent properties and to limit and
control soil losses to not exceed five tons per acre. (Erosion control
structures will be designed for 25-year storm frequencies at a minimum).
8.   A written plan which provides for:
   A.   Preservation of eight inches of topsoil, if available.
   B.   Prompt seeding following grading, including types and methods of
seeding used.
   C.   Seasonal restrictions on the plan.
   D.   Preservation of drainage in field tiles.
9.   The layout of the land contours of all proposed lots with elevation of
sufficient height to permit construction of the lowest habitable floor of a
building elevated to or above a 100-year flood level, if the proposed
subdivision lies within the Overlay Flood District.
10.   Subsurface conditions on the tract, if required by the Commission.
Location and results of tests made to ascertain subsurface soil, rock, and
ground water conditions; depth to groundwater unless test pits are dry at a
depth of five feet; location and results of soil percolation tests if
individual sewage disposal systems are proposed.
11.   Photographs of the site, indicating camera location, directions of views,
and key numbers.
12.   Other conditions on adjacent land. Approximate direction and gradient of
ground-slope, including any embankments or retaining walls; character and
location of buildings, railroads, power lines, towers, and other nearby non-
residential land uses or adverse influences.
13.   Any other information as may be needed to help clarify the existing and
proposed site conditions or as may be required per the site plan criteria
listed in Section
170.57.
175.11   NOTICE OF POSSIBLE EFFECT TO DRAINAGE TILES.
The following is required of a subdivider developing any tract of land within
the boundaries of the City and for lands outside said boundaries and not within
the corporate limits of any other municipality for a distance of two miles:
1.   When filing the preliminary plat, the sub-divider will provide the
following, if tile exists or is reasonably expected to exist:
   A.   Evidence of written notification, given by the subdivider to all
adjacent landowners, of the subdivider plans and advising them that any
drainage tile entering the property that is the subject of the subdivision may
be affected by the development.
   B.   In the event that no field tile exists, or is reasonably expected to
exist, a sworn, certified affidavit must be filed in lieu of notification
documentation.
2.   The following methods of notification will be deemed sufficient compliance
with this subparagraph:
   A.   A return receipt for first class mail containing such notification
signed by the landowner or his representative, or;
   B.   A statement, signed by the subdivider, that after diligent search and
inquiry, the landowner cannot be located for the purpose of sending such
written notification.
3.   A true copy of all duly recorded drainage easements for the benefit of any
adjacent dominant landowners.
4.   A true copy of the pertinent portion of the drainage plat book kept by the
County Recorder pursuant to Section 468.624 of the Code of Iowa, (as amended)
showing all recorded drainage systems. Such pertinent portions will include all
lands contiguous and adjacent to the land that is the subject of the proposed
subdivision. In the event that an adjacent landowner has drainage tile
installed on the property affected by the subdivider’s proposed subdivision,
the subdivider will submit a written plan for continuation of existing drainage
tile to the City. As a condition for approval of the final plan by the Council,
such plan must be approved by the City Engineer, in writing.
175.12   PUBLIC NOTIFICATION.
At the time of filing, an application will be accompanied by a list of names
and addresses of all those people owning property adjacent to and within 200
feet of any part of the proposed subdivision. The Building and Zoning
Enforcement Officer will notify those property owners listed, by depositing
notices in the U.S. Mail, at least seven days prior to the scheduled date of
the regular Planning and Zoning Commission and Council meetings at which time
said plat is scheduled to be reviewed and considered. These notices will be
delivered by certified mail.
175.13   PREVIOUS SUBDIVISION REFERENCE LIST REQUIRED.
At the time of filing, an application will be accompanied by the subdivider’s
previous subdivision, (or other developmental), experience and reference
checklist. The subdivider’s checklist will include, as a minimum, the following
items:
1.   Name(s) of any previous subdivision or development work, (if any).
2.   Name of City or County in which work is located.
3.   Name, address, and phone number of governing body and contact person
overseeing and approving of any previous work.
4.   Date(s) previous work was undertaken.
175.14   PRELIMINARY PLAT SUBDIVISION FEE.
At the time of filing, an application will be accompanied by a certified check
or money order payable to the City to cover the cost of notification and
reviewing the proposed plat and accompanying plans. The following rate schedule
will apply:
 
Number of Lots Contained in Subdivision Fee Schedule
2 -10                                   $250.00
11 or more                              $500.00
 
175.15   PRELIMINARY PLAT - REVIEW AND CONSIDERATION.
1.   Review by City Engineer, Building and Zoning Enforcement Officer, Public
Works Director, and County Board of Supervisors. Immediately upon the filing of
18 copies of the preliminary plat, the Building and Zoning Enforcement Officer
will retain two copies for the City’s file (one copy is to indicate the
Planning and Zoning Commission and Council action), and the remaining copies of
the preliminary plat will be distributed as follows:
   A.   One copy to the City Engineer, if applicable;
   B.   One copy to the Public Works Director, if applicable;
   C.   One copy to each Planning and Zoning Commission member;
   D.   One copy to each Council member and the Mayor.
and, where a proposed plat is outside the City limits but within the area of
subdivision jurisdiction, one copy to the Zoning Administrator of the County.
The City Engineer, if applicable, the Building and Zoning Enforcement Officer,
the Public Works Director, if applicable, and where concerned, the Board of
Supervisors for the County, will review the plat and application materials to
assure that the proposed subdivision complies with the applicable regulations
and requirements and report upon such to the Planning and Zoning Commission.
The Building and Zoning Enforcement Officer will determine if the proposed
subdivision complies with the zoning ordinance. The Building and Zoning
Enforcement Officer will also report upon conditions of the site or adjacent
properties which, while not evident in the application materials, may affect
development upon the site. (Review by the Soil Conservation Services may be
sought where erosion or sedimentation control considerations are evident).
2.   Review by the Planning and Zoning Commission. The Planning and Zoning
Commission will review the preliminary plat and application materials to assure
compliance with the various comprehensive plans of the City. Particular note
will be made that any planned major streets or other planned public facilities
of the community falling in the area of the subdivision being reviewed are
accommodated in the proposed plat. They also will review the reports of the
Building and Zoning Enforcement Officer, City Engineer, Public Works Director,
and County Zoning Administrator, where applicable, with regard to the proposed
subdivision. Within 30 days of the subdivider’s filing for preliminary plat
approval, the Planning and Zoning Commission will make known to the Council and
the Clerk that the preliminary plat has been:
   A.   Approved.
   B.   Approved, subject to modification.
   C.   Disapproved.
If disapproved, the Planning and Zoning Commission will submit to the
subdivider, with a copy to the Clerk, a statement setting forth reasons for the
disapproval, indicating particularly the aspects in which the proposed plat
fails to conform to ordinance requirements. Failure of the Planning and Zoning
Commission to act within 30 days of the filing of the plat application with the
Building and Zoning Enforcement Officer will be deemed approval of the plat
unless, however, an extension of time is mutually agreed upon by the subdivider
and the Planning and Zoning Commission or as such extension of time is
otherwise provided for herein.
The Planning and Zoning Commission will maintain one copy of the preliminary
plat in its files with the Planning and Zoning Commission action noted upon it.
The above-referenced review process notwithstanding, any petitioned matter
submitted to the Planning and Zoning Commission may be withdrawn, amended, and/
or consideration and action upon said matter may be temporarily postponed,
once, for a period not to exceed 30 days from the date of the originally
scheduled meeting, providing a detailed, written, explanatory, request from the
petitioner asking for said withdrawal, time extension, and/or amendment of said
petition is received by the Building and Zoning Enforcement Officer no later
than four working days prior to the originally scheduled meeting date. If such
a request is properly and timely filed, the Planning and Zoning Commission will
continue to meet as scheduled and, in the case of a request for a withdrawal of
the petition, the Planning and Zoning Commission will acknowledge the request
for the permanent record and grant the request. In the case of a request for a
temporary extension of time and/or an amendment to the original petition, the
Planning and Zoning Commission will continue to meet as scheduled and will
acknowledge the request for an extension and/or amendment for the permanent
record and consider and act upon the request(s) at the meeting.
The Planning and Zoning Commission may grant, deny, or conditionally grant or
deny the request for the full-time extension requested or some other time
extension as the Planning and Zoning Commission may deem appropriate, but any
such extension will not exceed 30 days as spelled out above. If the Planning
and Zoning Commission denies a request for extension, then the meeting will be
conducted as scheduled at the specified time and place.
The Planning and Zoning Commission may grant, deny, or conditionally grant or
deny the request to consider and act upon an amended petition as the Planning
and Zoning Commission may deem appropriate.
Any additional expenses incurred by the City as a result of granting an
extension and/or amendment request which was submitted by the petitioner will
be borne by the petitioner and paid in full to the City prior to the date set
for the rescheduled meeting.
Further, consideration and action upon said matter may be temporarily
postponed, once, for a period not to exceed 30 days from the date of the
originally scheduled meeting, providing a detailed, written, explanatory,
request for such action, signed by 20 percent or more of the property owners
whose property boundaries lie within 200 feet, (inclusive of any and all public
and quasi-public right-of-way distances), of the boundaries of the property
upon which the proposed matter is to be considered, is received by the Building
and Zoning Enforcement Officer no later than four working days prior to the
originally scheduled meeting date. If such a request is properly and timely
filed, the Planning and Zoning Commission’s action(s) will be conducted as
spelled out above.
3.   Approval or Rejection by the City Council. The Council will, after being
notified of the Planning and Zoning Commission’s action on the plat, consider
and act on the preliminary plat within 30 days after the first regular Council
meeting following the date of action of the Planning and Zoning Commission. If
the Planning and Zoning Commission does not approve the plat, the Council may
approve said plat and accompanying development proposals only by a four-fifths
vote of the entire membership of the Council.
4.   Action On Preliminary Plat to be Filed with the City Clerk. A certified
copy of the resolution approving the preliminary plat or disapproving the
preliminary plat and stating the reasons, therefore, will be attached to a copy
of the preliminary plat by the Clerk and filed in the office of the Clerk. (See
Appendix Form F.)
5.   Preliminary Plat Approval Not to Constitute Subdivision Approval and
Revocability. Approval of the preliminary plat by the Council does not
constitute approval of the subdivision, but is merely an authorization to the
subdivider to proceed with the preparation of the final plat and any
preliminary plat, or any portion thereof, not final platted is revocable by the
Council.
6.   Time Limitation of Preliminary Plat Approval. Approval of the preliminary
plat will be effective for 12 months; except, however, the Planning and Zoning
Commission, upon written request of the subdivider and advice of the Building
and Zoning Enforcement Officer, may grant an extension of time, not to exceed
an additional 12 months. If the final plat is not filed with the Building and
Zoning Enforcement Officer within 12 months, or within an authorized extension,
the Council’s approval of the preliminary plat will become automatically null
and void. If only a part of a preliminary plat is approved as a part of a
larger final plat, the approval of the remaining portion(s) of the preliminary
plat shall automatically gain an extension of 36 months before another phase of
the plat must be submitted in final form.
175.16   FINAL PLAT - PREPARATION AND FILING REQUIREMENTS.
Following approval of the preliminary plat, the subdivider will cause to be
prepared a final plat and other materials as required for final approval. The
filing for final approval will consist of a fully signed and stamped
reproducible final plat, the final plat application, (See Appendix Form C), for
plats consisting of four or more lots, a computer generated and reproduced copy
of the proposed plat using autocad or some other compatible, approved drafting
software saved to an appropriate storage medium (flash drive, compact disk
(CD), E-Mail, etc.), and such additional information as is outlined herein. All
required materials will be filed with the Building and Zoning Enforcement
Officer at least 15 calendar days prior to the scheduled meeting of the
Planning and Zoning Commission at which the plat is to be considered.
1.   The final plat of the subdivision, (and accompanying plans), will be drawn
to the scale of one inch to 100 feet or larger, but will not exceed 30 x 42
inches in size, and one copy of the plat will be reduced to fit on an 8-1/2 x
14-inch page. The plat drawing will include as a minimum:
   A.   Name of the proposed subdivision in bold letters, centered at the top
of the plat.
   B.   Detailed, legal description of property subdivided showing its location
by distance and bearing to the nearest quarter section monument, including
accurate distances and bearings from the subdivision to some corner of the
congressional division of which the addition is a part. Reference corners shall
be accurately described on the plat.
   C.   Name and address of owner(s).
   D.   Name of person(s) who prepared the plat and owner’s attorney(s).
   E.   North point, graphic scale, and date.
   F.   Accurate exterior tract boundary lines, (indicated by a solid, heavy
line), with dimensions and angles which provide a survey tract, closing with an
error of not more than one foot in 5,000 feet for any lot and not more than one
foot in 10,000 feet for the subdivision.
   G.   All monuments, erected corners, and other points established in the
field in their proper places. (The material of which the monuments, corners, or
other points are made will be noted at the representation thereof, by legend.)
(See Section
175.34(1))
   H.   All proposed streets named and listed.
   I.   All curves supplied with complete and accurate curve notes. (Reference
table(s) may be used.)
   J.   The exact length and bearing of the boundary lines of all blocks,
public grounds, streets, all alleys, and all lot lines, except that when the
lines in any tier of lots are parallel, it will be sufficient to mark the
bearings of the outer lines on one tier thereof. Easements will be shown by
center line and width when lines are parallel to a boundary; otherwise,
boundary bearings and distances will be shown.
   K.   The exact width of all easements, streets, and alleys.
   L.   All blocks consecutively numbered or lettered in alphabetical order.
(The blocks in numbered additions to a subdivision bearing the same name will
be numbered or lettered consecutively through the several additions.)
   M.   All lots in each block numbered consecutively, showing street addresses
as provided by the City.
   N.   All lake, stream, or river shore meander lines established by the
surveyor in accordance with the preliminary plat requirements, the distances,
and bearings thereof, and the distance between the point of intersection of
such meander lines with lot lines and the ordinary high-water mark, including
floodplain boundaries and elevations, if applicable.
   O.   All front, rear, and side setback lines, per the Zoning Code
provisions, and existing structures.
   P.   Areas to be dedicated or reserved for public use, and any area to be
reserved by deed covenant for the common use of all property owners in the
subdivision and, any public areas to be vacated as a part of the plat with
corresponding language.
   Q.   Where provisions are made for access from any subdivision to any lake,
stream, or river, the plat will show the area over which access is provided to
the lake, stream, or river.
   R.   The names of adjoining streets, State highways, and subdivisions shown
in their proper location, with property ownership and zoning classifications
shown.
   S.   Abutting street and State highway lines of adjoining plats shown in
their proper location by dotted lines. The width of these highways will be
given also.
   T.   Certification seal/stamp by a registered State land surveyor indicating
that they have surveyed the subdivision and that the plat conforms to said
survey. (See Appendix – Form K)
   U.   Final approval signature block of the Council and Planning and Zoning
Commission with signature and date spaces for Mayor, Clerk, and Planning and
Zoning Commission Chairperson. (See Appendix – Form G.)
   V.   All land contour, street storm drainage, and water and/or sewerage
system layouts provided in Section
170.27, as defined in the Overlay Flood District of the Zoning Code,
(preferably on another sheet).
   W.   Certification that the natural gas and electric company(s) have
received the final plat and found that the plat meets their minimum utility
requirements.
   X.   Certification that the telecommunication company(s), (telephone, cable
T.V., etc.), have reviewed the final plat and found that the plat meets their
minimum utility requirements.
   Y.   Certification that the County Health Department has reviewed and
approved the final plat, if said subdivision lies outside the corporate limits,
but within the area of subdivision jurisdiction, or if a subdivision
incorporates a private water supply system or a private sewage disposal system.
   Z.   Restrictive covenants, private restrictions, supplemental agreements,
and trusteeships and their periods of existence, if any. Should such
restrictive covenants, restrictions, supplemental agreements, and trusteeships
be of such length as to make the lettering of same on the plat impracticable
and thus necessitate the preparation of a separate instrument, in an acceptable
form suitable for recording. Reference to the existence of such instrument(s)
will be made on the plat. (See Section
175.27(1))
2.   Other Required Documents.
   A.   A notarized “owner’s certificate” executed by the owner(s) of the
property and spouse(s), if any, that the subdivision as it appears on the plat
is with free consent and is in accordance with the desire of said owner(s) and
spouse(s), establishing the setbacks, declaring the limitations on easements,
and providing for any restrictive covenants needed or requested. (See Appendix
– Form H).
   B.   An attorney’s legal opinion placing the fee title in the owner and
certifying that the land is free from encumbrances, or free from encumbrances
other than those provided for in an encumbrance bond duly prepared, executed
and recorded by the owner as required by the Code of Iowa. (See Appendix – Form
L)
   C.   A certificate showing consent to platting by the mortgagee, if any.
   D.   Certification from the County Treasurer showing that all taxes and
special assessments due on the property to be subdivided have been paid in
full. (See Appendix – Form M)
   E.   A hold-harmless and waiver of liability agreement protecting the City
from any damages, claims, or suits resulting from the construction and
development by the owner and/or subdivider. Said agreement will be recorded
with the plat. (See Appendix – Form S)
   F.   A certification by a registered professional engineer licensed in the
State indicating that they have prepared the plans for all public improvements
proposed to be installed in the subdivision. (See Appendix – Form I)
   G.   Prior to any construction within or adjacent to the proposed
subdivision, the subdivider will cause to be prepared complete construction
plans, specifications, and engineering drawings, including profiles, cross
sections, and all necessary and applicable details of all public improvements,
including streets, sidewalks, alleys (where applicable), water systems,
sanitary sewerage systems, gas, electric, and communications systems and storm
drainage systems which will conform to the preliminary plat requirements. This
submission will be in accordance with the Standard Public Works Improvements
Specifications. Four full sets of these plans will be submitted to the Building
and Zoning Enforcement Officer not less than 30 days prior to the commencement
of any construction activity or the scheduled meeting of the Planning and
Zoning Commission at which the plat is to be considered, whichever is
applicable.
These plan sets will include, as a minimum, but are not limited to, the
following:
      (1)   A copy of the most recent, current, preliminary plat and site plan
for the area showing the exact area(s) covered by the construction plans and
any proposed revisions to the preliminary plat which are to be considered as a
part of the construction plan approval.
      (2)   A tentative draft, final plat, (or a stamped, recorded, final
plat), for the entire area upon which improvements are to be proposed for
acceptance. Where improvements are to be made or where utility extensions will
be required outside of the final plat limits, easements covering those areas
will be provided.
      (3)   Specific plans related to the site plan which are to ensure that
desirable features are retained, topsoil and tile drainage are preserved and
erosion is limited.
      (4)   Detailed State I.D.N.R. approved plans for sanitary sewerage
facilities in accordance with the Standard Public Works Improvements
Specifications. Where public sewers are not a part of the plan, a certification
by the County Board of Health that the area can be adequately served by other
means will be required.
      (5)   Detailed State I.D.N.R. approved plans for water service will be
provided, including the location of hydrants, valves, service lines, and other
appurtenances.
      (6)   Detailed plans, etc., for streets, storm sewers, culverts, and such
other drainage and/or erosion control facilities as may be required.
      (7)   Grade sheets, including street cross-sections at 50-foot intervals
will be supplied by the sub-divider's engineer prior to any work being done.
These sheets will be reviewed by the City and their issuance will be the
contractor’s authority to proceed.
      (8)   All changes to the approved plans will be submitted to the City in
the form of change orders after said changes have been prepared by the
subdivider’s engineer, and have been approved by the subdivider and the
subdivider’s contractor. The City Administrator is hereby authorized to approve
change orders on behalf of the City, provided the change orders do not
represent a material change from the plans that are approved by the Council.
      (9)   The subdivider’s detailed estimate of the cost, (including unit
prices, quantity estimates, etc.), of the minimum improvements required, and a
statement from the City concurring with the subdivider’s estimate.
      (10)   Where a subdivision within the City limits is to contain sewers,
sewage treatment plants, water supply systems, park areas or other physical
facilities which will not be maintained by existing public agencies, provisions
will be made by a supplemental agreement which will become a part of the deed
restrictions and which is acceptable to the proper public agencies, for
jurisdiction over the continuous maintenance, supervision, operation, and
reconstruction of such facilities by the lot owners in the subdivision.
      (11)   A written, signed agreement or contract between the City and the
subdivider specifying the exact nature of the improvements to be installed or
work to be done, the time period in which the work is to be completed, and any
other pertinent provisions regarding the particular subdivision improvements.
(See Appendix – Form N)
      (12)   Such other certificates, affidavits, endorsements, or dedications
as may be required by the Planning and Zoning Commission and/or the Council in
the enforcement of these regulations.
      (13)   A surety bond in double the amount of the lien shall be secured
and recorded, if a lien exists on the land included in a subdivision plat, and
the required consent of the lienholder is not attached for one of the following
reasons: the lienholder cannot be found, in which case an affidavit by the
proprietor stating that the lienholder could not be found shall be recorded
with the bond; or the lienholder will not accept payment or cannot, because of
the nature of the lien, accept payment in full of the lien, in which case an
affidavit by the lien holder stating that payment of the lien was offered but
refused shall be recorded with the bond. The bond shall run to the City and be
for the benefit of purchasers of lots within the plat, and shall be conditioned
for the payment and cancellation of the debt as soon as practicable, and to
hold harmless purchasers or their assigns and the City from lien.
175.17   GUARANTEE OF IMPROVEMENTS.
The final plat submitted to the Planning and Zoning Commission for approval
will be accompanied by a notice from the Clerk stating that there has been
filed a certificate by a registered professional engineer stating that all
improvements and installations to the subdivision required for its approval
have been made or installed in accordance with the City specifications, (See
Appendix – Form J), a complete set of detailed, as constructed drawings, have
been received; and a maintenance bond or bonds, from the subdivider,
guaranteeing the improvements for a period of two years against defective
materials and workmanship have been received. (See Appendix – Form P)
175.18   INSTRUMENTS THAT MAY BE FILED IN LIEU OF THE FINAL COMPLETION OF
IMPROVEMENTS.
In lieu of final completion of the improvements before the final plat is
approved by the Council, the subdivider may file one or more of the following
instruments with the Building and Zoning Enforcement Officer:
1.   A performance bond with the City and/or the County, depending upon the
location of the subdivision, of sufficient amount, which will insure to the
City or County that the required improvements will be completed by the
subdivider within two years from the date of acceptance of the final plat by
the Council and/or County Board of Supervisors; and
2.   An assessment waiver which will provide that the City may, without notice,
construct and install the improvements and assess the total cost thereof
against the subdivided property in accordance with City and State requirements
regarding special assessments, and that the subdivider(s), for themselves,
their heirs, their grantees, their assigns, and all subsequent owners of any
part of the subdivided area, waive all formalities, rights of protest, and
rights of appeal to the construction and installation of the improvements by
the City and to the assessment of the total cost thereof against the subdivided
area, even though the cost may exceed the amount that can legally be assessed
against the subdivided area by the City.
The assessment waiver will further provide that the subdivider and the persons
who own the property benefited by the improvements at the time construction and
installation of the improvements is initiated by the City will be jointly and
severally liable for any difference between the cost of the improvements and
the amount which can be legally assessed by the City against the subdivided
area. (See Appendix – Form Q)
   A.   The filing of an assessment waiver for a particular improvement, in
lieu of final completion of the improvement, will not be permitted if:
      (1)   The abutting property which would be assessed for the cost of the
improvement pursuant to the City’s regular assessment procedures is not
included within the platted area; or,
      (2)   The past performance of the subdivider in installing subdivision
improvements within or without the City indicates, or other circumstances exist
which indicate, that the improvement may not be installed within two years from
the date of Council approval of the final plat; and/or
3.   A Tax Increment Financing (TIF) development agreement and/or a Minimum
Assessment Agreement guaranteeing the completion of improvements, if the
subdivision is located within an Urban Renewal Area within the City.
175.19   PUBLIC NOTIFICATION.
At the time of filing, an application will be accompanied by a list of names
and addresses of all those people owning property adjacent to and within 200
feet of any part of the proposed subdivision. The Building and Zoning
Enforcement Officer will notify those property owners listed, by depositing
notices in the U.S.
Mail, at least seven days prior to the scheduled date of the regular Planning
and Zoning Commission and Council meetings at which time said plat is scheduled
to be reviewed and considered. These notices will be delivered by certified
mail.
175.20   FINAL PLAT SUBDIVISION FEE.
At the time of filing, an application will be accompanied by a certified check
or money order, payable to the City, to cover the cost of notification and
final review of the proposed plat and accompanying plans. The following rate
schedule will apply:
 
Number of Lots Contained in Subdivision Fee Schedule
                                        $250.00 (If classified as a minor plat,
2 - 10                                  only one $250.00 filing fee is
                                        required)
11 or more                              $500.00
 
175.21   FINAL PLAT - REVIEW AND CONSIDERATION.
1.   Review by City Engineer, Building and Zoning Enforcement Officer, Public
Works Director, and County Board of Supervisors. Immediately upon the filing of
the reproducible final plat, the Building and Zoning Enforcement Officer will
retain one copy for their own files, (on which is to be indicated Council
action), and they will distribute the remaining copies of the final plat, as
follows:
   A.   One copy to the City Engineer, if applicable.
   B.   One copy to the Public Works Director, if applicable.
   C.   One copy to each Planning and Zoning Commission member.
   D.   One copy to each Council member and the Mayor.
and, where the proposed plat is outside the City limits, but within the area of
subdivision jurisdiction, one copy to the Zoning Administrator.
2.   Review by the Planning and Zoning Commission. The Planning and Zoning
Commission will review the comments of the Building and Zoning Enforcement
Officer, the Public Works Director, (if applicable), the City Engineer, (if
applicable), and where concerned, the County Board of Supervisors and, make its
own study to assure compliance with these regulations and substantial
conformity to the approved preliminary plat or conditionally approved plat
subject to any modifications requested. The Planning and Zoning Commission will
approve or disapprove the final plat within 30 days after submission of the
final plat materials by the subdivider to the Building and Zoning Enforcement
Officer. Failure of the Planning and Zoning Commission to act within 30 days
will be deemed to be approval; unless, however, the subdivider and the Planning
and Zoning Commission have mutually agreed to an extension of time, or as such
extension of time is otherwise provided for herein. The Planning and Zoning
Commission will make known immediately to the Clerk and the Council its action
upon the final plat.
The above referenced review process notwithstanding, any petitioned matter
submitted to the Planning and Zoning Commission may be withdrawn, amended, and/
or consideration and action upon said matter may be temporarily postponed,
once, for a period not to exceed 30 days from the date of the originally
scheduled meeting, providing a detailed, written, explanatory request from the
petitioner asking for said withdrawal, time extension, and/or amendment of said
petition is received by the Building and Zoning Enforcement Officer no later
than four working days prior to the originally scheduled meeting date. If such
a request is properly and timely filed, the Planning and Zoning Commission will
continue to meet as scheduled and, in the case of a request for a withdrawal of
the petition, the Planning and Zoning Commission will acknowledge the request
for the permanent record and grant the request. In the case of a request for a
temporary extension of time and/or an amendment to the original petition, the
Planning and Zoning Commission will continue to meet as scheduled and will
acknowledge the request for an extension and/or amendment for the permanent
record and consider and act upon the request(s) at the meeting.
The Planning and Zoning Commission may grant, deny, or conditionally grant or
deny the request for the full-time extension requested or some other time
extension as the Planning and Zoning Commission may deem appropriate, but any
such extension will not exceed 30 days as spelled out above. If the Planning
and Zoning Commission denies a request for extension, then the meeting will be
conducted as scheduled at the specified time and place.
The Planning and Zoning Commission may grant, deny, or conditionally grant or
deny the request to consider and act upon an amended petition as the Planning
and Zoning Commission may deem appropriate.
Any additional expenses incurred by the City, as a result of granting an
extension and/or amendment request which was submitted by the petitioner, will
be borne by the petitioner and paid in full to the City prior to the date set
for the rescheduled meeting.
Further, consideration and action upon said matter may be temporarily
postponed, once, for a period not to exceed 30 days from the date of the
originally scheduled meeting, providing a detailed, written, explanatory
request for such action, signed by 20 percent or more of the property owners
whose property boundaries lie within 200 feet, (inclusive of any and all public
and quasi-public right-of-way distances), of the boundaries of the property
upon which the proposed matter is to be considered, is received by the Building
and Zoning Enforcement Officer no later than four working days prior to the
originally scheduled meeting date. If such a request is properly and timely
filed, the Planning and Zoning Commission’s action(s) will be conducted as
spelled out above.
3.   Approval or Rejection by the City Council. The Council will, after being
notified of the Planning and Zoning Commission’s action on the plat, consider
and act on the final plat within 30 days after the first regular Council
meeting following the date of action of the Planning and Zoning Commission. If
the Planning and Zoning Commission does not approve the plat, the Council may
approve said plat and accompanying development proposals only by a four-fifths
vote of the entire membership of the Council.
4.   Action on Final Plat to be Filed with the City Clerk. A certified copy of
the resolution approving the final plat, or disapproving the final plat and
stating the reasons, therefore, will be attached to a copy of the final plat by
the Clerk and filed in the office of the Clerk. (See Appendix – Form T)
5.   Appeal of Review or Disapproval. If the plat is disapproved or approved,
subject to condition(s) by the City, the applicant has the right to appeal,
subject to the provisions of Section 354.10 of the Code of Iowa, to the
District Court within 20 days after the date of the denial of the application
or the date of the receipt by the applicant of the requirements for approval of
the subdivision.
6.   Time Limitation for Recording of the Final Plat. An approved final plat
will be filed with the County Recorder within 45 days of the date of approval
by the Council, and the County Board of Supervisors, where applicable, and if
not filed within such time, will have no validity, and will not be recorded
without reapproval by the Council and recertification by the Clerk. Before it
is recorded in the office of the County Recorder, the provisions of Chapter 354
of the Code of Iowa, and amendments thereto, will be complied with. Within five
working days after recording, the duly certified copy will be filed with the
Clerk. No building permits will be issued until verification of such recording
is on file in the office of the Clerk, or unless such provisions are waived, in
writing, by the Council.
7.   Release, Expiration, or Extension of Bond. Prior to the release or
expiration of any bond, the Council will request that the City Engineer certify
that they were notified by the subdivider to witness the installation of the
required improvements at key times so as to be able to certify that all
required improvements were properly installed and that neither the subdivision
as constructed, nor improvements installed, deviate from the approved final
plat.
Should the required improvements not be completed within the duration of the
