bond, the subdivider may request of the Council an extension of time for the
installation of the balance of the improvements. Should such a request be
granted, the subdivider will deposit with the City, a performance bond for the
length of time extension is granted. The bond format to be used will be that
form shown in the Appendix – Form O and will be approved as to adequacy of
amount by the City Engineer.
175.22   STREETS AND STREET RIGHT-OF-WAY CRITERIA.
1.   Streets to be Continued. Streets in new subdivisions shall be designed and
adjusted to the contour of the land so as to produce usable lots and streets of
reasonable gradient and to provide for the continuation of existing and planned
streets. In addition, the Planning and Zoning Commission and/or the Council may
require the provision of right-of-way for the connection of the proposed
subdivision to any adjoining unsubdivided land. The street and alley right-of-
way arrangements shall also be such as to cause no hardship to owners of
adjacent property when they plat their own land and seek to provide for
convenient access to it. Whenever a street or alley right-of-way abuts the
tract to be subdivided, the plat will include the additional right-of-way which
is necessary to make the width of the entire right-of-way conform to the
requirements of this Code. The width of right-of-ways will be no less than the
width required by this section except where:
   A.   The owner of the abutting property agrees, in writing, to dedicate
sufficient right-of-way to make a full width right-of-way and the subdivider
agrees to construct a full width street or alley on said right-of-way; or,
   B.   The City owns the abutting property and agrees to the use of it for
right-of-way purposes and the subdivider agrees to construct a full width
street or alley on said right-of-way.
2.   Street Construction. Those streets contained within the boundaries, and
the extensions thereof, and those non-developed, platted streets immediately
adjacent to and abutting any subdivision for a distance greater than 100 feet
will be constructed or reconstructed of concrete or asphalt. All such streets
will be constructed/reconstructed to those minimum standards as set forth
herein and as more specifically alluded to in the City’s Standard Public Works
Improvement Specifications.
3.   Discourage Through Traffic on Local Streets. Local streets will be laid
out so that their use by through traffic will be discouraged.
4.   Streets to Intersect at Right Angles. Intersection of streets will be as
nearly right angles as possible. No street will intersect any other street at
an angle less than 80 degrees, or greater than 100 degrees.
5.   Not More than Two Streets to Intersect. Intersection of more than two
streets at a point will be prohibited.
6.   Intersection Corners to be Rounded. Property lines at street intersections
will be rounded with a radius of not less than 25 feet. Comparable cut-offs or
chords in place of such rounded corners are acceptable.
7.   Obstruction to Visibility at Intersections Prohibited. There will be no
obstruction of any type to visibility at street intersections within the sight
triangle formed by the center of the intersection and two points 75 feet
distant, each point being on the centerline of any intersecting street.
8.   Minimum Centerline Offsets. Offset streets are to be avoided. Where they
are deemed necessary, a minimum horizontal distance of 150 feet will be
maintained between the centerline of the offset streets.
9.   Connecting Street Lines to be Joined by Curves. Connecting street lines,
deflecting from each other at any one point by more than 10 degrees, will be
joined by curves, the inner radius of which will be not less than 350 feet for
arterial streets, 250 feet for a collector street, and 100 feet for sub
collector and local streets.
10.   Reverse Curves to be Connected by Tangent. A tangent or portion of a
street in a straight alignment and of not less than 100 feet in length will be
introduced between reverse curves on arterial and collector streets.
11.   Right-of-Way and Pavement Widths. Right-of-way widths and pavement widths
measured between the back of the curbs or to the edge of the pavement where
curbs may not be required, will be provided as follows:
 
Street Classifications                          Right-of-Ways Pavement Widths
Arterial                                        80 feet       48 feet
Collector                                       80 feet       45 feet
Sub-collector                                   60 feet       31 feet
Local (Drives, lanes, places, and cul-de-sacs)  60 feet       31 feet
(Without Parking Restrictions)
Local (Drives, lanes, places, and cul-de-sacs)  60 feet       31 feet
(With Parking Restrictions)
 
12.   Maximum and Minimum Street Grades. Street grades as measured along the
centerline will be not less than one-half of one percent and not greater than:
 
Arterial                          5 percent
Collector                         5 percent
Any cul-de-sac                    6 percent
Sub-collector                     6 percent
Local (drives, lanes, and places) 8 percent
 
13.   Cul-De-Sac and Loop Streets. Cul-de-sac streets will meet all the
requirements for a local street and, in addition, will be constructed to
provide a turnaround with a right-of-way radius of not less than 50 feet and a
pavement radius of not less than 40.5 feet. No cul-de-sac will exceed a six
percent grade. No cul-de-sac will exceed 600 feet in length. Cul-de-sacs and
loop streets will only be allowed on local classified streets. Exception: The
Council may determine a different street turnaround standard or classification
within a planned unit development based upon the applicable land use and the
number of lots served. All measurements will be made along the center line of
the cul-de-sac or loop street right-of-way. Lengths will be determined by
measuring from the center line of an intersecting street to the center line of
the intersecting street for a loop street or circle drive, or from the center
line of the intersecting street to the termination of the right-of-way for a
cul-de-sac.
Cul-de-sacs with islands will have a minimum island radius of 30 feet. Paving
width will be uniform around the island. Design of non-concentric or irregular
shaped islands may be approved by the City after consideration of the effects
of the design on water drainage, snow removal, garbage collection, and street
sweeping, etc.
14.   Change in Street Grade. All changes in street grades will be connected by
vertical curves of minimum length in feet equal to 25 times the algebraic
difference in percents of grade. In no case will the vertical curve be less
than 100 feet in length. Final decision on the above to be made by the City.
15.   Half Streets. Half streets will be prohibited.
16.   Buffer Treatment Between Subdivisions and Adjacent Uses. Where a proposed
subdivision contains an existing or proposed arterial street or abuts such a
street or land use which may have an adverse effect on a subdivision, the
Planning and Zoning Commission or Council may require some buffer treatment
such as frontage roads, reverse frontage with screen planting along the rear
lot lines, deep lots, or any other such treatment which may protect the
proposed subdivision from these outside influences. (See Sections
170.43 and
170.55).
17.   Access to Highways Under State Jurisdiction. If the tract of land
proposed to be subdivided, or any part thereof, lies adjacent to a highway over
which the Iowa Department of Transportation (IDOT) has jurisdiction with
respect to maintenance and upkeep thereof, and an entrance or entrances are
desired from such highway to lots, streets, roadways, or alleys in such
proposed subdivision, the subdivider will submit to the Planning and Zoning
Commission an approved permit from the IDOT, granting permission to obtain and
construct such an entrance or entrances. Whenever the proposed subdivision
contains or is adjacent to a highway designated as a controlled-access highway
by the IDOT, provisions will be made for a marginal-access street, a parallel
street at a distance acceptable for the appropriate use of the land between the
highway and such parallel street, or the limiting of access, where possible and
practical, to said street by restrictive covenants.
Whenever the proposed subdivision contains or is adjacent to a street
designated as an arterial street or as a collector street in the master street
development plan, provisions may be made for limiting access, where possible
and practical, to said street by restrictive covenants.
18.   Street Names. Streets will be named in accordance with the present naming
system. Streets, that are obviously in alignment with others already existing
and named, will bear the name of the existing street. Otherwise, names will not
duplicate existing street names, and names similar to existing street names
will not be permitted.
19.   Sidewalks. Sidewalks of at least four feet in width will be provided on
both sides of all streets and the edge most distant from the curb will be
placed a distance of one foot from the property line, or as otherwise specified
by the City. The City reserves the right to require additional width depending
on the character of the development. The extra width is to be provided at the
subdivider’s expense. Materials, location, widths, and construction methods
will be determined by the City in accordance with the minimum standards set
forth in the City’s Standard Public Works Improvement Specifications.
175.23   ALLEYS AND ALLEY RIGHT-OF-WAY CRITERIA.
1.   Alleys in Commercial or Industrial Districts. Alleys may be provided in
commercial and industrial districts, except that the Planning and Zoning
Commission or Council may waive this requirement where other definite and
assured provisions are made for service access, such as off-street loading,
unloading, and parking, consistent with and adequate for the uses proposed.
2.   Alleys Prohibited in Residential Districts. Alleys are prohibited in
residential districts.
3.   Width of Alleys. Alleys will have right-of-way and pavement widths of not
less than 24 feet, and 18 feet, respectively.
4.   Alignment of Alleys. Alley intersections and sharp changes in alignment
will be avoided, but where necessary, corners will be cut off sufficiently to
permit safe vehicular movement.
5.   Dead-End Alleys to be Avoided. Dead-end alleys will be avoided where
possible, but if unavoidable, will be provided with adequate turn-around
facilities at the dead-end, as determined by the Planning and Zoning Commission
or Council.
175.24   BLOCKS.
1.   Shape of Blocks. No specific rule concerning the shape of blocks is made,
but blocks must fit easily into the overall plan of the subdivision and their
design will show consideration of topography, lot planning, traffic flow, and
public areas.
2.   Length of Blocks. Block length will not exceed 1,200 feet. Where a
subdivision adjoins an arterial street, the greater dimension of the block will
front upon such arterial street to avoid unnecessary access or egress, except
upon approval by the City.
3.   Width of Blocks. The width of blocks will not be less than 220 feet and
not more than 350 feet, except upon approval by the City.
4.   Blocks in Commercial or Industrial Areas. Blocks intended for commercial
or industrial use will be designated as such, and the plan will show adequate
off-street areas to provide for parking, loading docks, and such other
facilities that may be required to accommodate motor vehicles.
5.   Pedestrian Cross Walks. The Planning and Zoning Commission or Council may
require the construction of pedestrian crosswalks in blocks which exceed 800
feet in length. Crosswalk easements not less than 10 feet in width will be
provided where deemed necessary at the approximate center of the block. The use
of additional crosswalks, in any instance, to provide safe and convenient
access to schools, parks, or other similar destinations, may be required by the
City.
175.25   LOTS.
1.   Lot Size, Width, Depth, Shape, and Orientation. The lot size, width,
depth, shape, and orientation will be appropriate for the location of the
subdivision and the type of development contemplated, and will be established
on all lots; providing, however, that such setback lines are not less than the
applicable requirements of the appropriate underlying zoning district. The
depth-to-width ratio of the usable area of a lot will be at a maximum of 3.0 :
1.0.
2.   Building Setback Lines to be Established. Building setback lines,
appropriate for the location of the subdivision and the type of development
contemplated, will be established on all lots; providing, however, that such
setback lines are not less than the applicable requirements of the appropriate
underlying zoning district.
3.   Lot Lines to be at Right Angles to Street Lines. Side lot lines will be
substantially at right angles or radial to the center line of the street or
center of a cul-de-sac turn-around.
4.   Corner Lots to be Extra Width. Corner lots for residential use will have
extra width to permit appropriate building setback from both streets.
5.   Every Lot to Have Frontage On and Access to a Public Street. Every
subdivision of land will be such as to provide, by means of a public street,
each lot with satisfactory access to an existing public street. No lot will
have a frontage width of less than 40 feet, or that as specified for the
underlying zoning district, whichever is larger.
6.   Reverse Frontage and Double Frontage Lots Not Normally Allowed. Double
frontage and reverse frontage lots will be avoided except where essential to
provide separation of residential development from traffic arteries, or to
overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation, or except where
desired, along arterial, limited access highways or streets, lots may face on
an interior street and back on such thoroughfares.
7.   Land Remnants (Outlots). All land within a subdivision shall be
encompassed into platted lots or dedicated public right-of-ways and no
undesignated land remnants will be permitted.
8.   Reserve Strips Not Allowed. Reserve strips created by the platting of
property lines, several feet inside the property line/street right-of-way line,
with the objective being the receiving of remuneration for access to an
improved street will not be allowed.
9.   Acre Subdivision. Whenever an area is divided into lots containing one to
three acres, inclusive, and there are indications that such lots will
eventually be resubdivided into smaller building lots, consideration will be
given to the street and lot arrangement of the original subdivision so as to
allow the opening of additional streets and the ultimate extension of adjacent
local streets which will permit a logical arrangement of smaller lots. Land
dedications and easements provided for the future opening and extensions of
such streets may, at the discretion of the Council, be made a requirement of
the original plat.
10.   Subdivision On or Overlapping City Limits. Should a subdivision be on or
overlap the City limits, it will be platted so the City limit boundary, will be
also a street right-of-way line or will be a lot line. In no case will a lot be
platted so as to be bisected by the City limit boundary line.
11.   Shopping Centers. Wherever possible, unit shopping centers, based upon
sound development standards, should be designed in contrast to the platting of
lots for unrestricted commercial use.
12.   Additional Width for Lots Abutting a Water Course. Lots abutting a water
course, drainageway, channel, or stream will have additional minimum width or
depth as required to provide an adequate building site and afford the minimum
usable area required for front, rear, and side yards while not restricting the
water course.
175.26   EASEMENTS.
1.   Utility Easements to be Provided. Easements across lots or centered on
rear or side lot lines will be provided for utilities and will be at least 10
feet wide on each side of all rear lot lines and side lot lines where
necessary.
Easements of greater width may be required where needed. Easements will be at
final grade before any utilities are provided for the property and the
subdivider, contractor, or builder will keep all easements free of any
excavation dirt, construction material, or any other obstacles during
construction.
2.   Utility Service Easements. A blanket easement will be provided to allow
individual utility service lines to be extended from utility trunk service
lines, providing that the individual service line traverse only that parcel on
which the structure to be served is located.
3.   Maintenance and Flowage Easements Provided for Natural Water Courses.
Whenever any stream or important surface watercourse is located in an area that
is being subdivided, the subdivider will, at their own expense, make adequate
provisions for straightening or widening the channel so that it will properly
carry the surface water and will also provide and dedicate to the City an
easement along each side of the stream, which easement will be for the purpose
of widening, improving, or protecting the stream and for recreational use. The
width of such easement will not be less than 20 feet on either side from the
watercourse centerline and the total width of the final easement will be
determined by the amount needed to adequately provide for any necessary channel
relocations and straightening. The subdivider will notify adjacent properties/
communities, the Corps of Engineers (C.O.E.), if applicable, and the Iowa
Department of Natural Resources (IDNR) prior to any alteration or relocation of
a watercourse, if the stream or watercourse drains an area in excess of 10
square miles, and a “401 Water Quality Permit” application shall be made
directly to the IDNR and (C.O.E., if applicable), in these instances. For
drainage areas less than 10 square miles, any changes in the stream or
watercourse as a result of the subdivision will be considered and acted upon by
the City during the subdivision review process.
If the outlet for surface drainage is outside of the boundaries of a
subdivision, the sub-divider shall also provide drainage easements and/or
flowage agreements from abutting property owners to said approved outlet.
4.   Free Access of Authorities to Easements. No tree, shrub, or structure will
be placed or erected in any easement for purposes of preventing the proper
authorities free access to and use of such easements at any time.
5.   Access Control. Each lot in a subdivision will have access to a local,
sub-collector, or collector street, except lots having a minimum of 150 feet
frontage on an arterial street may be granted direct access to that street,
provided that design standards for sight and stopping distances are met.
6.   Land for Public Purposes. Where sites for parks, schools, playgrounds, or
other public uses are located within the subdivision area as shown on the
City’s Comprehensive Plan, or where such sites appear to be desirable, the City
may request their dedication for such purposes, or their reservation for a
period of one year following the date of the approval of the plat. In the event
a governmental agency concerned passes a resolution expressing its intent to
acquire the land so reserved, the reservation period shall be extended for an
additional six months.
175.27   CHARACTER OF DEVELOPMENT.
1.   Generally. The Planning and Zoning Commission or Council will have the
right to require that certain minimum regulations, and restrictive and
protective covenants regarding and controlling the type and character of
development, be incorporated in the final platting process.
Such regulations will be intended to protect the character and value of the
surrounding development and will also tend to secure the most appropriate
character of development in the property which is being subdivided.
In addition to other approved regulations, stipulations, conditions, and
covenants provided by the subdivider, the following shall be incorporated into
each subdivision plat as a minimum:
   A.   Prior to the issuance of an occupancy permit and the actual occupancy
of any structure, any disturbed areas of a lot not otherwise landscaped or
paved, located between the rear building line and the front street curb line
(s), will be sodded. All other disturbed areas of the lot will be hand-seeded
or hydro-seeded.
   B.   With the exception of non-storage, recreational-related buildings or
uses, (i.e., swimming pools, gazebos, children’s playhouses, etc.), no detached
accessory building or use will be allowed on any lot within the subdivision.
   C.   Parking provisions relating to recreational vehicles and/or trucks will
be subject to those provisions contained within the Section
170.52
2.   Protection of Natural Vegetation Cover. Whenever a wooded site is to be
developed, no more than 15 percent of the naturally occurring canopy-tree cover
will be removed due to surface earth grading, roadway construction, building
site clearance, or any other improvement. Whenever removal of more than 15
percent of the naturally occurring vegetation cover is deemed necessary and
unavoidable, a mitigating, replanting measure will be implemented. Such
mitigation will require re-establishment of two native trees of a similar
species to those removed, for every three trees of four inch caliper or greater
removed or fatally damaged within two years after the acceptance of the
improvements.
3.   Open Space Requirement. In all residential subdivisions of 15 lots or more
there will be a minimum of 10 percent or a minimum of 6,000 square feet,
whichever is greater, of the subdivision dedicated or reserved as usable common
open space land. The land will be within or contiguous to the subdivision.
Common open space land will be clearly designated on the subdivision plan as to
character of use and development, be intended for the public use of all
citizens, and will not include: (i) areas reserved for the exclusive use or
benefit of an individual tenant or owner; (ii) dedicated streets, common wells,
sewage treatment facilities, and other public right-of-ways; or, (iii)
vehicular drives, parking, loading, and storage areas.
   A.   Large lot subdivisions, provided that at least 90 percent of all lots
have lot areas of one acre or more, will be exempt from the open space
requirements of this section, provided that adequate deed restrictions will
limit subsequent lot re-subdivisions. Exemptions may be provided if within one-
quarter of a mile to an existing public park or designated greenway.
   B.   Guidelines for designating open space land will be as follows:
      (1)   Areas may include environmentally sensitive land, such as stream
beds, marshes, and steep slopes, however, a minimum of 50 percent of the land
must be level ground that is within or contiguous to the subdivision and
suitable for active recreation.
      (2)   The length will not be more than five times the width, (except in
the case of a bikeway proposal).
      (3)   It will be easily accessible to the public.
      (4)   It must have topsoil and be able to grow grass.
      (5)   May include enclosed drainage easements that are compatible for
intended usage.
      (6)   May include land in a high power transmission line easement, but
only a maximum of 20 percent of the open space requirement may fall within this
type of area.
   C.   Bikeways constructed according to the following standards may be
included as a part of the reserved open space: (a) right-of-way at least 12
feet wide; and (b) a permanently paved surface of asphaltic cement concrete or
Portland cement concrete (ACC or PCC) at least eight feet wide, four inches
thick, on a well-drained subsoil base. As an incentive for the development of
bikeways, the land area occupied by the bikeway will be counted as double
towards fulfilling the minimum open space requirement, provided that at least
10,000 square feet of other open space has been set aside for active and
passive use.
   D.   Suitable provisions for the maintenance and upkeep of open space shall
be provided through a homeowners association, deed covenants, or through other
similar approved means as approved by the City.
4.   Perimeter Fences. Any subdivision boundary adjoining an existing
agricultural land use will be fenced with lawful fences to prevent livestock
and horses from entering the other property. Where no fence exists or where an
existing fence is in need of repair, the cost will be assigned to the
appropriate landowner. Future repair and maintenance will be done by the
agricultural landowner with the cost prorated according to length of fence
between the homeowners and the agricultural landowner.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 359A)
175.28   GENERAL INFORMATION.
All public or private utilities or improvements, including, but not limited to,
public and private sanitary sewers, storm sewers, water systems, and streets,
shall be constructed as set forth on the approved final subdivision plans, in
accordance with the City’s Standard Public Works Improvement Specifications and
standard drawings for construction in effect at the time of the subdivision
construction, and the provisions of Section
175.33.
1.   Construction Plans Prepared by a Registered Engineer. Construction plans
for all public improvements to be installed will be prepared by a registered
state professional engineer. (See Appendix – Form I)
2.   Construction to City Specifications. The type of materials and
construction for improvements in subdivisions will be in accordance with the
City’s Standard Public Works Improvement Specifications and standard drawings
for construction in effect at the time of construction. Said specifications and
standard drawings will be revised at such time as the City deems appropriate
and become effective on the following January first and remain in effect until
revised. Revisions to the City’s standard specifications and standard drawings
will be approved by the Council on or before November first of each year and
will take effect the following January. Subdivisions receiving final approval
after November first, but before January first, will use the new approved
standard specifications and standard drawings. Changes in the City Standard
Public Works Improvement Specifications will be incorporated into actual
construction at the earliest possible time prior to the approval of the final
plat or expiration of the performance bond.
Construction drawing review, construction observation, inspection, and testing
of the improvements will all be performed under the direction of the City, or
by a qualified engineer, or inspection and testing laboratory, as approved by
the City. The City may consult with the Soil Conservation District on erosion
control.
The inspecting agency, if different than the City, will submit daily reports to
the City on forms approved or furnished by the City, certifying compliance of
all construction performed under the City’s Standard Public Works Improvement
Specifications.
3.   Completion of Improvements. No public improvement will be considered as
completed until officially approved and formally accepted by the City.
4.   Improvement Costs to be Paid by Subdivider. Any and all costs associated
with the platting, development, and installation of improvements in connection
with a subdivision created under these provisions shall be paid for by the
subdivider, unless otherwise provided for by a formal agreement between the
City and the subdivider. (i.e., T.I.F. Development Agreement, Minimum
Assessment Agreement, etc.)
5.   Payment of City-Related Engineering and Inspection Fees. The cost of any
City related engineering and inspection of the improvements, based upon the
amount of time devoted to the project, will be paid for by the subdivider to
the City prior to the release of any bond and prior to the City’s acceptance of
the final plat, and/or improvements.
6.   Improvement Credit: Procedure Established. Upon the installation of
improvements required by this Code which may provide benefits to other
properties in the vicinity of the land to be subdivided, which cross or adjoin
other properties and can be used by such properties, the subdivider and the
City may, by contract, agree that upon the connection or use of the
installations made by the subdivider by others, within a period of 10 years
following their installation, the new user or users will pay to the City a fee
in an amount agreed upon by the subdivider and the City, the amount of such fee
to be credited to and paid to the subdivider.
175.29   STREET AND ALLEY IMPROVEMENTS.
1.   All Streets Constructed to Standards. The construction of all streets and
alleys will be in accordance with the design standards set forth in this Code
and in accordance with the City’s Standard Public Works Improvement
Specifications.
2.   Curb and Gutters. Curb and gutters will be required on all streets and
alleys and the design and construction will be in accordance with the City’s
Standard Public Works Improvement Specifications. The minimum grade of any
street gutter will not be less than four-tenths percent.
3.   Curb Corners. Curb corners of all streets will have radii of not less than
25 feet.
4.   Street Pavement Widths. The subdivider will be responsible for providing
street pavement widths in accordance with those provisions of Section 175.29
(5).
5.   Paving Requirements. The surface and pavement dimensions and
characteristics, including thickness and base courses, shall follow the
guidelines of the City Standard Public Works Improvement Specifications Manual.
6.   Stormwater Inlets. Stormwater inlets will be provided within the street
improvements at points specified by the City.
7.   Sidewalks. Sidewalks and crosswalks will be paved and constructed in
accordance with the standards set forth in Section
175.22(19) and the City Standard Public Works Improvement Specifications.
8.   Traffic Control Devices. All traffic control devices and other associated
street signs for intersections and/or other features as designated by the City,
will be paid for and/or provided by the subdivider and said devices, signs, or
other features, will be in conformance with the Manual on U.T.C.D.
9.   Street Lighting. Provisions will be made by the subdivider to pay for and
furnish streetlights in the number and types so designated to comply with the
standards set by Illuminating Engineering Society of North America in ANSI/IES
RP-8-18 and the Department of Transportation or as designated in the approved
street lighting plan for the City. Any additional, special, or ornamental
streetlights, not otherwise provided for in the City’s master street lighting
plan, requested by the subdivider, will be paid for by the subdivider.
10.   Acceptance of Street Dedications. No street in any subdivision that has
been approved by the City after July 1, 1983, will be officially accepted by
the City for the improvement and maintenance thereof until the minimum
improvements required by this Code have been made either by the subdivider(s)
or by the abutting property owners. Private streets, not dedicated to the City,
may be approved by the City where adequate covenants or other legal documents
ensure that the City will not have or need to assume any maintenance or other
responsibility for such street, unless or until it is brought up to full City
standards required by this and other City ordinances. In this regard, building
setback lines should accommodate the layout of such public streets in case of
future conversion.
11.   Driveways. All driveways, approaches, and associated appurtenances
constructed within the public right-of-way will be constructed in accordance
with the provisions enumerated in the Municipal Code.
12.   Designating Street Addresses. Street addresses will be assigned to each
lot in the subdivision by the City according to the City’s master addressing
guidelines and regulations, and shall be shown on each lot on the final plat or
in tabular form. Any variation from these procedures must be approved by the
Council.
175.30   SEWAGE DISPOSAL.
1.   Connection to Public Sewer System. Connection to the public sanitary sewer
is required for every lot in a proposed subdivision located within the
corporate limits. Whenever a subdivider can provide conclusive evidence to the
Planning and Zoning Commission and the Council that public sanitary sewers are
not readily and reasonably available, the subdivider will design the
subdivision to be served by private sewers accessible to each lot in the
subdivision and connected to a private treatment facility other than a septic
tank, approved by the City and the County Board of Health. All sewers will be
constructed to standard City specifications and will have prior approval of the
City that said private sewer system will be compatible for connection to public
sanitary sewer facilities when available. Maintenance of private sanitary
sewers and treatment facilities will be the responsibility of the subdivider or
a duly constituted homeowners association, until such time as it is connected
to public sewers. Sanitary sewer mains will be televised and inventoried with
GPS locations and depths to the City’s specifications immediately prior to
being dedicated and accepted by the City. The sewers will then be dedicated to
the City and thereafter be maintained as part of the public sanitary sewer
system. (A duly constituted homeowners association will be one whose articles
of incorporation have been approved by the City.)
Private or quasi-public sewage treatment and disposal systems and water well
systems allowed in any subdivision will be designed and constructed in
accordance with standard State and County Board of Health laws, rules, and
regulations.
Construction observation and testing of improvements mentioned will be
performed under the direction of the County Board of Health.
2.   Sewage Disposal Outside of the City Limits. Lots outside of the corporate
limits, but within the area of subdivision jurisdiction which cannot be served
by a central sewerage system, will have a minimum width of 100 feet, measured
at the building line, and a minimum area of 20,000 square feet, unless poor
percolation conditions exist in the area.
In this case, a minimum of one acre will be required, subject to the County
Health Department requirements.
3.   Sewer Installed to Comply with Specifications. Sanitary sewers will be
installed to comply with specifications established by the City and with the
approval of the Iowa Department of Natural Resources (IDNR).
175.31   WATER SUPPLY.
1.   Connection to Public Water Supply System. Connection to the public water
supply system is required for every lot in a proposed subdivision located
within the corporate limits when a public water supply system is reasonably and
readily available.
2.   Water Supply Outside of the City Limits. Lots outside of the corporate
limits, but within the area of subdivision jurisdiction, may be served by a
public or quasi-public private well system.
3.   Water Supply Installed to Comply with Specifications. Water supply systems
will be installed to comply with specifications established by the City and the
Iowa Department of Natural Resources (IDNR).
4.   Connection to Private Community Water Supply System Beyond Available
Public Water Supply. Any subdivision which is located within the City limits
and beyond a reasonable distance from the public water system, and if connected
to the public system would yield 15 or more water hook-ups and/or 25 or more
water users, may be allowed to use its own quasi-public water supply system.
This quasi-public water supply system will be installed in accordance with this
section and in compliance with specifications established by the City, Iowa
Department of Natural Resources (IDNR), County Health Department, and all other
applicable State agencies and in compliance with the Safe Drinking Water Act of
1974, as amended.
This system will be so designed so that, at such time as the public water
supply, in the judgment of the City, passes within a reasonable distance of the
subdivision, it may be connected to the private supply and become a part of the
public water supply. No private water supply will be interconnected with any
public water supply.
5.   Lots Not Served by Public Sanitary Sewer and Water Supply Systems. In a
proposed subdivision located within the corporate limits, all lots served by
both individual subsurface sewage treatment facilities and individual water
supply systems will have a minimum width of 100 feet, measured at the building
line, and a minimum area of 30,000 square feet.
6.   Installation Of Dry Water Supply and Sanitary Sewer Systems. If the
proposed subdivision is to be constructed within an area of the City that is
not presently being served by the Municipal Water Supply and/or Sanitary Sewer
Systems, but is reasonably expected to be accessed by said systems within a
period of time not exceeding five years, then the Council may require the
subdivision improvements to include “dry” in-place, but inoperable conveyance
facilities and all associated appurtenances necessary to furnish each lot of
said subdivision with a public water supply and sanitary sewer services, when
they become available. Each such case in this matter will be evaluated and
considered on the merits of that case.
175.32   STORM DRAINAGE.
1.   Land Subject to Flooding or Containing Poor Drainage Characteristics. No
plat of a subdivision will be approved which is subject to periodic flooding or
which contains extremely poor drainage facilities, or where conditions are such
that adequate drainage of the streets, and the entire subdivision, is
impossible.
However, if the subdivider agrees to make improvements which will, in the
opinion of the Planning and Zoning Commission or Council, make the area
completely safe for occupancy and provide adequate street drainage, the
preliminary and final plat of the subdivision may be approved.
2.   Installation Of Storm Drainage Systems. The entire subdivision will be
served by one or more storm drainage systems which will be separated and
independent from the sanitary sewer system and which will provide adequate
outlets to other downstream storm drainage systems. All lots and internal
streets shall be adequately drained. The storm drainage system for the
subdivision will be composed of two distinct systems, one to handle low
intensity storms (the minor system) and another (the major system) which comes
into use when the minor system has insufficient capacity or becomes inoperable
due to temporary blockage.
The minor system will consist of closed and open conduits and their
appurtenances. The minor system will have the capacity and detention facilities
needed to capture and convey runoff from a 25-year storm occurring throughout
the drainage area served by this system and, in a way, which will cause only
minor public inconvenience. The release rate out of any stormwater collection,
conveyance, and/or detention facility shall be restricted so as not to exceed
the pre-development volume and conditions produced by a five year storm. The
velocity of water leaving the subdivision shall be reduced so as not to cause
erosion.
The major system is the route followed by runoff waters when the minor system
is inoperable or inadequate. The major system will have a capacity to convey
runoff from a 100 year storm occurring throughout the drainage area served by
this system. The major system will be designed so that no damage is caused to
private structures due to flooding. Surface flows on streets will be kept
within reasonable limits, and will not exceed the gutter capacities at any
time.
All storm drainage system designs will utilize runoff calculations based on all
tributary areas considered fully developed in accordance with the City
Comprehensive Land-Use Plan or other more intense development, when required by
the City.
All storm drainage system designs will consider and accommodate backwater
effects caused by the receiving storm drainage systems as such systems
currently exist. All storm drainage collection and conveyance system plans will
be designed and sealed by a professional engineer, licensed to practice within
the State.
175.33   UTILITIES.
1.   Underground Utilities. All utilities provided as new installations to any
area subdivided will be provided underground, except those utility services
which are listed under Subsection A as exceptions. All utilities provided as
new installations to any areas subdivided for industrial purposes will be
installed underground within any portion of the subdivision lying within 100
feet of a residentially zoned area that is already served by underground
utilities, except those utility services which are listed under Subsection A as
exceptions. The subdivider will be responsible for making the necessary
arrangements with appropriate utility companies for the proper installation of
underground utilities in accordance with the utility company's rules and
regulations.
   A.   The following instances, with the conditions listed for each of them,
may be considered exceptions to this section:
      (1)   Principal electric distribution feeder circuits and electric
transmission circuits will not be required to be installed underground.
      (2)   Any service which is considered by the utility company to be
unfeasible for undergrounding, due to high voltage or inordinately high and
unjustified cost, can be provided overhead, upon approval by the City.
      (3)   In the instance where topographic or soil conditions cause the cost
of underground installations to be extremely and unjustifiably high, these
services can be provided overhead, upon the approval of the City; however,
utility companies may provide services aerially on a temporary basis until
approval of the City is acquired for installation of permanent underground
facilities, but said utility companies will file with the building inspection
department, notice both of the installation of temporary services and their
termination.
      (4)   Where a subdivision is developed adjacent to or abutting an
existing development, and in such a way as the new development would normally
share primary feeder lines that have already been installed, and when those
feeder lines have been installed overhead, the new development can use those
feeder lines which do exist, providing that the service lines to the structures
in the new development are installed underground, and providing that all
additional necessary feeders are installed underground or in accordance with
the provisions of this section.
      (5)   Developments having preliminary plat approval prior to the
effective date of this section will not be subject to the requirements of this
section.
   B.   The following specific facilities will not be subject to the
requirements of this section:
      (1)   Poles used exclusively for police and fire alarm boxes, or any
similar municipal equipment installed under the supervision of and to the
satisfaction of the City.
      (2)   Poles used exclusively for street lighting.
      (3)   When authorized by the City, poles and overhead lines and
associated overhead structures crossing or entering any portion of a district
from which overhead wires have been prohibited and originating in an area in
which these structures are allowed.
      (4)   Overhead lines attached to the exterior of a building by means of a
bracket or similar device and extending from one location on the building to
another location on the same building, or to an adjacent building without
crossing any public street or right-of-way.
      (5)   Radio antenna and associated structures and equipment used for
furnishing communications service.
      (6)   Service terminals, and necessary pad-mounted electric equipment,
installed above ground used to distribute communication and electric services
in underground systems.
   C.   All underground electric distribution circuits installed by the utility
company for the purpose of distributing electrical current within the City will
be installed in accordance with the Safety Rules for the Installation and
Maintenance of Electric Supply and Communication Lines, U.S. Department of
Commerce, National Bureau of Standards.
175.34   MONUMENTS.
1.   Monuments. Unless otherwise specified by the City, monuments will be iron
rods, pipes, or steel bars at least 36 inches long and not less than five-
eighths inches in diameter.
Monuments will have a cap affixed to the top of same that is capable of being
detected by magnetic or electronic equipment and is made of a reasonably inert
material, bearing an embossed or stencil-cut marking of the State registration
number of the registered land surveyor that prepared the survey. These
monuments will be placed not more than one quarter mile apart in any straight
line and at all lot corners, at each end of all curves, at the point where a
curve changes its radius, and at all angle points in any line, except when such
corners or points fall within a street or proposed future street, the monuments
shall be placed in the sideline of the street.
175.35   OVERLAY FLOOD DISTRICT.
1.   Land Contours. Land contours of all lots with elevation of sufficient
height to permit construction of the lowest habitable floor of a building at or
above the base flood level as defined in the Overlay Flood District of the City
Zoning Code, will be provided.
2.   Streets. Streets with grades being at or above the base flood level as
defined in the Overlay Flood District of the City Zoning Code, will be
provided.
3.   Drainage Facilities. Facilities designed to store and convey the flow of
surface waters and flood flows, without unduly increasing flood heights and
without causing danger of life loss to persons and/or severe damage to
properties, will be provided.
4.   Water and Sewer Systems. Water systems and/or sanitary sewerage systems,
designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of flood waters into the systems
and discharges from the systems into flood waters and required waste disposal
systems located so as to avoid impairment of them or contamination from them
during a flood, will be provided.
175.36   EROSION AND SEDIMENTATION CONTROL.
1.   Generally. For areas of the subdivision that may have ground cover,
removed at any one time, the subdivider will provide a plan including, but not
limited to, the following provisions:
   A.   The type of soil comprising the premises and the physical properties of
each type;
   B.   The type of temporary vegetation and/or mulching that will be used in
these areas to control soil losses from the construction site so as not to
exceed five tons per acre. Erosion control structures will be designed for 25-
year storm frequencies at a minimum. Both measures will maintain soil losses to
a minimum during:
      (1)   The construction period for any type improvement thereon; or,
      (2)   The changes being made in the land contours thereof; or,
      (3)   The removal or destruction of topsoil, trees, and other vegetation
located thereon.
   C.   The location, construction, and maintenance program of temporary
sediment basins (debris basins, de-silting basins, or silt traps) or other
control measures in the subdivision.
A statement of the time period within which temporary control measures will be
removed after construction ends and be replaced by permanent measures.
   D.   The type of permanent and final vegetation and structures that will be
planted or installed on the described premises.
A statement of the time period within which all vegetation and structures are
to be planted or installed.
   E.   In those instances where five or more acres of any subdivision will be
disturbed at any one time, the subdivider will acquire a National Pollutant
Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit and submit a copy to the City prior
to receiving authorization to proceed with site development.
2.   County Soil Conservation District Recommendations. The submitted plan from
the subdivider will incorporate the appropriate recommendations, if any, of the
County Soil Conservation District.
If any of the Soil Conservation District’s recommendations are not incorporated
into the plan, the subdivider will set forth, in writing as part of the
platting procedure, the reasons for the deletion, and the City will determine
their inclusion or exclusion.
A copy of the approved soil conservation plan will be filed with the County
Soil Conservation District and the City.
175.37   ESTABLISHMENT OF OFFICE AND APPOINTMENT OF A BUILDING AND ZONING
ENFORCEMENT OFFICER.
1.   Establishment of Position. The position of Building and Zoning Enforcement
Officer has been established in which is vested the duty of the administration
of these regulations as specified herein, and such other related regulations as
are assigned to that office.
2.   Appointment to Office. The Building and Zoning Enforcement Officer is
appointed by the City Administrator and shall be a person who is qualified by
professional or practical training and experience to conduct the affairs of
that position.
175.38   STANDARDS AND MINIMUMS.
These land subdivision regulations are adopted and enforced only as minimum
standards, and all developers may develop their subdivisions at higher
standards. The subdivider is encouraged, at any time, to surpass these
regulations.
175.39   AMENDMENTS TO AND REQUIRED OF THIS CHAPTER.
This chapter will be reviewed, in its entirety, not less than once every 10
years by the Planning and Zoning Commission. Amendments to this subdivision
chapter may be made by the Council as provided by statute. No amendment will be
adopted without first referring the proposed amendment to the Planning and
Zoning Commission and receiving a written recommendation therefrom. However, if
no recommendation is received within 90 days, the amendment will be deemed to
be approved by the Planning and Zoning Commission.
175.40   BUILDING PERMITS.
No building permit will be issued by the City for the construction of any
building or structure, within a subdivision as defined herein, which has been
approved for platting or re-platting, until the required utilities have been
installed and made ready to service the property, and streets providing access
to the subject lot or lots have been reconstructed or are in the process of
being constructed, or unless specifically approved for issuance, in writing, by
the Council.
175.41   OCCUPANCY PERMITS.
No occupancy permit will be granted by any governing official for the use of
any building or structure within a subdivision approved for platting or re-
platting until the required utilities have been installed and made ready to
service the property, and streets providing access to the subject lot or lots
have been reconstructed or are in the process of being constructed, or unless
the provisions of Section
170.38 have been met in full, or unless specifically approved for issuance, in
writing, by the Council. Notwithstanding the provisions enumerated above,
occupancy permits may be granted where a cash bond is filed with the City for
incomplete subdivision improvements. The cash bond will be on a form approved
by the City and will be in the amount of 150 percent of the cost of completing
the remaining improvements. The exact amount of the cash bond and the date the
bond may be called by the City, if improvements are not completed, will be
determined by the City at its sole discretion. In addition, a waiver of
liability will be executed by the subdivider, which will hold the City and the
public harmless for any damages that may be caused to yet unaccepted
improvements by their use of incomplete facilities, and will be filed with the
City along with the cost of recording said waiver. No occupancy permit will be
granted where the total estimated cost of the incomplete subdivision
improvements necessary to serve the lot(s) exceed $20,000.00 or when, in the
determination of the City, the streets are inadequate to allow City services to
be provided to the lot.
175.42   APPROVAL REQUIRED - RESTRICTIONS ON UNAPPROVED PLATS.
1.   No plat of any subdivision will be recorded in the County Recorder’s
Office or have any validity until it has been approved in the manner prescribed
in this Code.
2.   Any subdivision or resubdivision platted after the adoption of this Code,
which has not been approved in accordance with the provisions contained in this
title, will be subject to the following:
   A.   No building or repair permits will be issued for any structure located
therein.
   B.   No public improvements will be allowed therein.
   C.   No public funds will be expended for any public improvements or
activities therein.
   D.   It is unlawful to offer for sale, sell, trade, or otherwise convey any
parcel or tract platted therein.
175.43   PENALTIES.
Any person, firm or corporation, agent, employee, or contractor who violates,
disobeys, omits, neglects, or refuses to comply with, or who resists
enforcement of, any provision of this Zoning Code commits a municipal
infraction and as such will be subject to the penalties and remedies specified
in the
Chapter 3. In the event that any building or structure is erected, constructed,
reconstructed, altered, repaired, converted, or maintained; or any building,
structure, or land is used in violation of this Zoning Code, the Council, in
addition to other remedies, may institute an action for injunctive relief or
any proper action or proceedings in the name of the City to prevent such
unlawful erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, repair,
conversion, maintenance, or use, to restrain, correct, or abate such violation,
to prevent the occupancy of such building, structure, or land, or to prevent
any act, conduct, business, or use; in or about such premises in violation of
this Zoning Code. Any building erected, raised, or converted, or land; or
premises used in violation of any provisions of this Zoning Code or the
requirements thereof, is hereby declared to be a public nuisance, and as such,
in addition to the remedy provided above, may be abated in such manner as
nuisances are now, or may hereafter, be abated under the Municipal Code.
175.44   REPEALER.
All ordinances and resolutions or any part thereof, in conflict with all or any
part of this Zoning Code, are hereby repealed.
175.45   CONFLICT WITH PRIVATE DEEDS, COVENANTS, AND AGREEMENTS.
The provisions of this Zoning Code are not intended to abrogate any easement,
covenant, or any other private agreement. In case of any conflict between this
Zoning Code or part thereof, and the whole or part of any existing or future
private covenants, and the whole or part of any existing or future private
covenants or deeds, the most restrictive provision(s) will apply.
